142577623.review:
I have had Oceanhorn in my backlog for a couple of years and started it about three or four times, before finally committing to it earlier this year. Well, the commitment did not last. The graphics and atmosphere is charming and Zelda-like, but the progression and gameplay is anything but.

My problems with the game after 2 hours and a handful of dungeons are:

a) The player character has less stamina than a Call of Duty protagonist, only being able to "run" 10 steps and only in a straight line, before having to wait 10+ seconds for the stamina to regenerate. What a curious design choice, as it slows down movement -- especially in situations where you do not know where to go and are searching around.

b) The primary weapon, the sword, has an abysmal reach. What is it with some games forcing you to basically hug an enemy before you are able to make contact with a swing? Combat is not necessarily hard, since most enemies (in the beginning) are braindead, but it's tedious.

c) Quest, dungeon and world progression is locked behind arbitrary gates (sometimes literally) whose solution is either mindnumbingly dumb (e.g. key in the only other dungeon room) or impossible to figure out without looking up a guide or the forums (e.g. "jumping" into the well on the starter island -- you cannot jump, at least I never found an item that allowed me to jump in the early game, so you have to go all over the place and into some caves to emerge at a higher point of the island than the well to be able to fall down into it; and the well is F'N half the player height).

d) After not playing for a couple of weeks I forgot what to do next and there is no in-game quest marker or quest log or I am too dumb to find it. So I just figured out I would try a couple of islands, which only made the experience worse due to the following:

e) The fucking travel system. The screenshots make it look like Zelda: The Wind Waker, but it damn sure isn't. Instead you are forced to wait for up to minutes to make your way slowly from one island to another, on rails and your only saviour from boredom being a shooting minigame that got tedious after 5 seconds. It's really, really annoying.

That's a lot of negatives, which somehow breaks my heart as I was looking forward to a Zelda-like adventure and do not necessarily mind that the story is completely uninteresting. But despite it's charming look, the game is shallow and mis-designed on too many levels for me to maintain attention. This one goes into the ZZZ pile.

139707231.review:
The developer of Oceanhorn set out to make a Zelda-like game and all the elements are there. But it lacks polish and that really keeps it from being the excellent game it could have been. Design choices like having to hit the collectible red gems nearly 10 times in order to pick them up are illogical and never explained (I spent much of the game thinking I just couldn't do anything with them yet). Sailing from island to island can quickly become tedious. Sometimes your ability to jump down from a ledge is determined by whether or not it is a shortcut (you can't jump down) or backtracking (you'll probably fall down on accident).

I really wanted to love this game, and it was good enough that I played it through to the conclusion and want to give the sequel a try. If you have it in your library already or you see it in a bundle, it might be worth playing; it isn't a bad game by any means. But otherwise I can't recommend it.

I do not recommend Oceanhorn for PC.
 Is it a good game? No. Is it a bad game? No.
It's just boring and average. You should play more fun games instead.

The game is practically a copy of Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass (for DS). However, the time mechanics have been removed. Also meaningful quests, challenging puzzles and good fighting mechanics.
When you start the game, it feels charming and you're intrigued. But the game never delivers more. The longer you play, the more it feels like any depth is missing.
On the good side, there is a good soundtrack, the game has no bugs and the graphics are nice. On the downside, nothing is really fun, most things are more more and tedious and the fishing mini game has the worst mechanics of any fishing game that I ever played.

As a result, you should stay away from this game as it feels like you wasted you time and stick to better alternatives. Even thou there is no original Zelda game on PC, there are great alternatives, for example Blossom Tales (very close to a Zelda), Tunic (mostly very challenging combat), Figment (charming graphics and storyline) and many more.

123671766.review:
Lo he jugado en PSVita, siendo una versión claramente inferior, no sólo por el tema del aspecto gráfico, texturas de menor calidad, menor cantidad de FPS y una resolución más baja, todo eso es comprensible teniendo en cuenta la máquina que es, pero lo que más empaña la experiencia de esa versión es la distancia a la que se encuentra la cámara. Es evidente el motivo por el que se ha hecho este ajuste, ya sea para tener que cargar un menor número de elementos en pantalla a la misma vez o porque al jugar en una pantalla tan pequeña, todos los elementos se verían diminutos de otro modo, pero siento que le perjudica más que le beneficia, ya que el videojuego parece estar diseñado para una distancia de cámara mayor, ya que en determinados niveles hay elementos que no se muestran en su totalidad, haciendo más obtusa la lectura del mapa y la resolución de puzles en general.

Y otro aspecto negativo que me gustaría destacar y que va muy relacionado con el punto anterior, se trata del diseño de niveles. Cada zona, sobre todo las primeras islas se sienten como si los elementos hubieran sido colocados de manera un poco aleatoria para rellenar y dar la sensación de no estar tan vacío, dando lugar a algunos elementos que no tiene sentido, por ejemplo una escalera que no va a ningún sitio o un pasillo que da la sensación de esconder un cofre al final del recorrido y que de repente se corta, entre otros. Sumado a esto está el aspecto de la verticalidad de los niveles, hecha a base de bloques tipo vóxel, distribuidos de una forma que en la gran mayoría de ocasiones hacen difícil la exploración por el hecho de que, como he dicho antes, la lectura del mapa es obtusa (sumado a la corta distancia a la que se encuentra la cámara). Además, el apartado visual es agradable a la vista, pero la perspectiva elegida no termina de convencerme. Y en cuanto a la historia, comentaré que sirve como hilo conductor para avanzar por las distintas fases pero nada más, no está mal pero se toma demasiado en serio a sí misma y si fuera un poco más desenfadada le habría sentado genial.

Normalmente en mis análisis suelo mencionar más los aspectos negativos antes que los positivos. ¿Quiere decir esto que Oceanhorn sea un mal juego? Para nada, de hecho lo recomiendo siempre y cuando te guste la saga Zelda y no comiences el juego con las expectativas demasiado altas. Se nota que tiene un origen humilde y comete algunos errores en cuanto a diseño, pero se fija en los más grandes del género (tiene claras referencias a Zelda, y más concretamente a Wind Waker) y en definitiva es un buen juego de aventuras, tiene muchas buenas ideas en su planteamiento y la sensación de exploración está bastante conseguida, te hace querer hablar con los ciudadanos o investigar en los libros de las aldeas para descubrir nuevas localizaciones, y siempre que entras a una nueva isla se renueva esa sensación de exploración y se siente muy fresco. 

Algunas de las buenas ideas que comentaba anteriormente y que me han gustado son esa progresión de niveles a base de obtener experiencia ya sea derrotando enemigos, avanzando en la historia, explorando y descubriendo secretos, y que no hace que tu personaje sea más fuerte aumentando estadísticas y ya, sino que te recompensa aumentando la cantidad de un determinado objetos que puedes llevar en cada momento, o haciendo que tus habilidades consuman menos estamina y tus magias consuman menos maná, o mejorando la navegación con el barco. Y aquí viene mi último comentario negativo, que es la exploración de los mares. 

Siento que el sistema de navegación está algo desaprovechado, que puedas desplazarte de una isla a otra simplemente pulsando a donde quieres ir está bien sin más, pero sería más emocionante tener un movimiento libre, descubrir algunas islas por el simple hecho de pasar cerca de ellas y acabar en ellas de casualidad, mayor variedad de enemigos (sólamente hay un enemigo acuático que es la copia del octorok y ya), poder encontrarte eventos, mejorar el barco, etc. No digo que esté mal tal y como lo han diseñado, simplemente se siente desaprovechado y harían al título aún más disfrutable incluyendo algunas de estas mecánicas.

120187044.review:
It had sat in my backlog for years and I finally got around to playing it. 5hrs in at the moment and it is a very lackluster Zelda clone. It has all the basics you'd expect in a Zelda game (sword, shield, bow, bombs, coins, hearts, simple combat, charge up whirl attack, NPCs, etc), but it the story, voice acting, and pacing are all subpar. The fact that I was lead to believe I'd be able to navigate to islands like in Wind Waker but in fact it's just an on-rails shooter (after you get the boat gun) when traveling between islands from a menu was such a let down. also the stamina bar is trash, depletes to fast for most of the game (I'm praying it lasts longer late game for dash, right now it's almost useless save for one or two quick dsashes), and takes way to long to refill.

It's not a terrible game by any means and I'll likely finish it, but years of it sitting in my backlog sort of built an aura around it that the game just failed to live up too.  If it's on sale for under $5 go ahead and grab it you could do a lot worse, just don't go in expecting a masterpiece.  

Well 17 hours to 100% it so if you want an easy 100% this is it.   It's not terrible, but it really does just feel like a watered down Zelda game.

119760090.review:
A pretty decent game, obviously inspired by The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, but unfortunately Oceanhorn doesn't do much to differentiate itself from its inspiration, and feels more like an off-brand Zelda copy. This doesn't mean it's a bad game though, just that it isn't very original.

The game mostly consists of you traveling between different islands by boat, exploring them and finding items that will help you to reach new areas. There are a few boss battles thrown in here and there, and while a couple of them were decent, most aren't all that interesting.

The level design is pretty good, with some well thought-out puzzle sections, although there are some places where you can trap yourself and possibly even soft-lock your entire save file. There's also a bunch of places where you can spot things like floating trees, or gaps in the terrain so you can see through to the sky or sea.

One thing I didn't like is the fact that there's no easy way of knowing whether or not you can blow up certain walls like you can with the cracks in Zelda games. Having to just bomb anything you suspect might be possible to destroy isn't good design, but thankfully bombs are easy to come by.

Defeating enemies nets you XP, and while leveling up doesn't increase stats like HP or anything, it does refill your items and health, plus it grants you some effect like less stamina cost for blocking, or the ability to carry more of a certain item. You can also get XP by completing various challenges, which are like in-game achievements.

It's not the longest game out there, and it took me roughly [spoiler]14[/spoiler] hours to 100% and get all achievements. There is a decent amount of exploration and non-mandatory islands though.

The controls are a bit off, probably due to it being an iOS release originally. They're not terrible or anything, but there are some quirks like not being able to block in the direction you want using the shield, and since the dodge roll and jump action is the same button it's very easy to roll off a ledge instead of jumping over a gap.

As for the story, I found it to be mostly generic and not all that interesting. It's sort of just there for you to have a reason to do whatever you do in the game. The writing isn't terrible, just bland, and there is some voice acting as well. The music is serviceable, ranging from somewhat dull to pretty good.

It's certainly not the best game of its kind, but all things considered I'd say it's worth getting, at least during a sale.

112776669.review: Oceanhorn is a serviceable action-RPG game that takes many of its cues, for better or worse, from the Legend of Zelda Windwaker. If you've played Windwaker, then you've already seen entirely what this game has to offer. You'll sail around from island to island, completing dungeons, finding pieces of hearts, gaining new items, collecting the elements, and obtaining a stand-in Master Sword near the end. Beat by beat, this game follows Windwaker to a T, and if you're ok with that like me, then you will enjoy Oceanhorn. I hesitate to say cookie cutter because that does insinuate I dislike this game, which I certainly don't, however I don't absolutely love it either. It is serviceable and fun at its best, and repetitive at its worst where Zelda clearly does what this game does, but better. Whereas Blossom Tales: The Sleeping King was a a clear homage to A Link to the Past, it added enough variety and mechanics to justify itself as its own game and not just a Zelda clone. This game does not do that and is certainly a Zelda clone, but there is a reason the Zelda formula works so well and it is repeated here in its entirety. Just don't expect anything new or exciting during your playthrough.

108019018.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Una experiencia notable[/h1]

Desde que me lo pillé, allá por 2016, tres veces tuve que empezar este juego hasta que me lo he acabado, 5 años más tarde. Siempre lo empezaba con bastantes ganas porque sin duda me recordaba a Zelda, y su jugabilidad y su aspecto gráfico me resultaban muy atrayentes. Sin embargo, siempre pasaba algo que me hacía abandonarlo, generalmente que me ponía con otro juego y al final lo dejaba apartado.

Pero esta vez no fue así. Empecé a jugarlo y cada vez me entretenía más y más, hasta que él fue en esta ocasión el que hacía que dejara a otros títulos pendientes de lado, y no lo he soltado hasta que no me lo he acabado completamente. Y realmente lo he disfrutado mucho.  Esto no hace sino reformar mi teoría de que no solo basta con que un juego sea bueno, sino que también te tiene que coger en el momento oportuno para disfrutarlo realmente. Sea el juego que sea. 

Oceanhorn tiene una gran cantidad de virtudes, aunque no está exentos de algunos “defectos”. Lo entrecomillo porque realmente no lo considero defectos como tal, sino que al parecerse tanto a determinados Zelda, uno espera encontrar la misma experiencia jugable, y obviamente esto no es así. Sin duda, esto juega en su contra, pero no es tampoco algo por lo que haya que denostar al juego, ya que lo que hace lo hace bastante bien, aunque no llegue a los niveles de excelencia de la obra de Shigeru Miyamoto. Tampoco tuvieron los mismos medios, por cierto.

Sea como sea, Oceanhorn ofrece una aventura bastante entretenida donde nuestro personaje, espada en mano, y escudo, arco, bombas y magia también, visitará numerosas islas de una tierra que ha caído en desgracia y se enfrenta a un grave peligro.

El argumento como tal no es nada del otro mundo, y lo único que hace es presentarse, aparecer en algunas ocasiones y listo. Así que no es un juego que brille por su argumentación, pero sí lo hace por su exploración y, sobre todo, por su resolución de puzles. Realmente es una aventura bastante entretenida.

Generalmente, los puzles se encuentran diseminados por casi todas las islas, y serán del tipo de mover objetos, presionar palancas y cosas similares. No es que sean especialmente complejos, pero sí que exigirán que te comas el tarro en más de una ocasión para saber cómo abrir la maldita puerta que te impide seguir progresando en la aventura. Esto se vuelve mucho más exigente si quieres encontrar todos los cofres y completar todas las islas al 100%. Si vas simplemente a pasarte la historia sin más, la exigencia será mucho menor, aunque también menos gratificante.

El combate es tremendamente simple, aunque no por ello aburrido, y es muy parecido a lo que podemos ver en “A Link to the Past”, por ejemplo. Un botón para golpear con la espada, otro para cubrirte con el escudo, otro dedicado a las armas secundarias, como las bombas y el arco, y otro botón para ejecutar las magias.

Como ya pasaba en el juego de Zelda antes mencionado, en Oceanhorn nuestro personaje no puede saltar cuando queramos, sino que lo realizará cuando haya una distancia idónea para hacerlo y, además, cuando hayamos encontrado las botas que nos lo permitan. Esto podría parecer algo negativo, pero ni mucho menos, ya que este aspecto se enlaza directamente con la jugabilidad referida a los puzles. 

El juego tiene una manera muy particular de presentar el mundo donde se desarrolla la aventura, ya que el entorno parece estar construido con cubos. De este modo, las montañas estarán representadas por bloques cúbicos apilados unos encima de otros, creando diferentes alturas que nunca podremos escalar, pero si descender, y dependiendo de la altura de los cubos se podrá realizar la acción o no. Esto es importante, porque muchos puzles se podrán resolver al descubrir zonas que se interconectan entre ellas en base a la altura del entorno. En sí no es más que otro modo de presentar un puzle utilizando el entorno. Entorno que por otra parte es bastante bonito, bastante variado y diferente según la zona, así como los retos que nos presenta, pudiendo llegar a sorprendernos en algunos momentos.

Los enemigos también son variados, aunque no son tampoco demasiados, pero nunca se siente que se reciclen en exceso ni nada parecido. Además, dentro de determinadas mazmorras nos encontraremos con jefes finales bastante bien diseñados, aunque presentarán muy poco reto a los jugadores más experimentados.

En sí se siente toda la experiencia como algo muy agradable de disfrutar, pero es indudable que se nota que viene de la mano de un equipo indie muy reducido. Esto no es algo malo, ni mucho menos, porque lo conseguido es algo bastante notable, aunque en algunos momentos se pueda sentir algo casual.

Tampoco hay que olvidar que este juego es un port de móvil, pero no te equivoques con esto, el port está muy bien realizado y perfectamente adaptado para jugarse en PC, incluso a 4K, ya sea con teclado y ratón o con mando, aunque yo lo disfrute bastante más con mando.

En definitiva, tenemos un juego con grandes dosis de aventura y mazmorreo de 10-12 horas de duración, unas 16-17 si vas a por todo, lleno de puzles y acción muy entretenida, aunque no muy exigente, y todo ello representado con unos gráficos bastante bonitos y una música bastante notable. No es tan bueno como ningún Zelda, obviamente, pero sí es lo suficientemente bueno para ser disfrutado ya que ofrece una experiencia bastante notable.

100515220.review:
TL;DR - Rubbish port of a rubbish game. No idea what all the positive reviews are for, this is [i]not[/i] a good game. Don't buy.

To elaborate
You play as link- uhh, some random kid with a fetish for smashing pots and local flora, in a fairly standard A-RPG very much in the style of Zelda

First of all is the controls, they do not work at all on a m+kb setup, which is not justifiable if being on sale on the PC market. Multiple items bound to a single button, no cycle option, useless abilities not remappable. Nope, just, nope.

Graphics, well it resembles the same games its designed of and isn't bad. Nothing stands out whatsoever though, no bonus points here.

Combat is bland and uninteresting, plink away at enemies with your sword. Theres a few other [~]annoyances[~] variations like opponents that require specific spells to beat, or ranged enemies. A lot of enemies melee attacks outrange yours, and the timing of shielding is off (you have to shield [i]before[/i] their attack windup animation starts. No, that's not a typo). Boss battles are vague and terribly annoying.

The lots-of islands each with a theme is kind of nice (and I mean its pretty standard for a reason), but the minigame of sailing between them gets old, and slow movement + the backtracking (no fast travel, what is this the 80's?) felt like overkill. Minimap is poor as well.

Not to mention the terrible fishing minigame which feels like a rigged slot machine, and is slow to boot.

There are more things I could go into (enemies with infinite aggro range, respawning in aggro range, hugely restricted mana/stamina/item reserves, multiple abilities using same reserves, the list just goes on)

There is nothing here to make or a good game. Or even to redeem the bad points.
Save your time & money and do not buy.

[b] Title: A Captivating Indie Adventure - Oceanhorn: A Nostalgic Homage to Zelda [/b]

Introduction

Oceanhorn, an indie gem with an isometric perspective, presents a delightful homage to The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker. My time spent with it was a pleasantly surprising journey that left a significant impact.

Gameplay - Simple Yet Engaging

The simplicity of Oceanhorn's gameplay is one of its standout features. It offers a gentle learning curve, making it easy for players to pick up and enjoy. This accessibility doesn't mean the game lacks depth, though. In fact, it features one of the most engaging leveling systems I've ever encountered in a game.

Levelling System - A Standout Mechanic

Oceanhorn's leveling system is a true standout. It seamlessly blends character progression with the core gameplay, providing a sense of accomplishment as you grow stronger. This mechanic encourages exploration and tackling challenges, making each moment in the game feel rewarding.

Storytelling - A Surprisingly Engaging Tale

While not every action-adventure game excels in storytelling, Oceanhorn manages to impress. It weaves a narrative that, surprisingly, hits the emotional mark more than once. I found myself genuinely sentimental at key points in the story, a testament to the developers' ability to connect players with the game's world and characters.

A Journey Worth the Investment

As I navigated through Oceanhorn, I couldn't help but think that it was a worthwhile investment. The game offers a rich and captivating experience that easily justifies its price. It's clear that the developers poured their hearts into crafting this adventure, and it shows in every detail.

Anticipation for the Sequel

My experience with Oceanhorn has left me eagerly looking forward to trying the sequel on Steam. If the first game is any indication, the sequel promises to be an even grander adventure that fans of the action-adventure genre won't want to miss.

Conclusion

In conclusion, Oceanhorn is more than just an imitation of The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker. It stands as a remarkable indie game in its own right, offering accessible gameplay, a fantastic leveling system, a surprisingly engaging storyline, and a journey well worth the price of admission. For those seeking a nostalgic adventure reminiscent of classic titles, Oceanhorn is a true hidden treasure in the world of indie gaming.

96715260.review:
[h1] Oceanhorn - A rough yet charming Zelda clone [/h1] 

It is clear as day that Oceanhorn draws heavy inspiration from the Zelda franchise, from the overall gameplay design of A Link To The Past to the sailing between islands of Windwaker, it is not afraid to show where it got its ideas. Back when it released in 2013 it was the closest thing we had to Zelda on the PC, and I bought and played it a bit when it first released. Yet, recently I found myself wondering why I dropped it so quickly all those years ago, and so I decided to give it another go.

Having completed the game, I can now tell you what it was that steered me away from it the first time. Oceanhorn might look like Zelda, and it incorporates many ideas that have become series tradition, but it ultimately fails to capture the feel of a Zelda title. The main issues I found was a lack of polish and faulty level-design, or in this case the dungeons.

Zelda, and as a result Oceanhorn are equal parts combat, exploration and puzzle-solving. I had no issue with the puzzles, most of them are simple and while a few of the later ones border on cryptic there are usually clues to help you in the enviroment. My problem lies with the two former matters. Lets start with the combat.

Oceanhorn, like Zelda eventually gives the player lots of tools like bombs and arrows that can be used both to deal with enemies and to interact with the environment, but primarily combat is done with a sword and shield. The sword has a swift three swing combo and can also be charged to do a spin attack. The issue is that the attacks feel floaty and inaccurate. There is no real flow to the combo, and most enemies (and a few bosses) can be staggered to death by simply spamming the sword attack. There is also a stamina meter, similar to the one found in Skyward Sword and Breath of the Wild, but unlike BoTW there are no edibles to restore stamina here, and using the spin attack drains your stamina. The Stamina bar is also used for blocking and sprinting. Sprinting doesn't just up your movement speed; instead it locks your direction similar to the Sprinting Boots from ALTTP but unlike those boots which let you charge forward with your sword at the ready piercing enemies, here you sprint unarmed and it can therefor not be used offensively. Walking is very slow, so you may resort to sprinting but doing so prevents you from blocking enemy attacks for a rather long time while waiting for the stamina bar to refill. You do eventually get a roll, but it too drains a ton of stamina and while less awkward than sprinting still limits your options in terms of blocking and spin-attacking. I think having all these depend on the same limited resource was a very bad idea for the game, and although there is a secondary resource in the magic meter it is only used for casting spells, which also make you stop dead in your tracks. If I had to describe the gameplay in one word it would be clunky.

Next there's the exploration. While sailing from island to island is rather exciting, and there are quite a few treasures to find including pieces of heart, gold and Blood Orbs which must be collected to unlock the strongest spell in the game, the actual dungeons themselves often suffer from an over-reliance on destructible walls that are rarely hinted at or make sense in the grand scheme of the level design. I eventually found myself bombing almost every other wall I came across, and while there is no lack of bombs it does become very exhausting after a while. Bombs weren't just needed to find secrets either, oftentime you had to bomb multiple walls just to progress through the main dungeons, and unlike Zelda there weren't always a small crack to hint that the wall could be blown up. Nor can you attack the walls to hear a distinct sound effect from these walls. Finally, I found myself very disappointed with the Master Chests in this game. A staple of the Zelda series, Master Chests are known to hold new tools for you to use both in the dungeon their found in but also in your adventure as a whole. There are a few of these here, but quite often the Master Chest simply held money or some other resource instead of a new exciting item. Oh, and the last tool you find only has a single use in one specific scenario.

I feel I might have come across a bit too harsh on this game. It is not that I dislike it, I really wanted to like it a lot, but it unfortunately disappointed me in a lot of ways. Even so, it does have some good ideas of its own and some aspects were surprisingly well done, so I want to give credit where credit is due.

One of the tools you obtain on your journey in Oceanhorn is a fishing rod. Fishing is not something Zelda is known for, and it did give a bit more life to the world I must admit. Most islands had their own unique fish to be caught, and while the mini-game itself wasn't anything too special, it did break up the monotony and offer a unique spin on things.

Oceanhorn also has stellar audio design, the music especially caught my eye, or ears. The soundtrack is both whimsical and bold, inspiring and mysterious. It's not as catchy as the OSTs from Zelda games past, but it does its job very well and can be enjoyed separate from the game. If someone told me it was the score of some Zelda spinoff, I might've been inclined to believe them. The voice acting also deserves a mention. Voice acting is a hard thing to get right, and until BoTW the Zelda games had strayed away from it for the most part. Most indie games either don't dare to attempt it, or end up sounding more amateurish because of it, but in Oceanhorn it is one of the main draws. Not all the dialogue is voiced, the vast majority isn't, in fact I believe only the cutscenes were voiced, but it is still a very bold thing to attempt for an indie game like this, and I must say I was surprised by how well the performances were delivered.

Oceanhorn is a love letter to the Zelda franchise, and there is a lot of heart in this game. I really wish I could recommend it, because it is obvious how much passion went into this project, but unfortunately it is held back by a lack of experience and some poor ideas. Nevertheless I commend the developers for their work, and if Oceanhorn 2 ever comes to Steam I'll be sure to give it a go! I am sure the devs have learned a lot since making this, and I'm interested to see where they'll be going from now!

94305445.review:
This is a 2013 mobile game rereleased onto Steam as of 2015. This is an old game, and it can feel old and clunky due to how it was originally built/developed as a mobile game. It's not perfect, and I want to say that up front.

HOWEVER! If you are ok with dealing with some mobile-esque graphical settings and a pretty easy game overall, and also are looking for something that can help scratch that Legend of Zelda: Windwaker itch some of us may have, then this game is easily worth picking up. 

[b][h1]STORY[/h1][/b]
The story is... ok... but so are most Zelda stories (let's be serious here...). Although this game's story doesn't come close the the best of the genre, it's passable and has some mystery to delve into with some of the in-game lore. Honestly, I'm surprised a mobile game put this much effort into fleshing out it's rather sparse world.  The tale as old as time now gets repeated in a less than unique way, but it is still put together in a decently engaging undercurrent of family and desire to save the world. Groundbreaking? Hardly. Perfectly passable? You bet!

[b][h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1][/b]
Pretty standard fare for what was originally a single button/touch interface. It maps surprisingly well to controller (played on Xbox 1 pc wired controller), and honestly even die hard M+KB users will find that although it may take some getting used to, the controls translate pretty dang well.  You'll be hacking and slashing your way through various environments and enemies, all with a steady upgrade in power with various items. Stop me if you've heard this before, "a fire, earth, and ancient technology temple all with their own unique items to find". LoZ to a T. But again, it works, has some interesting (all be it simple) ideas, and is fun enough to brush the samey-ness aside for the most part.  Have fun killing chu-chu look-alikes and bombing walls.

[b][h1]OVERALL[/h1][/b]
I 100% the game with little help (other than fishing... ugh) in about 13 hours. Totally worth the asking price if you ask me. I had fun, the game has some charming heart to it, and it definitely scratched an itch that Nintendo awakened within me all those year ago, if for only a week or so. Pick it up if you're interested in a fun/compact little Zelda-like game. And hey, they release Oceanhorn 2 on Nintendo Switch, so maybe one day we'll see that on steam as well.

I truly don't understand the volume of positive reviews for this game…
---

At a glance there's glimmers of Zelda games, notably Windwaker; which would be fine but it's just so poorly executed. This feels like a very bad port of a mobile game. I expect stodgy controls and a flaky camera if you are attempting to play a game like this on a phone, I don't expect those same limitations in a PC version. I don't feel like I'm walking, I feel like I'm being dragged around by the collar of my shirt, and the camera is downright claustrophobic even in places that should be open with a wide view, it just isn't.

If you can stomach the stilted interface and jerky movement without getting nauseas the game itself is just really routine. Walk around a tiny island, collect some coins, solve a baby-tier puzzle, rinse and repeat. There's no real depth, what challenge exists comes off as just random and the minigames like fishing (which are typically relaxing in this type of game) are intentionally frustrating with gimmicks that punish you for even trying (ghost fish that inverts your controls, electric fish that zaps you, etc.)

The story didn't draw me in, the voice acting felt like reading from a book and did I mention how much I hate how the controls feel? Because that's worth repeating. Even forcing your way through this for the achievements feels more like work than fun.
---

Bottom line: A bargain bin Zelda clone that was probably more at home on a last gen cell phone.
---

92677151.review:
On the surface this game is a knockoff windwaker for pc. The controls are a bit iffy on keyboard and mouse, the gameplay is simplistic but it's still fairly enjoyable.

That is unless you're a completionist. Then this game is your fucking worst nightmare. All the regular stuff in the game is fine, the final boss is actually a joke and you can defeat it sub 2 minutes. But then there are the fishing achievements tied to a god awful fishing minigame. 

This minigame is an abomination. There is rng on getting the fish you want, you can't see which fish you're catching until you've actually caught it. This is just a lot of trial and error. It's bad, but it gets worse. There is a ghost fish that inverts your controls while you're trying to catch it, and it's competely rng in the first place whether you'll actually hook it. In the ONLY area where you can get it, you can also catch other kinds of fish. It took me almost 30 minutes or constant retrying just to see the ghost fish the first time, at which point you're completely unprepared and it promptly escapes after 2 seconds. The second time when you're prepared for it it's just a tedious endurance round. You have to keep moving the rod along with the fish which is actually in the opposite direction because it inverts your controls for about 10 minutes. (look up youtube videos on the ghost fish) before it fully loses its strength. It's not fun, if you make a single mistake it'll escape and you can rng fish again hoping to get it before the endurance round begins again.

Then there's the botfish. A fish that electrocutes you every 2 seconds while trying to catch it. You lose half a heart each time it does it and you can't control the rod for a second either. So if it's anywhere near the edge of the screen it'll escape. But you can't keep it in the middle to prevent that because then you'll long lose all your health before it ever tires out. So you just have to keep retrying until you get god-like rng and get the dumbest fish possible that for some reason just pulls either left or right the entire minigame so you can sap its strength before you lose all of your health. And this is on a max health character. Good luck doing this if you're not a completionist because if you don't have 8 or 9 hearts you will die long before the fish is even halfway tired. 

It's fucking rng on top of rng and it destroys any positive feelings I might've had for this game. On top of that the developer is greedy and made the second game an exclusive. Don't give them any money, the fishing minigame makes this a no-go even on a sale where it'd cost less than €1.

90070533.review:
It's alright. Parts of it were enjoyable, but it's certainly nothing special.
Perhaps worth picking up if you really like the genre, and can get it heavily discounted. 

Cons
- Movement and fighting feels a little clunky.
- The "puzzles" are all pretty basic and never get more advanced.
- There are few dungeons, and they are all simple and unmemorable.
- Enemy AI (using that term feels like a stretch) is severely lacking/nonexistent.
- It presents no real challenges what so ever, even bosses (the hardest thing by far was catching a botfish).
- I found the story to be quite generic, and uninspiring
- The dialog is down right atrocious (or perhaps just poorly translated?)
- The length. It is short. As a mobile game it's fine. But on Steam it just doesn't feel like a full game. To illustrate this, in Ocarina of Time you collect the three spiritual stones (as you do in this), but then you go on to get the 6 sage medallions in full length dungeons. In this however, you collect the first 3, and then it's on to the final boss. 
It feels like they attempted to increase the length by requiring a lot of backtracking and relying on collectables.

Pros
- Soundtrack, a number of songs are quite good (however many of those seem dangerously close to the Zelda track that clearly inspired them)
- Many of the islands were pretty unique and can be fun to explore.
- I'm not sure how it plays on a touch device (control wise) but everything about it seems more appropriate as a mobile game.

What it does best, is remind you just how good Zelda really is. 
It honestly felt like a group of students trying to make a Zelda clone for their final project in a game development course. And if that was the case, they did really well! Solid B/B+! 
But as a real game hoping to survive in the video game market...I think it falls short in every single aspect.


When it first came out, friends and I watched the trailer and questioned why Nintendo would let them make this?
My initial thought was that they probably changed just enough that it's legally distinct.
But after playing it, it's pretty clear that they have no reason to worry about this game. Even writing an internal email about it wouldn't be worth Nintendo's time.

The game was good, until I got to the ending. There isn't really anything wrong with the gameplay or story until you get to the final boss. Its just upsetting that the conclusion doesn't really make sense.

----------------- End Game Spoilers ----------------------------

Basically the whole point of the story is that you beat the Oceanhorn, and to do that you need a sword that can cut it, a shield that can block it's lasers, and all 3 artifacts. The issue is that based on how the game ends you don't need any of these items technically. If you could go straight to the final island you could beat it with the stick you start with.

1. The sword and shield are pretty useless
The sword is the only thing that can actually cut the Oceanhorn, but you never need to cut the Oceanhorn or really attack it. The shield is use to deflect lasers you can out run fairly easily. If you have a bow or bombs, you can just throw it at the weak point to beat the 1st phase of the boss.

2. The artifacts are useless
They actually don't do anything.

3. The final boss fight is really bad.
The way to beat the boss is to electrocute by hitting the pillars which could have been hit with a stick and then playing your father's flute that you pick up. 

If you never got the sword and shield the first phase would be difficult but still pretty easy since you can out run all the damage. If you never got the artifacts then the 2 fish people would be frozen; 3 bird people could live on any other island; the 10 sky people would still live in the sky or just jump off because thats what the main character's mom did. 

So I guess you help 15 people and fix some small environment issues with the world and get a pet called Oceanhorn.

88023440.review:
[h1] TL;DR at the Bottom (Too Long; didn't read) [/h1]

Originally released on mobile platforms, Oceanhorn is a title that has been on my radar for a while now. That's because it's impossible to not get the feeling that this is a game majorly inspired by The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker, which is one of my favorite games on one of my favorite franchises. After spending ten hours to complete the game, I came out impressed, even if, as expected, originality isn't really something that's all that present here.

Truth be told, Oceanhorn is less Wind Waker and more Phantom Hourglass, the direct sequel to the former game that was released on the Nintendo DS. Like the latter, it's played from an angled top-down perspective, and the navigation through the open seas isn't directly controlled, but pre-determined, with a few shooting targets here and there to keep you busy while it happens. Luckily, the controls don't really mirror Phantom Hourglass (or even Oceanhorn's own original mobile version), meaning the game has complete support for physical button inputs.

The story is simple, but it does have some nice moments. Your character wakes up to find a note from his father, explaining he's gone away to fight Oceanhorn, a mythical monster who terrorizes the seas. From there, it's up to you to go after him, exploring the ocean and a good number of island scattered through it.

Like expected, the game play as a top-down Zelda-type game, meaning you'll come across quests, different races, and, of course, dungeons. Also like Zelda, each dungeon provides you with a new weapon, allowing you to reach previously unreachable areas. The overall game design is fair and the gameplay itself is very fun, but it has to be said that the puzzles are more simplistic and far less imaginative that the ones in Nintendo's franchise.

The one exception for this is the Island of Whispers, which is a late-game discovery that was by far my favorite part of Oceanhorn. The island was originally a post-launch downloadable content, and it shows, as the quality of game design goes dramatically up. Not only that, the island offers a parallel, self-contained story about a mysterious kid whose ambition led to the end of the local civilization. Figuring out what exactly happened, piece by piece, was an extremely engrossing experience, and the closest the game got to Zelda levels of excellence.

As far as production values go, I have to say the game far exceeded my expectations. The stylized graphics are crisp, colorful, and very pretty. Even more impressive is the soundtrack, which is nothing short of phenomenal, and is complemented in the audio department by excellent voice acting.

[h1] TL;DR: [/h1]
There's no two ways about it: Oceanhorn is a Zelda clone, lacking originality to stand as its own thing. Luckily, it features a nice campaign and a surprisingly interesting story, even if the overall game design is a bit more basic that I would have hoped. Each of the game's explorable islands are self-contained isometric playgrounds that are a lot of fun to pick apart, and it all looks great (and sounds even better). For someone looking for a Zelda-lite experience, you really can't go wrong here.

[h1]Review[/h1]
It’s hard to believe that Oceanhorn is a port of a standalone mobile game, given its impressive soundtrack and fun gameplay. Unfortunately though, I am reviewing the ported variant of this game which leaves me with a few annoyances that were more understandable for the original release due to limitations. There are a lot of gameplay mechanics that are mostly “harmless but not spectacular”. Sailing doesn’t have a lot going for it due to its simplicity, but also doesn’t do much wrong. Combat isn’t my favourite and puzzles are okay at best, but they work. Vertical traversing is the bane of my existence, but the game is built around this limitation. But despite my annoyances, I can’t understate how much fun I had with exploring the game and all the islands that popped up, including the dungeons and the many challenges that came with them for a levelling system. The mechanics may not stand out, but they did still work in providing me with a fun journey.

Kind of a Zelda clone. Well, it reminds me a bit of the Zelda series because the main character looks a bit like him, and the game play is quite primitive. Your overall goal is to recover some sort of emblems to restore something to somewhere. Story is the usual fantasy drivel, but the game is a fun slash and explore. It doesn't have a perk system or stat system, so when you level up the game just increases your hit points. You do collect coins which can be used at shops to buy such helpful things as health refills and bombs. Though it isn't open world, there are several different islands that open up once you get off the tutorial island, which should be renamed Tedious Island because of how boring it is. Though the islands don't have to be visited in any particular sequence, certain islands can not be opened up without getting something from some other island. I do wish the islands were easier to transverse. To get anywhere you have to weave your way through a series of ladders and bridges. A bit tedious and frustrating at times.



conclusion

simple slash and explore. Zero customization and cliched story doesn't subtract from the simple primitive fun. Get it cheap.

78986150.review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is an action adventure game developed by Cornfox & Bros.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

In Oceanhorn, you control a little boy who wakes up alone in his tent at the start of the game and finds a letter from his missing father. He went headlong to find a creature called the Oceanhorn. Your task is now to hurry after your dad and find out what the fabled monster is all about. The exciting story is picking up speed quickly and is told partly in pretty video sequences, partly in the form of your father's diary entries. 

Some dialogues were even set to music, but only in English with German subtitles, whereby the speakers sometimes sound a bit bored. In the course of the adventure you will make 14 different locations unsafe, each with their own dungeons, which are peppered with all kinds of monsters and nuts. 

For example, you balance over wooden planks and operate lever mechanisms, bludgeon rows of rats, goblins and fantasy figures and puzzle your way through sometimes more, sometimes less challenging puzzles in order to finally crack the coveted treasure chest that awaits inside every dungeon - and not infrequently from one nasty boss monster is guarded. It's best to get an idea of ​​it yourself.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ fascinating lively game world
+ colorful art design
+ great cutscenes
+ good mix of puzzles, exploring and fighting
+ Characters with a lot of charm
+ fair storage system
+ find several spells and weapons
+ many hidden secrets
+ Achievements and Trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- Mission objectives are not always clear
- Partly chunky objects and washed out textures
- hardly any secondary occupations
- sometimes much too easy

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a visually and playfully high-quality Zelda clone with a lot of charm, which is definitely worth a sailing trip.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas ist ein Action-Adventure, welches von Cornfox & Bros. entwickelt wurde.

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

In Oceanhorn steuerst du einen kleinen Jungen, der zu Spielbeginn allein in seinem Zelt aufwacht und einen Brief seines verschwundenen Vaters vorfindet. Der ist Hals über Kopf aufgebrochen, um eine Kreatur namens Oceanhorn zu finden. Eure Aufgabe ist es nun, eurem Paps nachzueilen und herauszufinden, was es mit dem sagenumwobenen Monster auf sich hat. Die spannende Geschichte nimmt schnell Fahrt auf und wird teils in hübschen Videosequenzen, teils in Form von Tagebucheinträgen eures Vaters erzählt. 

Einige Dialoge wurden sogar vertont, allerdings ausschließlich auf Englisch mit deutschen Untertiteln, wobei die Sprecher manchmal etwas gelangweilt klingen.Im Laufe des Abenteuers macht ihr 14 unterschiedliche Schauplätze nebst jeweils eigenen Dungeons unsicher, die mit allerhand Monstern und Kopfnüssen gespickt sind. 

So balanciert ihr etwa über Holzbretter und betätigt Hebelmechanismen, knüppelt reihenweise Ratten, Kobolde und Fantasiegestalten nieder und knobelt euch durch mal mehr, mal weniger anspruchsvolle Rätsel, um schließlich die begehrte Schatztruhe zu knacken, die im Inneren jedes Dungeons wartet - und nicht selten von einem fiesen Bossmonster bewacht wird. Macht euch am besten selbst ein Bild davon.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ faszinierend lebendige Spielwelt
+ farbenfrohes Artdesign
+ tolle Zwischensequenzen
+ gute Mischung aus Rätseln, Erkunden und Kämpfen
+ Charaktere mit viel Charme
+ faires Speichersystem
+ etliche Zauber und Waffen zu finden
+ viele versteckte Geheimnisse
+ Errungenschaften und Trading Cards

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- Missionsziele sind nicht immer klar
- teils klobige Objekte und verwaschene Texturen
- kaum Nebenbeschäftigungen
- teils viel zu einfach

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas ist ein optisch und spielerisch hochwertiger Zelda-Klon mit viel Charme, der in jedem Fall eine Segelreise wert ist.

67894584.review:
After about 10 hours i almost finished Oceanhorn - Monster of Uncharted Seas and i kinda had a bit of fun playing it so far. The graphics are nice, music is good too and the flow just works. The balancing between combat and puzzles works fine too.

But this game has one big flaw for me i cannot ignore: It's a Zelda clone, which is more than obvious (and i can live with that ... in fact that's why i bought it), but it doesn't have the charme of the original at all. The characters, quests and the story are quite boring, the islands in the game look nice and most levels are well designed from the perspetive of pure game mechanics, but they don't feel alive, they don't have character and there is barely any interesting lore at all. And the enemy types, even the bosses are just random. Some trolls, mushroom creatures, beetles, birds. Not really bad, but there is nothing unique, nothing that stands out. From the technical perspective Oceanhorn is a nice little indie game, but imho it lacks soul. It's just a 3d clone of some older Zelda games that fails to capture the spirit of the original.

Oceanhorn - Monster of Uncharted Seas not a bad game, but it's not really a good one either. I still give it a thumb up because it kept me busy without frustating me too much and there is no option to to choose something between thumb up and thumb down (it's still not bad enough for a bad rating), but while many other games touch something inside my gamer heart ... this unfortunately didn't manage to do that.

And a little update after i've finished the game after about 13 hours: I'll stay with my opinion. Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a nice Zelda clone that works good mechanically, has some nice dungeons and puzzles, looks good and has nice music ... but not a lot of spirit. It was fun, especially the first 4 or 5 hours, but it could have been a lot better with a more interesting story, characters and world design. Not a bad game, but also not really a very good one.

62058325.review:
First off; you start the game as an orphan boy who finds his father's sword and shield. He is then promptly tasked with finding the three relics of power, which when combined... Yeah; we're not doing anything to hide the fact that this is a zelda clone. Like a mix between LttP and windwaker.
But it is a good clone. The story is good. The aesthetics are great. Music is wonderful. Combat is tight. The puzzles are (mostly) intuitive, and not too difficult. So head out, pick up your bombs and your bow, defeat the dungeon bosses weak to the item you just picked up, and just enjoy the game.
I played it for roughly nine hours without being bored or having to consult a guide. Had another four hours of less fun revisiting old locations to pick up all challenges and achievements. Never got to the point that I relied on checklists or walkthroughs to find anything.

There are some nitpicks, however. None of them make the game unenjoyable, but they are noticeable.
First, and perhaps biggest, is that there aren't any collectable upgrades worth backtracking for. You gain powerups which unlock different areas with new collectibles and powerups, but the collectibles don't do anything until you get 100%, and the heart containers aren't as useful as you'd think. The big and useful upgrades are all tied to the plot, so instead of going the metroidvania route of revisiting every land when you get a new ability to pick up bling, there's no reason not to wait until you've gained all abilities and the game kindly reminds you it's time to stock up before beating the snot out of the final boss.
Also; whoever in development decided that "precision jump to the next platform" and "throw caution to the wind and combat roll wildly around" should be bound to the same button deserves to live the rest of their life in a world where hotsauce and toothpaste randomly swap flavors.

Overall though, it's an enjoyable game. Some nitpicks, but also some "wow" moments.

60716884.review:
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a good game and a good port of a mobile game. So it’s now time for the story.

Long ago the kingdom of Arcadia was a magnificent place, a place where magic and science gave way to a beautiful future not just for Arcadia, but its neighbors.

But a great catastrophe happened caused by the dark lord Mesmeroth and his army and in the wake of the war, three terrifying monsters came to be.

But that was hundreds of years ago and only one of these terrifying monsters still live, the monster known only as Oceanhorn. And it is that monster that will soon make a young kid try to become a hero.

Now it’s that time to talk about what’s to like about the game. To start the story is good and has some cool moments and interesting ideas, like with the villain Mesmeroth. The art/Graphics style is good with some good detail and some interesting places to see and explore. 

The combat is good and simple with a sword and shield but all so bombs and arrows as well as some magic to use. 
The bosses are very good and great looking; my two favs are Mesmeroth and Oceanhorn even those that boss is a pain to fight. The music is good, and the voice acting was okay too did not feel very wooden.

And the two best things in the game was one: When you stop on a certain island the main character’s dad would talk about the place. And Two: was whispering island were we got to find out more about the villain Mesmeroth.

Now it’s that time to talk about what’s to dislike about the game. Well there are only four bosses in the game and one optional Boss, there are sub bosses but the game could have used some more main bosses.

There is all so no exploring with your boat, you see when you go to an island your boat takes you there, you don’t get to sail around and find places on your own.

And while the combat is good and simple; there could have been more done with it, like with the weapons and magic like homing bombs and fire arrows.

And the magic is not really needed in combat except to take out this one type of enemy and the battle with Oceanhorn.

So that said, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a good game and a good port of a mobile game. With a good art/Graphics style, good music and okay voice acting.

Now if you’re looking for a legend of Zelda wind waker like game, this maybe the game for you.

58945996.review:
Though a decent enough game, Oceanhorn is a far cry from the Zelda games which it is supposedly based on in terms of gameplay design and inspired by. It's almost as if the developers failed to understand just what makes the Zelda games fun, what makes players want to dive into their worlds and explore.

 For starters Oceanhorn's combat is dull, animations are slow and clearly the animators lacked any sense of timing, combat is not impactful at all making it a very unsatisfying experience. Even if we decide to ignore this game's inspiration, the Zelda series and its nicely designed and satisfying combat, Oceanhorn on its own sports some exceptionally dull, slow, completely devoid of any kind of satisfaction or trhill battles. Everything feels like it lacks substance, and combat feels unfinished and like an afterthought to a walking simulator with some puzzle elements almost.

Speaking of puzzles, the majority of them are functional enough but not overly exciting or interesting, some are just plain unintuitive and tedious for the sake of prolonging the game rather than offering the player a  satisfying puzzle solving experience. Though truth be told, this can sometimes be the case with some of the Zelda games as well, (Twilight Princess in particular IMO. I find it fairly frustrating in Oceanhorn because the game has little else to offer in compensation.

We have rather unimpressive puzzles and dull combat so far, terribly hidden secrets that often require blind placement of bombs and sheer luck to discover unlike the Zelda games. To make things worse the main character moves at a snail's pace though running is an option it doesn't add much to the overall pacing of the games and environmental traversal. The environments themselves are your typical puzzle/adventure environments in terms of design and fairly generic when it comes to their looks, while the game looks decent at first glance the completely soulless character designs, unimaginative monsters and downright boring environments quickly overwhelm anyone who has played any decent fantasy games with more artistic creativity behind them.
It's a shame that so much muscal talent went into this product when everything else is just sub par and simply functional enough to offer some enjoyment but ultimately fall short of an even average fun gaming experience in the genre.

Though I did enjoy my time with the game, it was mostly out of curiosity to see how the developers would handle the Zelda formula throughout, I love easy games but Oceanhorn's problem isn't the lack of challenge or difficulty, it's the lack of creativity and imagination on the developers' end.
Sure it has a fairly decent premise, nothing we haven't seen before but not all games of this genre need a strong story to support them, so by no means do I fault Oceanhorn for having a generic story, but I do fault it for failing to build an interesting world and interesting environments populated by all manner of characters and monsters that invite the player to explore.

If I had to rate the game I'd give it a 5.0/10

This game is very reminiscent of Wind Waker. To the point that I would call it a "barely apologetic clone." Does this make it bad? Of course not, I adored WW and seeing so much Zelda inspiration in an indie title is, while not exactly new, familiar and fun. The puzzles, what with me being used to modern/GC Zelda being almost Portal-like in critical thinking exercises and ingenuity, are laughably easy so far, mostly consisting of "find this out of the way button and press it" and "push these boxes to proceed." 

It is a game based from mobile, so I can't expect too terribly much from a startup company that's getting its feet wet in the PC scene, and so far, my lowered expectations have been satisfied.

One tiny problem, though: I'm not sure what causes it, but every so often, my game picture freezes and while the sound indicates it's still functioning, I can't do anything, and when I minimize and open it back up, it crashes. This has happened about a half-dozen times, now, and is very annoying, as it has cost me precious minutes of gameplay and progress. 

I may attempt lowering my graphics settings.

54032472.review:
This is a keeper. I was never a fan of Zelda series, but this game stole my heart. Really good game which you can easily play both with gamepad or keyboard+mouse. Story is interesting and nonlinear so you can take your time to explore the environment and visit in different islands to collect some extras. Extras are not just for achievements, but you also gather experience which will raise your level and upgrade your skills. Unfortunately you cannot choose your skills, but still they are most vital in order to survive when game proceeds.

There is a lot of different monsters and fighting happens in a real time. Fighting the easiest of monsters isn't that complicated, but when meeting some stronger opponents or bosses you must plan your approach more carefully. There is a few main bosses altogether in the game and everyone acts with some pattern you must solve and try to find their weak spot. You naturally gather some experience by killing enemies, but it usually also rewards you with money and health. With money you can visit shops and swiftly resupply your hitpoints or current tools which include items like arrows and bombs. Most of the things are not available in the beginning of the game. You can also collect these things by killing enemies, thus the shops do not need frequent visiting. They do sell a couple of special items which are quite necessary so money is not totally vain.

The hero have his hitpoints and mana which you can use to cast spells which are not only effective way to deal some heavy long range damage but also work as a key on some puzzles and can also reveal some new paths. For example the fire spell melts all the ice. Already in the beginning there is a lot of places where you can't get, but when you proceed in the game you will be provided with all the equipment and magic you need to get in the trickiest of places. Some things require also some puzzle solving and attentiveness.

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas isn't the most difficult of games and if you die you spawn from the beginning of the same area which aren't too huge and only penalty which you will have is a loss of an experience point or two and if you are lucky you may have time to collect them from the ground before they disappear. Only real challenge lie in bosses and some of them can take few trials and errors before you are victorious.

This game is like a warm breath of midsummer having sympathetic graphics and sweet soundtrack and a good amount of gameplay which can easily spread few hours longer if you want to collect and explore everything.

Oceanhorn trata, claramente, ser un zelda para pc, y hasta que no ves los creditos puedes decir que es un intento mediocre, pero este juego esta hecho por un equipo muy pequeño, creo que habian mas actores de voz que programadores, y tambien tenemos que recordar que trata de acercarse a un Zelda.
El combate es como en zelda, (incluyendo el ataque giratorio) pero sin poder fijar a los enemigos (dificulta el uso del arco) y la esquiva es un item (uno muy tardio y que gasta stamina). Personalmente batalle algunas vecez con las bombas y es que colocarlas es complicado, a vecez las lanza a vecez las deja frente de ti, pero aparte de eso es un sistema bastante comodo.
Las mazmorras estan combinadas con las islas en su totalidad, y crean unos laberitos muy buenos, que para mi es lo mejor del juego. Tiene algunos jefes que no son genialidades, pero estan bien (excepto una batalla que es muy muy similar a la de ganondorf de tloz oot y el jefe final en su primera forma, lanza bombas de una manera un poco injusta a mi parecer).

49270004.review:
I'm honestly baffled by how highly rated this is. I can see how it would be decent enough on a mobile, with the small selection of good action games available, but on the PC?

Starting with the good points:
- The general art style is nice, with a bright cartoony look that's straight out of Wind Waker (a little too straight out at points, but anyway) and high resolution textures. Gillfolk's Drop in particular looks quite pretty with the rain effects.
- The music is also good - I wouldn't buy the soundtrack, but it was certainly very listenable and although some tracks were repeated here and there, overall the tracks matched well with the location/usage.
- The game saves very frequently, which is a positive if you only have short gaming sessions.

Neutral or subjective points:
- The controls were overall fairly decent - I played both with controller and keyboard/mouse, and I didn't experience any problems. Items were sometimes finicky (particularly the Trencher Boots roll/jump detection and bomb throwing), but not to the point that I'd consider it a real negative.
- I personally disliked the voice acting and thought it was at best average, at worst eyeroll-worthy, but I will admit I have very high standards in this regard and would rather have no VA than even average VA. So this may not be a negative point for others.
- The isometric viewpoint is nice in theory and for perhaps the first half an hour of playing, but the joke of a camera makes it very annoying to see where you need to go and the game is inconsistent about attacking and moving between higher and lower levels.

And negative points:
- At best, the level design is bland. The game is short (roughly 8-10 hours for the main story, longer for 100%) so it's not as obvious as it would be in a longer game, but the island areas and dungeons both were unexciting and predictable.
- The puzzles were insulting. "Push a box onto a clearly marked button" is not a puzzle, "push a box around a corner onto a clearly marked button" is not a puzzle, and "blow up a crate and then push a box onto a clearly marked button" is not a puzzle. And yet they never get any better than this, all the way up to the final dungeon. Honestly, I would have preferred no puzzles to what we got in the game - it was aggravating and annoying having to waste time on the same petty nonsense over and over again. "Exciting gameplay" this was not.
- Connected with this, the entire game was laughably easy. I'm not asking for every game to be Dark Souls-hard - I'd be pretty annoyed if they were - but I feel like I'm not expecting too much to want some level of challenge. The bosses in particular were a pushover, up to and including the final boss. Hell, I died more times to the botfish than I did any of the bosses.
- The game is extremely linear despite this supposedly being (and drawing so heavily from a series known for being) an exploration game. Even when the game unlocks multiple islands at a time, they can only be traversed in a set order, and the "extra" islands have literally nothing except a pair of collectables each. The worst of these is the world map, where you sail around on set routes and can do nothing except shoot the occasional crate and octorock-clone. 

I'm gonna put story & character into their own separate point, because this was a big one for me: whoever wrote "captivating storytelling" on the Steam store page should be ashamed of themself, because that is a massive flat-out lie. There is nothing captivating about Oceanhorn's story. There is nothing I would even call good about Oceanhorn's story. There are a few elements that could, potentially, be interesting - how do the living fortresses function? What is the connection between technology and magic hinted at on the Island of Whispers? - but they're drowned beneath a sea of yawn-inducing banality. None of Oceanhorn's characters have any real personality or depth to speak of and the unnamed hero is about as blank slate as it gets.

The story is almost laughably minimal. Here, I can sum it up (spoilers, I guess): The hero finds out that his dad is missing because he's gone to fight a monster called Oceanhorn. There's a dark magic user called Mesmeroth controlling it who has corrupted the three Emblems of the Gods, so the hero has to reclaim the emblems, use their power to reveal the ruins of an ancient kingdom, and fight both Mesmeroth and Oceanhorn. That's it. That's the entire story. 

Of course, it can't be content with being bland, it has to also be cliched. The hero's mother is dead. She had a special necklace that the hero wears to remember her. His father (and therefore him) are of a special, noble, ancient bloodline. The villain is evil just because. There's a girl that wants to go exploring but can't because [reason not found] and immediately has an emotional connection with the hero despite speaking with him once. Ancient kingdom that was brought low by their own hubris. Hero's mother sacrifices herself for some reason. Owl people that are known for being wise. Fish people that hate the humans for polluting the water. It just goes on and on and on.

Oceanhorn expects you to be emotionally invested in characters that it barely introduces and in a world that it barely explains. What little it does have is things everyone's seen a thousand times before.

Overall, I would rate Oceanhorn a 4/10. It's definitely playable, it looks and sounds nice, and if you're absolutely desperate for a Zelda-like game, this might scratch that itch. But it's bland, overly easy, and the story is terrible. If you can pick it for a dollar or two, then maybe look at it, but otherwise don't bother. Your time's better spent elsewhere.

On top of that to change island you have to travel on the worlds shittest boat journey without the epic Zelda sea music. 44233864.review:
I heard about Oceanhorn 2 and thought it looked pretty cool, so I figured I'd try out the first game to see where the series was coming from. This first Oceanhorn game sure is a rough beginning, but overall it's a remarkably solid effort for such a small game, and does a good job at creating an experience with the limited resources available to the team. I thought the world design was mostly pretty good, the character and monster art was reasonably charming, and the game has a nice balance between combat and puzzles, without either being too difficult most of the time.

That said, a few things rubbed me the wrong way. The first is that the movement controls are quite bad, but in a very specific way. You feel like your character is walking through molasses; turning, or going up or down ramps, seems to slow your character down in a way that feels terrible; but moving in a straight line, once you get going, feels fine. It's weird, and makes for some awkward moments in some of the timing-sensitive puzzles or boss fights where I wanted to yell at the screen for how sluggish the character was responding to the controls.

The final boss fight also seems to have severe bugs in it - there's a laser-reflection mechanic that's introduced earlier in the game and is used here as well, but it seems broken half the time. Sometimes your reflection ability doesn't actually reflect and you get lasered anyway; other times the laser itself reflects into the ground or gets caught on the boss' geometry instead of responding the way it does in past laser puzzles. Combine this with the sluggish movement and it becomes a very frustrating fight.

The story is also really basic and uninspired, feeling for the most part like a collection of recycled stories from the very simplest quest stories imaginable. I'm not really sure why this is - good writing is hard, sure, but ideas are cheap, and there don't even seem to be any really interesting ideas here. Some old wizard crossed a line, magical items must be collected, you're the heir of a special bloodline, etc. It was well-presented as far as simple little adventure games go, but I'm left hoping the sequel actually tries to have more interesting narrative ideas.

But still - it's a cute game with fairly fun gameplay for the most part, it's not too long, and given what such a relatively small team was able to squeeze out of a simple concept and simple parts, I'm still quite curious to see what they do with Oceanhorn 2.

41453470.review:
Played this game expecting something like Link to the Past, maybe that was my fault.
It's a top-down game with a sword, but this is not Link to the Past. It has a much larger focus on exploring islands, which if you know me, I care more about combat, movement, and good dungeons and bosses. This game has none of those, and really lacks polish.
If you like exploring, you might like this game. But it's not BotW-style exploring. Every island just feels like a shallow dungeon, with a dungeon in it (which aren't that great either). And know that the boating is sort of on-rails and mandatory every time. It's not free-roam boating, they just set the path for you from what island you're on, to which one you want to head to, and just sort of becomes a rail shooter from there. And you got to do this everytime which becomes tedious since it's not exactly fun or exciting. If it was once the first time you go somewhere, it'd be fine. but no, it's everytime.

For Link to the Past specific fans, I would more so recommend Adventure Time Secret of the Nameless Kingdom. Outside of random crashes, that's the only game I've personally played that done the genre/format right. Ittle Dew wasn't bad, but way too easy and simplistic.

41403613.review:
What a great game.  If you like the Legend of Zelda, you will most likely enjoy this game.  The story is quite simple but enjoyable.  The gameplay is very fun and familiar.  It is a standard sword and shield game with items such as arrows, bombs, and boots that let you jump.  Unlike the Legend of Zelda, secrets that can be opened with bombs are not discolored so they can be a little hard to find, but they are usually worth it and result in finding a new piece of a heart container.

The one complaint that I have with this game is the fishing mini-game.  Truth be told you can go through the entire game without even once going fishing, but if you do, it is fairly frustrating.  While I would highly recommend using a controller for the entire game, for fishing, I would say use the left and right arrow keys, it will make life so much easier.  I would absolutely recommend this game to any who enjoy adventure games and who enjoy Zelda games, you won't be disappointed.

40811375.review:
This one really surprised me in how good it is. Maybe not worth $15, but still worth playing.

It doesn't hold your hand as much as it should in the begining. But, stick with it and you learn by doing.

The puzzles aren't taxing, nor is the combat, but that doesn't make it less enjoyable, somehow.

-----
EDIT:
Now that I have played the game up to near complete, I can say that this game surprised me with how good it is. The player and some of the other art assets are less than perfect, but look past that and there is a great game here! There is a limit on what you can do, but that is the trick: it is crafty in its simplicity...

Spells: Activate switches remotely, fire, freeze, heal, black hole(!)

Items: Arrows, bombs, boots(for jumping gaps), fishing pole, flute

Weapons: basic sword, upgraded sword that shoots if you are full health

Shields: basic shield, upgraded shield that deflects lasers

My verdict now is that it probably IS worth the $15.

Note: I have never played a Zelda game, so I am judging this game on its own merit.

[list]

[list]

39994655.review:
This became one of my favorite games in a prety quick timeframe. It has a unique charm that keeps me wanting more...and more. But unfortunately, it's 100 percent completed, both achievement-wise and in the game itself. This is one of those games you need to play for about four or five hours to know whether or not you enjoy it. If the terms 'Zelda-like' and 'top down' seem a bit mundane to you after seeing quite a bit of games like those, with a single one of those qualities or both, this is a game you can't afford to overlook, or at least acknowledge, because Oceanhorn seems to be just different enough to be considered a different approach to the genre.

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is indeed a Zelda-like game that has everything similar within, such as the dungeons, the way the game's story is laid out to you, an overworld nearly identical to The Wind Waker [except it isn't free-roam], items and equipment you can obtain [not too much variety, though], and mechanics themselves. And not to mention that the game's music is nice and catchy, the occasional voice acting is amazing, and the puzzles are pretty goshdang good. Starting with three hearts as your health, you can find [also not many] 'Heart Pieces', every four earning you another segment of health. You'll eventually get a magic bar as well, learning a few spells along your journey, some of which are even hidden/or optional.

Without saying too much, and correlating to the similarity to the Zelda franchise, the game's story revolves around the events of the past, before you set out on your journey, after your father who you overhear speaking of something called 'Oceanhorn'. Before you leave your starting island, you'll acquire your father's sword and shield in hope of going after him. And then you learn of the game's plot that pretty much consists of heading to faraway islands, meeting new species that come to aid you, clearing kinda-shorter dungeons and retrieving the three sacred emblems within them. You even find an upgraded sword and shield later on. And you'll learn of the game's lore throughout playing the game, obviously, and I think it's pretty elaborate for a game that's originally an iOS game for Apple phones. Not too many things on the side of the main quest, but there are fifty-five collectible 'bloodstones' you can whack to heck and will count toward getting a ridiculous spell that's really fun to blow everything up with.

Oceanhorn really is a fairly big game aside from what the Steam Store page suggests. Fifteen dollars is probably not an amazing asking price, but pick this game whenever it's on sale. Or conversely, get it on your Apple phone and have a mobile-but-less-graphically-enhanced version, if you care about how it'd look. And it already looks pretty amazing, and it's not even that demanding, either, which is great.

If you love Zelda games and want a great breath of that air, or looking for a decent action-adventure game that's actually extra-ordinary, again, pick up Oceanhorn when you can. There's a sequel in the works, if you measure success based off of sale and scores and all that.
