39753507.review:
Oh how I wish steam would allow something between a thumbs up and thumbs down, as Oceanhorn has got 3/5 written all over it. Oceanhorn is not inspired by Zelda – it’s a blatant knock off, aping the gameplay from the 2D entries and cribbing the aesthetic from Wind Waker while being nowhere near as good as either.

That Oceanhorn doesn’t measure up to one of the most critically acclaimed franchises by one of the world’s most prolific developers should not come as a surprise, especially considering this was originally a mobile game. This however doesn’t excuse everything in Oceanhorn from being a bit low rent, especially compared to other indie games at a similar price point. The overall presentation is very barebones – animations (where the devs even bothered) are stilted and stiff, texture and environment work is bland and constantly repeated and the writing and voice acting is absolutely terrible. Nothing here even approaches the quality of even the least fondly remembered Zelda game. Not even Phantom Hourglass.

That Oceanhorn is still a half decent game in spite of its flaws is more a testament to the quality of its inspirations than to any particular merits of its own. I can’t deny that I had fun, and everything about the design is so obviously lifted from better games that it’s hard to go wrong – dungeon/puzzle design is solid (though a bit too block puzzle heavy), combat and bosses are what you’d expect and there’s a decent amount of hidden collectables to reward those who go off the beaten path.

However, even on steam there are several significantly better options if you’re craving a Zeldalike – if you’re after a top down game similar to A Link to the Past then Hob is so much better it’s almost embarrassing. In the 3D Zelda space you have the excellent Darksiders and stone cold classic Okami. If you’ve played these, and don’t want to emulate the real thing then I suppose Oceanhorn makes for a middling but somewhat entertaining 10 hour distraction.

39548006.review:
It's a cute little puzzle game with a barebones story but somehow it works.  It's not mindblowing by any means but you can tell the small team of devs tried to polish it up as best they could.  Other reviews compare it to some Zelda titles but it does stand out on its own, drawing inspiration from some of the puzzles seen in older isometric games.  While rendered in 3D, the game does have a fixed camera for the most part in a top-down isometric 45 degree angle.  

The environments are nice enough to look at and the characters all have just enough personality as to not be 100% generic.  There are a lot of tropes seen in other RPG / ARPG games but Oceanhorn puts its own style and spin on it all.  An interview with one of the devs states that supposedly all the levels are made by one guy on a proprietary engine via iPad which is pretty interesting.  I'd like to state that for the most part it's a puzzle game, and not so much a platformer game, although height differences between environmental objects does come into play.  The closest comparison I can think of would be the world of Link to the Past rendered in 3D, tilted to the isomentric 45 degree viewing angle, and then split up and spread across a bunch of cute little Wind Waker islands.  It's not a generic Zelda clone, like say, 3D Dot Game Heroes so some of the other reviews were a little misleading in that respect.

Since the game was out on Android and iPad the combat isn't as refined as I'd like but you won't usually find yourself blaming bad controls for failing any challenges.  I would recommend playing with some type of controller as the keyboard layout isn't very intuitive and you can't rebind 75% of the keys for some reason.  This is my biggest gripe.  It's 2018 and we're still getting video games where you can't customize the controls.  An even bigger issue is due to the mobile restrictions certain buttons are used to do multiple things that don't quite relate to each other.  An example would be the button used for dashing around is the same button used to pick up items and throw them.  If your character isn't lined up quite correct with the item you're trying to pick up you'll find yourself running past it like a dummy.  Little annoyances like this should not exist, especially on a PC port.

If you compare this game to other mobile games it blows 90% of them all out of the water.  As a PC port it's not going to win GOTY but it's cute enough with enough secrets to discover that will drive you to 100% the game in a short amount of time without pulling your hair out.  It brings back feelings of the first Spyro or Ratchet & Clank titles before they got overloaded with too many sequels, powerups, and silly characters existing for no reason other than to bolster the Intellectual Property's Skylander figures.  The fun is in finding all those coins, eggs, gems, and bolts in a game like this and Oceanhorn's whole premise is constructed around that which is refreshing in an old school sort of way.

39334841.review:
Oceanhorn is unashamedly inspired by The Legend of Zelda, incidentally I decided to play it through after trying the demo on the Switch. 

The experience wasn't bad, but there are some pain points. If you're looking for a mini-Zelda, this largely hits the mark considering it's low pricetag (I believe I got it in a Humble Bundle as well.) The game compromises in enemy variety and dungeon puzzle variety (mostly pushing blocks and finding keys.)

The puzzles themselves were never challenging, but sometimes it was hard to tell what I was even trying to solve. This happens in the later bosses as well, figuring them out ended up being more of a frustrating process rather than exciting like it would be in LOZ. 

The writing is respectable. The game succeeds in building out an interesting world, while lacking interesting characters. I was still impressed though, as I was expecting it to be completely devoid of plot. I was interested enough, and pleasantly surprised by the voice acting for an indie. If the characters were as developed as the backstory of the game's world, it would've been exceptional. 

Combat is decent considering it was an iOS port, but could've been much better with a bit of touching up. Blocking and dodging is tied to a stamina meter. I had fun rolling between enemies, avoiding attacks, blocking in time, but that fun was short lived by running out of stamina. The final boss especially became irritating because of this. Some of his attacks seemed nearly impossible to avoid without rolling, but I needed the stamina to deflect certain attacks with the shield. Ultimately the fight felt much more lame since I just healed through his damage so I could expend all my stamina with the shield instead. 

In conclusion, considering that it's an indie game with a low pricetag, Oceanhorn does decently enough to be worth playing if you like the Isometric style of Zelda games. I'm personally a sucker for good worldbuilding, so I found myself driven forward by that, but also I'm less picky about the characters being lightly developed than most as it leaves plenty of room to fill the gaps myself. If you do get stuck anywhere though, just look up the solution. When you "figure it out", you won't feel satisfied most of the time. You'll just feel irritated that the puzzle itself wasn't hard, you just couldn't find the puzzle in the first place. 

Extra Notes: 94% completion in 13 hours, acquired all optional spells, but unsure if acquiring the rest of the collectables gets anything (reward is given without acuiring all of them.) After beating, no desire to 100%.

38119524.review:
Oceanhorn is unashamedly a Zelda Wind Waker clone.  Oceanhorn has the very similar music, artistic motifs, items, and enemies; some of these are even identical to those in the Zelda games.  The only noticable difference is Oceanhorn's unique, multi-tier terrain.  If you liked Wind Waker, or most any Zelda games, you'll probably like this one.

But Oceanhorn does have its flaws.  Movement is very sluggish, combat is incredibly easy, and the puzzles all almost exclusively just require you to push blocks to solve.  I think the biggest failure is that Oceanhorn really doesn't offer anything unique to make it stand out.  Oceanhorn is blatantly "okay" in every way.  Not bad, not great, just a game you'll play once and forget.

37938757.review:
Decent game, it's more on the good than on the bad side; not worth it at full price but if it catches your eye it will entertain you during it's short-ish duration.
The ideas were good, and it's a fine exploring/collectathon, but every problem this game has is self-inflicted pain.

The game is very easy (which is not a bad thing in particular, just be warned if you want some challenge this ain't the one), both in terms of combat and puzzling, there are some nice ideas and setups for puzzles and I'd wish they'd done more with them, yet I'll give them a pass, they work perfectly fine.
When it comes to combat there is very little enemy variety. I don't think that's a huge issue considering the lenght of the game, but it becomes increasingly noticeable after some time.

The story and worldbuilding has some nice ground, and you can feel there's something beyond what you're seeing, it's just barely explored and feels like hollow or "you're just seeing this very narrow side of the story"; which makes sense in a journey's perspective, but feels like the world closes it's doors to you when it comes to an exploration game.
I was very into the game's premise. An ocean monster? ancient technology? Ruined cities? Totally my jam! But it doesn't provide anything that you've never seen before or with a decent amount of substance to make them stay in your head after quiting the game.

In roleplaying games, they say "the most interesting part about the story can't have already happened when you start", here you feel you're here for the scraps, and not in a "you reconstruct the story and make sense of it while defining the new direction the world will take" (which would be just one of many interesting ways to take a story like this), but in a "oh, let us tell you what happened and there's this one thing left to do, do it and everything will be fine".

Traveling from island to island, you just select your destination and wait. You can shoot at some ocasional enemies and crates that will appear but it's so little engaging you'll end up spamming the fire button in the general direction while doing something else. Most boring part of the game by far, I would've loved more items to use on board, things to do or freedom to move myself.

The boss battles were... the most disappointing part. You explore, fight, and make your way to the islands to find some unique enemies that poses a challenge and... every single encounter is summed up to "find out what's the gimmick, repeat over and over."
You're probably thinking "well, most games in the genre are similar", but Oceanhorn pushes the boundaries. Maybe one is remotely memorable, the ambientation (either hype before or thrill during) the battle is nonexistant, the arenas are generic terrain you're already tired of... and when I say they're gimmicky I mean they're more trick execution that battles. Every single one of them. The final battle was extremely short as well which left you with a feeling it ended before it even started.

Performance-wise it runs fine, could be better optimized but no mayor problems.
It doesn't support gamepads/controllers with direct input, you'll need to use a third-party to map the controls.

Fine game, would give it a recommend if it supported controllers and had a little more content for the price point, for what it is, worth it if interested and on sale.

PS. Forgot to mention there's voice acting in the game, which ranges from "good but needed a little more emotion and oomph" to "I honestly took my headphones off and felt more inmersed in the world reading the dialogues alone bad"

37481707.review:
If you can get it for <$5 it's an acceptable game (my copy was part of a humble bundle), otherwise it's not worth hte time or money spent on it.

PROS
*Action based RPG (not a fan of turn based)
*Decent visuals, with consistent animation.

CONS
*Subpar controls
*Too many game mechanics are not explained. Travel mini game; how to switch spells; how to collect "bloodstones"; fishing mini game to name a few.
*The camera control for looking at the area at "different" angels allows you to turn the camera about 1 mm in either direction. In other words, anything you couldn't see before won't be revealed if you "move" the camera.
*During boss fights the camera rotates to keep the boss centered on the screen. This does not garent that you are facing the boss, nor are you able to see what is behind you (such as hostile enemies during the first boss battle).

36432327.review:
I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle. This game was not the reason I got the bundle, thankfully.

Anyone who's familiar with [i]The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker[/i] will see that Oceanhorn takes almost all of its ideas from it, down to the blue starting outfit, island travel, cannons, and more. I'd be able to look past this if the game offered much of anything inventive, funny, or novel. It disappoints me in every category, from gameplay to level design to story.

At first glance, this game has the makings of something good. Puzzle-oriented dungeons and so-so combat make the game seem inviting. As I played more of this game, I found so many shortcomings compared to other games in its genre. I'll cover these in order of importance.

[h1]Controls and Gameplay[/h1]

Oceanhorn offers both keyboard+mouse controls and Xbox controller controls. I played the game using a DualShock3 and BetterDS3 to emulate an Xbox360 controller. Sometimes, the game glitches out and reverts to KB+M controls and won't re-detect the controller until you relaunch it. When the controls work, they're okay. No other game does this to me, so I'm sure it's Oceanhorn.

Movement is very clunky. The main character can jog at a very slow pace, and dashing is limited to a single direction at a time. Stamina is depleted upon dashing, and you'll be lucky to cross a screen worth's of distance before running out. It takes roughly 10 seconds from depletion to fully charged stamina. There may be stamina upgrades later in the game, but I couldn't take it by the time I beat the Elder Gillman boss. More on that later.

Despite being in 3-D, Oceanhorn is clearly built using self-contained 3D boxes, which is closer to 2-D design philosophy. They're not voxels (it's traditional polys), but the reuse of assets is apparent. That wouldn't be a problem to me if it felt good to move around in the levels. The standard running speed is too slow to dodge anything reliably, walking up and down stairs is like watching a snail travel, and a later item that allows for rolling expends your stamina too quickly to be of any use. Couple this with a clearly box-oriented world, and you have a game that looks 3-D, but would be better off in 2-D.

When you hold your shield up using the right trigger, your character faces the nearest enemy and can strafe... except it's the same speed as swimming (which also eats stamina like crazy). Also of note is your shield can barely defend against anything. Rocks, maybe arrows. That's about it. Aerial enemies can hit you from above, past your shield, too.

Next is interaction. Oceanhorn mimics Zelda once again by using a context-sensitive action button. When you pick something up, hold a direction and hit the action button again to throw it. Aiming in this game is a pain in the ass, due to being stuck in an isometric camera angle. Thankfully, the game will correct for you if you're aiming near anything important.

Spells are something that sets Oceanhorn apart from the games it copies. It adds a second layer of interaction to the game world, which is very welcome. Unfortunately, you must stand in place and aim a cartoon hand at what you want to cast the spell on. Most of the time, this works fine, but if you're aiming at anything from a distance, there's a good chance that you'll cast on the wrong item, wasting your mana. Spells are also expensive, so you'll need to avoid busting things until puzzles are solved if you want to conserve mana.

Frankly, it's apparent that Oceanhorn underwent zero competent play-testing. There are so many minor issues with this game that it becomes a big problem just to play it. There are numerous places where I shouldn't have been able to go, but the weird edge detection would send me into walls. Sometimes, I'd have to hit a button twice to register an action. This game should've been in testing for at least 3-6 months to iron out these issues. One time, I fell through a floor and into the Elder Gillman boss fight, but was unable to correct the camera or escape, forcing me to exit the game.

The same item that allows you to roll is also used to jump across gaps. That's a great idea, but actually *using* that ability, especially during its boss, is a crapshoot. You'll most likely end up rolling off the edge of things instead of jumping, even if you're stationary when using it.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

Oceanhorn is not what I'd call a difficult game; nothing wrong with that, because it's fairly lighthearted and started out pretty solid. However, the difficulty in this game comes from knowing where to bomb things, or "dodging" boss attacks that have nigh-perfect accuracy. That is not a substitute for real difficulty! In fact, the Elder Gillman boss in general is a disaster. He hovers near you constantly, and rains boulder shards on you from a distance; one of which is guaranteed to hit unless you dash or roll in time. His freeze laser traps you for 5-10 seconds, and the mechanisms you activate are dependent on switches or using the dungeon item perfectly. On its own, this wouldn't be so bad; cheese bosses can often be cheesed back in return. Sadly, this boss is very efficient at staying in your face, and is difficult to hit with the statues that breath fire. The camera is focused on him the entire time, which makes it difficult to see where you're going. Pots and purple coral will obstruct your way, making this fight even worse.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Honestly, the story isn't that bad. It's your standard adventure game fare. Instead of a princess, you're looking for your dad, who went to face Oceanhorn. Or something like that. The writing is a little cheesy in places, but overall there's not much to complain about. I couldn't get attached to any characters in the 12 or so hours I played.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Graphics are easily the best part of this game, but even then they feel... odd. It has a sort of Unity/Unreal feel to it, with over-rendered textures on environments, but cartoony enemies and characters. Kind of an odd mix. My biggest pet peeve is the lack of meaningful camera control. You can "lean" the camera using the right stick, but it's never enough to see anything important, and you can't rotate the camera or switch to a top-down view.

While we're talking about graphics, let's discuss objects you can destroy. It's not apparent which piles of dirt or rocks you can bomb and which you can't. This is a problem that game developers fixed [b]decades ago[/b]. There's no excuse to not have some sort of visual cue -- even if it's minute -- to prevent the player from wasting bombs or other resources like mana. In fact, Zelda: The Wind Waker *has* clues that suggest hidden items, while Oceanhorn does not. The game does a shoddy job of conveying what it intends you to do, and which areas are accessible. There are tons of places that [i]look[/i] like you can reach them, but are blocked.

Ultimately, Oceanhorn has the potential to be an enjoyable, light-hearted adventure game. Its light, unengaged story, frustrating controls and mechanics, and bullshit-grade bosses prevent me from enjoying anything great that this game might have to offer later on. I suggest skipping this game entirely. Word is the developers are working on a sequel; I would wait and see on that before bothering to spend money on an experience that will leave you wanting to play Zelda instead. Other games in the genre just plain do it better. I'm normally a big supporter of indies, but this game was clearly rushed and lacks the polish needed for the game to shine.

If I could tell the developers of Oceanhorn one thing, it's this: Give your games time to be refined and polished. A rushed game is bad forever. A delayed game can eventually be good. Do yourself a favor and test your games better. Insist on high quality programming; the graphics will come later.

Say, are you a fan of SNES-era action adventures?
You are? And you like A Link to the Past specifically?
Well, you're probably gonna like this then!

Alright, let's get down to business. This game draws heavily from 3 Zelda titles.
Its core gameplay is very much like A Link to the Past.
Its world and transportation is more like Wind Waker.
It has an aquatic race that is *very* similar to the zoras from Ocarina of Time.
All of these are good things. However, Oceanhorn understandably does not reach the same level of quality.
It would be unreasonable to expect such, considering the aforementioned series is a first-party Nintendo franchise.
Still, Oceanhorn makes an admirable attempt. It may not be as expansive or as polished, and I personally do not care for the voice acting, but it is an overall decent game and I certainly do not feel sorry for buying it.

It's derivative, clunky to control, generic looking, and boring. I wanted to like it because it looks like a nice modern take on classic Legend of Zelda style games. It's slow and clumsy, the area layouts have no flow to them and are not fun to explore, and the story and characters lack the charm of better games in this genre.


Playing this, i kept expecting that eventually the game would turn a corner and I'd get past the slow introductory phases of the game, at which point things would pick up. I don't know if that ever happens because I eventually ran out of patience.


One of the risks inherent in making a game which is so blatantly derivative of beloved classics, is that you may end up reminding the player of better games. Much of the time spent playing this, I kept thinking to myself that I'd be better off re-playing Link to The Past, or finding one of the other Zelda games that I'd never finished. Well my SNES classic arrived in the mail today so I'm probably going to do just that.


If you're looking for a decent Zelda-like with a good balance of new ideas and homages to the classics, I *do* recommend Anodyne.

I was pleasantly surprised by this game. It's a cute little Legend of Zelda clone that takes inspiration from all of the LoZ games and puts it all in a 2.5D world. By 2.5D, I mean that the graphics are 3D, but the camera perspective is fixed so the navigation, combat and world layout is very much like the old 2D LoZ game, although it is significantly smaller. Difficulty is somewhat less than a real LoZ title, but there are definitely some annoying boss fights (more due to the controls than anything else).

It's not perfect by any stretch. The game is a little on the short side, the controls are glitchy/unresponsive at times (especially the KB/M controls), and the world design/game flow is a little rough (too much backtracking, not enough shortcuts to previously visited areas) compared to a real LoZ game. There's also one item you get literally right before the final boss fight that is used only once in that fight and nowhere else in the game. Feels like a major missed opportunity.

Overall though, I definitely enjoyed playing this game and can recommend it if you enjoy LoZ.

A pretty decent zelda-like, strongly inspired by Windwaker it seems. I liked it, and the DLC/definite edition island was by far the best, but there are a few points you should consider before buying:

1) Unskippable cut scenes. The last cut scenes could be skipped on controller, but the first ones could not. And no speech can be skipped, so when you go to an island and there is a narrator, you cant see your hotkeys and cant skip the speech. I get the feel that they are very proud of their story but chose to tell it through cut scenes instead of gameplay.

2) It was infuriating to figure out where you can jump down and where you cant. The game opens up once you get the ability to jump (and frankly, that should be the first thing you learn) but that happens waaay too late. In any way, it was very poorly communicated where you can jump down and where you cant. For refrence: You can jump down 1 level. Mostly. More than that, and you cant jump. And sometimes you cant jump down 1 level either.

3) Bombable places are not marked what so ever. This is bad and needs to stop. Period. I liked the game but this was very much the largest detrement to that.

4) This is probaly mostly for modders of older games, but it felt a lot like a (very well made) mod from Warcraft 3, due to the way the levels and islands were designed within the limitations of the engine they used.

34718676.review:
An enjoyable old-school spirited Zelda clone, with charming art direction and fun (yet familiar) gameplay. You play as a boy on a quest to find his father and destroy the sea monster, Oceanhorn.

The narrative progression is in the form of island hopping, with challenges and quests on each of the land masses that pop up on the world map. This is a good looking game when in play mode but the cut scenes suffer from some terrible animation and the story isn’t very engaging. The voice acting is mediocre but the music is wonderfully nostalgic and reminiscent of old-school JRPGs. Another problematic area is in the level design. Since the game refuses to hold your hand or even provide a quest log or journal, this makes for some frustrating amounts of back tracking or redundant island hopping. Even with these delays, ‘Oceanhorn’  is a fairly short adventure, taking an average of about 10 hours to complete. There’s a fair bit of replayability for completionists in the form of each of the islands’ three challenges or expanding the game world further with DLC islands.

On mobile devices, this is a highly recommended little adventure.  For other platforms? Worth a playthrough, especially in preparation for that solid looking sequel on the horizon.

34241565.review: Oceanhorn has been an amazing experience for me. It takes the classic action/adventure formula and sprinkles in just a little bit of RPG leveling (though, not in the traditional sense). Your main character gets all of the usual moves - attack; block; magic; dash; etc. but the game is paced well enough that you get a new ability, item, or spell periodically enough to keep it interesting. Leveling up doesn't increase stats but instead improves your spells, increases your carrying capacity or grants a new ability. This offers a little extra motivation to fight the monsters along the way and not just run past everything. The puzzles are not too difficult but they were rarely boring and they were easy enough to execute once you figured them out. Many other games make putting the solution together more difficult than actually solving the puzzle, so I am glad Oceanhorn didn't do the same. I also like how the "drops" are prioritzed a little bit. If you're low on health the enemies are more likely to drop a heart for you. Low on bombs? They'll probably drop some bombs. It's a nice touch and saves you from running to town to constantly buy supplies. The graphics and sound are all done well, especially for a game that started on mobile devices. I have no real complaints, only a couple of minor frustrations. Having limited movement on the camera is a bit bothersome for a 3D game but it's clearly a choice the developers made based on the style of game. There is also a little bit of backtracking to be done but if you're going for 100% you're going to do that anyway. Also, the fishing mini-game had a couple of annoying "tricks" used by the fish, which didn't spoil the game but was still a minor frustration. Overall I really enjoyed Oceanhorn.

34141840.review: clearly inspired by Zelda: The Wind Waker, Oceanhorn is still enjoyable for the fans of the genre. I recommend it on sale.

34025062.review:
Pues, no lo puedo considerar un mal juego, pero tampoco una bueno.

Pros:
-Estilo artístico que imitar a The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker y The Legend of Zelda: The Phantom hourglass
-Calabozos, combates y acertijos estilo Zelda.
-Entretenido y con una  curva de dificultad aceptable.
-El minijuego de pesca es divertido aunque algo frustrarte con los últimos peces.

Contras:
-En algunas ocasiones el juego se cierra o se queda la pantalla en blanco; teniendo que forzar el cierre del programa o jugarlo modo ventana para que esto no ocurra (igual puede que solo ocurra en mi pc y no en todas).
-Es muy confuso usar el minimapa, es muy poco intuitivo, no sabes a donde ir y tampoco sabes si te faltó algo (aun así logré tener el 100% de  todos los logros).
-Entiendo que este basado en Zelda Wind Waker, pero resultan muy poco memorables.
-Las animaciones en los cutscenes se miran raras.
-El motivo de recolectar los emblemas se siente totalmente innecesario en toda la historia. No hay casi nada de conexión con ellos salvo al final (y muy forzado).
-La historia es  muy cliche, ya he visto demasiado juegos indie con esta premisa (buscar/rescatar/vengas a tu padre desaparecido). No hay nada de mano en usar cliches, Super mario o Zelda son quienes mas los usan, pero en ellos si funciona, por alguna razón aquí no mucho.
-La economía del juego esta muy desequilibrada. Al inicio cuando pudieses ocupar comprar algo de la tienda, no te alcanza nada ya que los enemigos dan muy poco dinero; y después, llega a un punto de los enemigos te dan tanto dinero que ya no hay nada que se pueda comprar.
-Las físicas del juego se siente raras, como si solo hubieran usado las físicas base de Unity en elementos que no ocupaban; provocando que en distintas secciones rompan el juego (pensaba que había encontrado un secreto en pero en realidad solo eran errores por las físicas del juego).
-Los premios que se consiguen con las Bloodstone son innecesarios en el punto del juego cuando logras conseguir todas (No diré que es para no hacer spoiler).

Lo que si puedo decir, es que disfruté los calabozos opcionales (principalmente el ultimo que es secreto), ya que sigue una estructura muy diferente a los otros calabozos. Pero nada mas eso. Pues nada, era eso lo que quería decir.

Dios me los bendiga :D

33209539.review:
Strip away its unique art style and seemingly half-baked story and suddenly Oceanhorn looks a lot like a Zelda clone. The basics of item progression, exploration, combat, and dungeon design all resemble Zelda in one form or another, which is comforting. The formula of the Zelda series is tried and tested, and works in Oceanhorn's favor.

While Oceanhorn never reaches the same heights as the Zelda games it attempts to emulate, it still does a good job at designing a believable world full of enemies, dungeons, and general villagers. What attracted me to Oceanhorn was its art style; I am a sucker for unique art styles, and Oceanhorn did a great job in this regard.

Pros:
- Item progression is rewarding
- Island discovery and exploration is a lot of fun
- The art style is visually appealing and the colors pop
- The music and general sound effects are well-designed
- It is satisfying to access unexplored areas with newly-found equipment

Cons:
- Combat is a bit clunky
- The story feels half-baked
- Most enemies are far too easy to defeat
- Swords are able to slay enemies but can not break pots
- The camera, while it can swivel slightly, is often too restricted
- The open ocean is not freely able to be explored like individual islands are
- Aside from the last few encounters, the bosses are laughably easy to take down

Pros and cons aside, my time with Oceanhorn was enjoyable. Exploring dungeons and fighting enemies with an ever-increasing collection of equipment was satisfying, and chatting with the locals of the various islands for information was a joy. Oceanhorn is inexpensive and a lot of fun. I highly recommend checking this game out.

32882891.review:
If you are a fan of the Legend of Zelda, then this will be an amazing game for you. It does a great job at following the tried and true formula of the classical Zelda games, including such great features as:

Dungeons and puzzles to explore and complete.

New items, spells, and upgrades to obtain all throughout the game.

Fierce monsters and bosses to overcome on your path to victory!

Being the first release in its franchise, it doesn't stray too far from the tree and you will certainly see how most of the things we experience in this game are based off elements from the Zelda series, but it does introduce a few new concepts to the formula like experience and leveling up, technology and magic hand-in-hand, and its own unique lore which I can definitely see getting built up later on. 

I really look foward to the sequel, so I hope others will help support Cornfox & Bros. on this series!

32388341.review:
The game is somewhat polished for an Indie title and it is no secret that it is heavily influenced and pays homage to The Legend of Zelda series, particularly the 2D titles, because there is little-to-no 3D gameplay here, and perhaps Wind Waker on a more superficial level. It is definitely pleasing from an aesthetic perspective, but the soundtrack is very forgettable. The gameplay is repetitive and unsatisfactory, if not awkward at times. There are no standout riddles or puzzles. On the surface, it tries very hard to replicate the design of Zelda games, but some questionable design choices will remind you of the power gap between Oceanhorn and a real Zelda game, or a well designed game in general. 

In conclusion, this is a game that is playable and looks nice, but lacks the necessary depth to really stand out among the hundreds of indie games around it in the same space. I wish I could give this a "Meh", as it is not a bad game per se to go for a straight "No", but between the two, it's definitely not a "Yes". It is just a flat, average experinence that doesn't have any particular highs to warrant a recommendation.

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seases un juego muy regular, para empezar es un port de IOS y Android,  intenta ser una copia de The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass con algunos pequeños cambios en lo que falla rotundamente.

Para empezar la historia es un cliche videojueguil de los de toda la vida, el mal acecha con cargarse el mundo y tu estas ahi para cargarte al mal y todo lo que se ponga en medio, por el camino procastinas un poco enamorandote, salvandole la vida a alguien querido, ayudando al pueblo o pescando. Vamos lo normal en este tipo de juego.

El problema llega a la hora de jugarlo, el propio juego no se respeta a si mismo, me explico hay partes donde te enseña tus posibilidades como puedes activar x interruptor con x objeto pero hay veces que esta norma no se sigue o a la hora de pelear contra ciertos enemigos en los que se supone que si te escondes detras de un muro puedes esquivar el ataque pero este te da igual que si no hubiera nada lo que lleva a situaciones injustas y bastante estupidas aun asi el juego es bastante simple  cosa que no va a impedir que vayas a morir 30 veces en x punto por cualquier chorrada, tambien tengo que decir que el escenario no es muy uniforme y se dan situaciones raras como intentar romper un jarro contra una pared y que quede arriba de esta y otras muchas mas cosas. la variedad de enemigos es escasa creo que solo e visto a 10 enemigos diferentes en todo el juego cosa que lo hace muy monotono y aburrido.

Los puzzles son muy simples hay 2 o 3 a los que hay que darle al coco y poco mas, si eres fan de los zelda clasicos seguramente te los sabras todos.

La BSO esta simplemente bien, hay momento en que acompaña prefectamente la accion y otros que no viene ni a cuento

La duracion totalñ del juego rondara las 8 horas como mucho y la rejugabilidad es casi nula.

En resumen, es un juego con muchos fallos que podria ser un juegazo si se arreglara, por ahora para mi solo es otra copia barata de los Zelda de nintendo ds.

There are items that you can get and they feel useful for the most part (the Bow and Arrow is great and has a sort of auto aim on the Y-axis). Riding in your boat is fun, and is especially so when you get items that you can use in your boat. Going to different islands feels good and the exploring is rewarding. The story as a whole (up to where I've gotten to in the game so far) is interesting but is nothing new. The bosses are fun and are very reminiscent of Zelda bosses in the way that they all have a gimmick. This game is a great Zelda clone and I would recommend picking it up if you're looking for a great adventure!

31580433.review:
The reviews I have seen compare Oceanhorn to The Legend of Zelda: The Windwaker, which I feel is an unfair comparison. The sailing you do in this game is on rails, but do not let this deter you!
Gameplay-wise, Oceanhorn is a classic Legend of Zelda game similar to the Gameboy or Gameby Advance games such as A Link to the Past. There are many dungeons and a few puxxles to solve.

I am quite driven to colect all the Bloodstones ad Achievement Hunt this game, as there is surprisingly a lot to do; you will gain abilities throughout the story that means you can return to previously explored islands to discover new locations and secrets!

Although the graphics and animations aren't fantastic, this game seems to have a lot of heart and inpiration behind it. I seriously recomend you play this for the first few dungeons and it will have you hooked.

I'm currently playing this alongside Breath of the Wild, and it is giving me the pure combat/dungeon experience, whereas games such as BotW or TWW are more exploratory.

tl;dr: A really good indie game in the vain of Link to the Past. Dungeoneering action. Worth a play.

31085061.review:
.... This is just..... Hard to review in a sense in how to describe this game.

This game is good but bad at the same time in some sense; but the good over shadows the bad only by so much... I guess I'll begin with the bad.

Bad:
The story is boring: In the sense it's your basic adventure story, something evil from an old age of technology and other sh*t comes out of no where and threatens to destroy the world and it's kinda mediocore from there. Sacred places with extra races who are grateful you recovered their technology or home or something precious to them that they give you a treasure so near and dear tot hem that you abuse it for puzzles and your own amusement such as dropping rocks out of the sky onto villagers for the hell of it.

The sound cues are just as bad, with the exception of the music, which is ok and some of the puzzle solving sounds, everything else feels out of place... When I got the Earth medallion for example, the laser like sound didn't sound like power was flowing from it and it's just awkward silence from there witht he voice from the medallion coming out of it. There are a dozen other sound clips in the game that just dislodge the whole experience. EVEN THE VOICE ACTING IS JUST..... WHY?!

If it was just the programmers voice acting to their game like the developers in Two World where the teams don't know HOW to voice act; Then I can give it the benefit of the doubt and let that slide for now.

The Good:
While it isn't as BIG or impressive as the game it's cloning, Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker and Legend of Zelda, any top down zelda-like game; It does bring other ideas to the table the legend of zelda genre won't touch or hasn't touched on yet.

Experience points: Ok, show of hands, who here finds grinding tiresome after doing it for a while in turn by turn RPG's and who here finds grinding LESS tiresome just by going around and killing lots of badies just because you we're bored and nothing good was on TV... Well, Ocean Horn uses the later part of that experience and it kinda works. What do you gain from the leveling? Well; imrpessive buffs such as the ability to carry more bombs or carry more arrows and so forth. In Zelda you either had to buy that kinda stuff or earn it after a tedious minigame; which is fine, unless that mini-game was a pain and you needed to perfect it. It's nothing new in some other top-down Zelda Clones, but at least this one has a decent idea of how to go about it.

World: The world is kinda like a mix between Minecraft and Legend of zelda and weirdly enough, I'm ok with that. You have an area to explore, you can't fall from great heights which forces you to think about how you navigate your terreign and so on. When you travel from island to island, the ocean water kinda looks like real ocean water, nearly realistic that I have to give the developers points for details like this and the different biomes from island to island.

Magic: Before I get stomped on, I want to ask a simple question, Aside from Din's Fire, Nayru's Love, Faore's wind and Large spin attack among OTHER spells in the Legend of Zelda, have any of them interacted int he world that you had to use to solve multiple puzzles? I've only seen it A FEW times in both N64 game's and in Link's Adventure for the NES and that's it. In this game, the spells or at least the magic I've found so far has multiple uses from puzzle solving to simple combat. Earlier I mentioned a spell that dropped rocks out of the sky; that spell can be used to fight enemies since you can throw rocks at them while also it can be used to hit switches you can't normally reach due to some difficulty.

Misc: The monster designs are though out in terms of how you beat them and their complexitity grows with each new island you find and become more difficult to beat. The character models, while not well designed, are ok for the kind of game developed, Puzzles, when solved, don't take 10-20 SECONDS TO SHOW THE EFFECT OF WHAT HAPPENED AFTER YOU SOLVED IT..... Looking at you ocarina of time..... There's places to explore for loot, treasure and it's fun to kill stuff.

I already heard theres an Oceanhorn 2 ind evelopment and after seeing a screen shot of it; I have high hopes for this team toa ctually make a game that could probably rival Zelda. If you have the money and just beat breath of the wild while WAITING for the DLC to it to be developed, I would defiantly give this one a look to the end.

30982586.review:
Oceanhorn is a fun little Gem of a game. It's truly a Zelda inspired game with elements of Windwaker, and a little classic SNES/Gameboy Zelda inside. The game is a lot of fun, yet simplified enough for anyone to pick up and play.  Controls work well, and surprisingly the voice acting isn't too bad for being on it's own merits. I want to give a very special shout out to the composer of the game. The music in this game is fantastic, and noticeably enjoyable to listen to. I would go as far to say that I would love to have an OST for this game.  Back to the game, the boss battles are fun and clever enough, using your progression as the tool to winning.  The game has a fair amount of meat on it, as of this review i'm nearing the end parts of the story; however, there is still a bunch of collectibles around the many islands to keep you busy and gaining Level Ups.  Yes, there are Level Ups too in this game, which reward you with new abilities, and stronger attributes, making grinding a factor as well if you want to beef up.  

Overall, this is a fun game, and worth the price! I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this title, and I would love to see this turn into a series of it's own if it were in the interests of the Devs!

30939791.review: Oceanhorn looks a little bit like Windwaker and it does play a lot like other Zelda titles, although with less complexity. Yet still, it is a fun little gem.

30929987.review:
Bad:

- Lots of backtracking. For example, you find jumping boots (for jumping over gaps) only after like 10 locations from when you first see a gap.
- Sometimes you can't swim on land even though there is land
- Enemies attack back faster than you can shield yourself after hitting them
- Fishing is pretty boring and slow (botfish and ghostfish have too much RNG in getting them)
- Some spells cost so much mana that you can only cast them twice, this can be bad in rooms with puzzles and enemies that require those spells
- You barely find any coins and you want heart containers from shops, so you tend to not use shop refills.
- Fetch quests and how the items they ask to bring break up after throwing them at an attacking enemy. You'd think a metal weather cuckoo wouldn't be destroyed after throwing it at a squishy enemy. Also it might be hard to even find a metal weather cuckoo without looking it up on a guide.
- Can't drop down blocks
- Too simplistic puzzles and not much difficulty increase in them
- Unavoidable bomb attacks and bugged laser attacks of the final boss

Good:

+ Overall artstyle and design
+ Some story elements
+ Sound/Soundtrack
+ Controls

Despite a lot of annoyances, I would recommend playing the game. Maybe you'll be patient with the final boss and it's buggy laser/unavoidable bomb attacks.. I wasn't.

Edit: After trying a few more times I got lucky with RNG and beat the final boss. I went to the Island of Whispers afterwards, but only managed to find 9 out of 10 skulls. I think the skulls are a bit too well hidden because I couldn't find the 10th one after backtracking.

7,5/10

30686699.review:
As a gamer who appreciates a more casual approach in a game, Oceanhorn is a very solid and fun experience. 

The puzzles, exploration aspects, achievement hunting and enemy difficulty were just right as I do not wish to be engaged in 5 minute extreme battles every time I fight a singular enemy - though the trend nowadays seems to be towards difficult encounters and challenging content. But I play games to relax and enjoy the experience - to that end Oceanhorn was perfect. 

There was no crafting bloating the irritation and time wasting aspect to the game. There were no side quests mandatory to level up. Just a straight forward story-lite which guided you to all the different islands, dungeons and puzzles with various challenges which each give achievements.

I have around 14 hours playtime and 100% of achievements, out of a £5 investment so great time:cost value as well. 

If you are after some Dark Souls level combat or difficulty, or a fully fledged Zelda-like experience, you will be disappointed with Oceahorn. 

However if you can appreciate the simple-ness of the game and note its solid combat, level design, art style and puzzle design then you can easily get your money's worth out of this cheap, cute and refreshing game.

Puzzles (lo unico que te supondra algo de reto, pero por insulsos, pesados y repetitivos):  mueve cajas, activa interrutor, coge llave, abre puerta, mueve cajas, mata esbirro generico, coge llave, abre puerta y asi hasta la saciedad ......

Durante el juego deberas ir de isla en isla (unas con poblados, otras con mazmorras y otras para decorar) y sin duda esta  es otra pata coja de esta silla. Vas en un barco (que no puedes controlar)  y cuando estas en el, tendras una escopeta ( ?¿ wtf) para disparar al calamar  y obstaculos que apareceran durante el recorrido, dependiendo de la distancia a la que viajes, entre punto A y punto B te encontraras con 1, 2, o 3 conjuntos de objetos + calamar. Las 3-4 primeras veces tiene un pase, pero cuando lleves ya 27 veces le habras cogido ya un asco a esta parte del juego muy generosa, por lo repetitivo y por el tiempo que te hace perder.

Luego la duración del juego, se alarga artificialmente, con unas piedras que tienes que recojer en todas las islas, y que en ningún momento parece que se puedan roper para cogerlas porque cuando las golpeas no hay ningun efecto extra, y tienes que golpearlas como 20 veces (sin exagerar), asi como retos de islas, que pasan por romper 20 objetos, gastarse dinero en las tiendas, matar x cantidad de enemigos.. y que al completarlos te daran experiencia para subir de nivel (el subir de nivel solo te aportara poder llevar mas cantidad de x objeto en la mayoria de las veces). 
Te anima todo esto a copletarlo 100% o rejugarlo? desde luego que no.

En fin a no ser que te regalen el juego no gastes dinero ni tiempo.
Si buscas opciones de "Zelda para pc" hay otras muchas mejores opciones y otras que estan por salir muy recomendables

[h1]System Info[/h1]

OS: Windows10 x64
CPU: i7-7700@4.2Ghz
RAM: 32GB DDR4@2400
GPU: GTX-1080-OC@~2Ghz
HDD: 512GB M.2 SSD, 256GB/1TB UASP USB3.1 SSD, 2TB SATA3
HDD: *Game was installed on 1TB UASP USB3.1 SSD

[h1]Positive[/h1]

- Cute (Music, GFX and Story...)
- Good Zelda Style Graphics (But doesn't support DSR...)
- Multiple Islands (But not enough...)
- Good Dungeons (But way too easy and small compared to Zelda...)
- Good Riddles (But way too easy compared to Zelda...)
- Game never crashed or freezed
- No Bugs encountered

[h1]Negative[/h1]

- Can't Aim correctly with Reflect Shield (In real Zelda this would been made perfectly!)
- Some Magics are never used and obsolete
- Becomes too Easy fast (Already OP around Lvl.11 of 16)
- Last Boss Battle sucked, especially Phase 1 (Reflect Shield Aim Issue hit hard here!)
- Bot Fish Sucked (Simply electrocutes too much which resulted in five very cheap Deaths)
- There is no Restart at Checkpoint or Suicide Option so if stuck Exit to Menu is only Solution

[h1]Additional Info[/h1]

There also was many reports of Resolution Problems and Stuttering Issues, but didn't notice anything like this. I played the Game at 1080p60 on the Plasma TV with a wireless Xbone Controller and everything was smooth as butter.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

If you liked Zelda Wind Waker and Zelda Occarina of Time and want to play an Indie Clone on PC get it on Sale.

30050769.review:
Put simply, Oceanhorn is an audio-visual feast with an emotionally driven, heartfelt narrative. While not groundbreaking in terms of originality, it succeeds at plunging you into a magical fantasy world and keeps you anchored there on account of its rich lore, thought-provoking puzzles, and sheer volume of environments that are ripe for exploration. Oceanhorn might be a love-letter to Zelda, but perhaps the question should not be whether it rises to Zelda's level, but rather, whether it is able to forge a path of its own that players will remember. In that regard, the answer is a resounding yes. If you are a fan of Zelda games and have been searching the oceans high and low for a similar experience, do yourself a favour and play this now. Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is as close to 3D platforming perfection as it gets.

Good things:                                              

+ Gorgeous art                                            
+ Excellent, clear onboarding                     
+ Breathtaking music
+ Touching narrative
+ Effortless, intuitive controls
+ Highliy Immersive

Bad things:

- Boss fight camera angles disorienting
- Final boss too easy

There's some puzzles that depend on being observant, some that depend on the obfuscation of the isometric viewpoint and others which depend on your improving skills/items. 
It's charming, solidly built and with an easy going pace which will suit older gamers looking for a bit of nostalgia, who are looking for something to take a couple of weekends of relaxed play time and for younger gamers who might not have played the aforementioned games and for whom this might be their first action adventure.

29530654.review:
A decent port of an iOS game. To most this is a Zelda clone, however, it's missing something that Zelda is known for: the Boomerang. Other than that... well, there's bombs, bow and arrows, a fishing rod, magic spells, and so on. To compare this to Zelda, though, isn't fair. Zelda is a much better game, but this is still enjoyable.

The graphics are decent for a mobile game, and the controls are pretty good. I recommend playing with a gamepad. Puzzles are fairly easy though it's easy to get stuck sometimes as well. Thankfully there's a reset switch in almost every puzzle. I did get stuck at one point due to having used a key in the wrong place, so I had to reload my save entirely.

The game has crashed on me a few times, though I'm lucky I didn't lose a lot of progress due to the fact that there's checkpoints everywhere. Combat is fairly basic, there's blocking and attacking. I mentioned bombs, bow/arrows, and magic. Aiming kind of sucks with the latter two, and magic isn't used too often to really care about it. Boss battles are easy enough though some can be frustrating. Especially a certain one later in the game. The story is rather bland but pieces together nicely in the end. The music isn't anything to write home about, either.

I've played over 18 hours and I'm barely at 85% completion. The game features a quest to collect 55 bloodstones scattered throughout the world, up to 9 heart containers, 7 types of fish to catch, and 16 adventurer ranks to obtain. Too bad there isn't an achievement for getting 100%. But there is a sense of satisfaction in it, at least.

tl;dr A decent Zelda clone with many hours of gameplay. Best to get on sale.

29499349.review:
A poor man's Zelda, by every stretch. From combat to flare, it doesn't just fall flat, but feels like a two dimensional biege mimic of an actual Zelda game's design. The items are unfun to use, the puzzles are nowhere near as fun as a zelda game, and unfortunately, there isn't really a redeeming factor outside its average monster design which, as it is just okay, can't really redeem things. Breaking things down for the game is hard, because each bland piece is connected to each other bland piece of the sub par jigsaw puzzle. 

Combat itself is probably one of the first things you'll notice, as it somehow lack that magic zing that makes it fun. Throughout my relatively short time with the game, none of it really felt either interesting or fun. The sword doesn't feel long enough to feel like I'm a swordmen, and the monsters both take too many hits and are annoying due to the short range. This probably is linked to how crowded the game is. There doesn't feel like any breathing room for flair, an entire town feels like a single street corner instead of an actual town. Dungeons feel like small hallways, and the fighting room just isn't there. Item use, what I have gone through, just isn't creative enough to break the mold and give me something new to work with. 

The worst part isn't really the gameplay, though it is linked to the cramping issue. The game just doesn't have any flavor. The first few shots of the island don't feel any different from each other due to the way the game is set up with its blocks, and there isn't enough small tidbits to make islands feel different. There isn't room outside of the small zelda clone box Oceanhorn has been crammed into.

It may have worked for a game on a mobile platform, but it doesn't work for a larger and more diverse game competition. If you want a zelda experience for your computer, all this game will do is remind you of everything zelda manages to get right. On the other hand, if you ever managed to convince yourself that what zelda does is easy and there's no thought to it, you should buy this game and realize everything zelda does right by seeing what oceanhorn does wrong.

28920810.review:
So, I completed Oceanhorn today, after around 11 or so hours. It's so much of a 2D Zelda clone that I've taken to calling it 'The Legend of Zoldo'. And I have to say it is a very problemed game, and a lot of those problems stem from it originally being designed for a touchscreen.

For example, in order to make moving the character manageable with a virtual stick the developer opted to make you walk really, really slowly. Which isn't helped with a difficult to control dash move that has you running out of stamina almost instantly (and it takes ages to replenish).

Add to that the cube-based level design which only lets you jump down from a height of one cube (whereas Zelda lets you drop down as long as there is ledge somewhere below, no matter how far below) and you have to painfully trek back and forth around the levels a lot.

But the design oversights get worse. For example, you can throw and smash pots (oddly you can't break them with your sword) to get hearts, arrows and whatnot, but unlike Zelda where the item you get is semi-randomised in your favour, in Oceanhorn it's entirely random which means you can get flooded with arrows when your stock is full and you desperately need health or magic. Many times I've had to trek back outside of a dungeon/area until I could top myself up.

There are also other immersion killers such as the poor implementation of the soundtrack.

Don't get me wrong, I don't mean the soundtrack itself is poor (anything but), rather that the way it is used is overbearing. The game is constantly playing music that doesn't fit the mood of the scene, many times being just too cacophonous (works great in boss fights, not elsewhere) and, ultimately, tiring to listen to. The tracks don't even loop correctly as you'd expect of videogame music.

Finally there's the several sections in the game where the solutions to puzzles are counter-intuitive because you can't move certain statues/boxes (for seemingly no reason) but can others. Or one part where you have to gather items from the island you are on, but are not given any indication that the last item you need is on a completely different island altogether.

Still, it's not all bad. Some of the puzzle towards the end are pretty cool. And there's a really substantial optional island that is worth checking out. The story too, develops into something that is quite interesting (with the major characters voiced well).

But, all in all, I feel it's a game that just needs more polish, especially in the dungeons where you mostly do rudimentary puzzles. There's no sub-bosses or cool moments when you are locked in a room against an enemy mob. It's all just very... pedestrian.

28917019.review:
Unapologetically inspired by The Legend of Zelda series, Oceanhorn is a fun, if fairly lightweight, adventure/RPG.

The game sees the player exploring a series of islands (with both overworld locations and buildings/dungeons) from an overhead perspective, fighting monsters with a small selection of weapons (most commonly, just a sword and shield) and solving simple puzzles. The combat is fairly straightforward 'hack-and-slash' in style, but remains satisfying, while the puzzles are generally focused around block-pushing and switches - these are seamlessly integrated into the world, maintaining a good level of variety in most situations.

Graphically the game is again farily simplistic in style, with its roots as a mobile port being clear, but that style has a certain charm to it and means that the game isn't very demanding on system requirements. The soundtrack works well to provide a fitting atmosphere, but I can't see it being anything that remains memorable long-term.

Coming in at around 10-15 hours to complete, the game doesn't outstay its welcome but still has enough content to feel substantial. A fairly extensive list of achievements provides an excuse to sink some more time into the game - many of these will come 'naturally' as you play, but there are a few with quite specific requirements that encourage experimentation. One thing that I'd recommend not getting too focused on is the fishing mechanic, as ultimately this brings little reward and is unfortunately based on randomness that does require 'grinding' to see out in full.

All in all, Oceanhorn gets my recommendation as a very approachable adventure - just don't come here expecting a great deal of depth to the game.

28195776.review:
this game was a lot of fun. a lot like zelda, except maybe without all of the polish that having a massive game studio can get you. i liked how the approach to every [big item you get to progress the story] wasn't just 'go to dungeon fight boss get thing,' it was designed with a few extra steps along the way to keep it interesting. the items kept things simple and nothing felt gimmicky or out of place. i liked the way that magic was included in game (as compared to the way it is in Ocarina of Time or a Link to the Past, at least), where it had a bit more focus on it (also the 5th spell was a lot of fun to use). the structure of unlocking the islands one by one was a pretty good way to not feel overwhelmed or go to places that you couldn't do anything with yet. the way that you used the achievements was a little weird at first, it reminded me of most mobile games that give you a rotating list of things to accomplish, but i starting warming up to it pretty early on. the idea of items that would refill your stuff after you ran out was pretty good, but potions that could be used on command and filled more than one heart would be good- while it is appreciated, you get the cure spell too late in the game imo. the character animations could have used a bit more polish on them, and i think some of the puzzles would have been a little better it were more obvious where you couldnt push things.

TL;DR a good game, a lot like zelda except a bit watered down. 8.5/10
looking forward to the sequel!

27669357.review:
Most people will buy this game because they think its very close to Zelda - and they are right!
I you liked [b]The Legend of Zelda - Windwaker[/b], Oceanhorn is definitely a game for you.
As you progress though the game more and more items are found, and you are temped to revisit earlier areas with these new items.
Although there are a lot of puzzles, they aren't as amazing a Nintendo's originals.
Another downside of this game is that it doesn't explain how to use a new item. (As with zelda, you get a new item in a dungeon and the puzzles onward show you what you can do with it).
Then there is the fishing part: This minigame is HUGE downside of the game.
You are supposed to cast your fishing rod into water, wait for the swimmer to be pulled under water to start the minigame. Then you have to keep the fish centered in the screen by pulling it left and right. At the bottom of the screen is a display of the fish's stamina, which is really hard to drain and even can regenerate. Most of the time you try to catch the fish for a couple of minutes until it eventually escapes...

To sum up: Oceanhorn is a well made Zelda clone with a few downsides, but definitely worth buying if you are a Zelda fan!

26404786.review:
Oceanhorn is a mediocre isometric Zelda Clone that was initially released for tablets.  The controls, production values and graphics are surprisingly good considering that fact, but the game is pretty wholly style-over-substance and limited by isometric view and tablet technology alike- and it's afraid to be ambitious and challenge the format as well.

Why isn't it recommended?  Well, you've got a lot of other choices for better zelda clones, for one.  For two, although they put in the work to render this playable with a 360 controller, the controls are going to feel weird for the whole of the game.  Lastly... well, there's just no ambition, original ideas or spark, here.  They made a damn fine tablet zelda clone, and that's kind of it.  The occasional voice acting isn't bad (although it sounds like the same guy each time) but it can't save the world's blandest adventure.  In addition, the hit detection is kind of poor and your character is ploddingly slow (limited running doesn't help, either)

If you buy this you won't be wasting 20 bucks, but you can do better.  I can't recommend it.

26040647.review:
There´s no denying this is a Zelda rip-off. If you re-skinned it could certainly pass for a handheld iteration of the franchise. It´s got heart pieces, dungeon with small keys and boss keys, dungeon items/spell as you progress, collecting powerful ancient artifacts necessary to defeat/reach the final boss. The question is, if it was  a Zelda, would it be a good one? Not really. Would it still be enjoyable? Hell yeah!

[spoiler]Come on: starting off as a kid with no parents, sailing a boat through different islands (wind waker), a city in the sky (SS, TP), "mirror shield", an ancient powerful sword, Zoras and Ritos, bombs, arrows, scripted boss fights...[/spoiler]

As far as "Zelda rip-offs" go, this was the best I´ve ever played. It keeps the light and colorful tone that makes you fell comfortable while playing it. The controls and gameplay are not particularly good, but you must consider this was originally a mobile game, and as far as gameplay goes when fighting enemies it doesn´t go far from what you'd expect in the handheld iterations.

Is does lack in story, though. Very simple plot, although there is a lore to the game.

Also, there isn´t really an open world, you sail from island to island without controlling a boat except for a "minigame" in which you shoot enemies and crates in the sea. I wish there was some sort of fast travel option, at least to know places, to skip this sailing bit.

The graphics are not particularly good, but the artwork and direction are very nice, there´s a pleasant atmosphere throughout the gameplay, and the soundtrack is just fantastic. Many developers don´t give the proper dedication to the soundtrack, and is this case it was one the things that made this game so enjoyable.

In the end, it was worth my buck, but it felt more like an experience than a full-fledged game. I was left craving for more. Not more of the same, but a more polished experience, a PC/console focused game, with better dungeons and better controls. Finally, they would do well with abandoning some part of the Zelda formula and risk trying out their own things, try to become a franchise of it´s own, and not just a mere tribute to another game.

It is not quite there yet, but Oceanhorn has what it takes to become the non-nintendo, multi platform Zelda we always craved for, and I have big expectations for the next installment of the series.

26024680.review:
Oceanhorn is a Zelda-like game. I mean really Zelda-like. As in it doesn't add enough anything new but just takes pretty much everything from Zelda. Some might see this as a bad thing and some as good. The game could've been way better if it did something new mechanically.

There isn't enough enemy variety. Couple hours in you've seen almost every monster in the game.

I just can't think enough what to say about this game. Bomb walls, hop from another rock to another. Collect bloodstones. Those btw you just need to whack like 30 hits. At first I just didn't think you could get them. Oh and the hopping from stone to stone.  You get this upgrade like halfway in the game and you've seen those out of reach stones from all the way in the first area. Lots of backtracking with just one upgrade seems a bit silly personally.

The dungeons are pretty much copy pasta from Zelda. Do the puzzles, get normal keys for doors. Get the Master key for the big chest and boss room.

I guess the only difference I can think of is the challenges in the game and level ups. Though the level ups are pretty much what you would unlock in Zelda by getting a new quiver etc. Though in this game the bombs and arrows are really strong and you should use them againts enemies whenever you can.

I don't think the game is bad but it doesn't do anything new, but I did enjoy it just for the Zelda nostalgia.

If you see it on a sale, you could buy it I guess.

25415778.review:
TL:DR A pleasant Zelda clone that isnt too challenging but still makes for an enjoyable game. Worth picking up on sale.

Full Version:
Went in to this game with pretty low expectations, as its a mobile port, and was pleasantly surprised to find a pretty decent game that I enjoyed. Oceanhorn is the closest you'll come to a Zelda game on PC until Nintendo decide to release games on PC. It is very similar to Wind Waker and Phantom Hourglass to the point of almost verging on copyright infringement. 

The story has you as a young boy whos father goes to fight Oceanhorn, a giant ancient mechanical creature that has been terrorizing the world. You travel around different islands discovering weapons and other stuff that while help you face it. The game is a little too easy and more on the casual spectrum of gaming but it still provides a pleasant few hours of gaming.

Good points:
- For a mobile game ported to PC, they've done a pretty good job of this. Rather then lazily porting it to PC like a lot of other mobile games, they have put in that extra effort to make it enjoyable on PC and it shows. The games graphics look quite nice and has controller support.
- This game copies a lot from the Zelda games but in a good way. It manages to capture the elements that makes those games so great.
-Theres a lot of extras to explore if you choose and they've done a good job in making those optional stuff fun instead of feeling like filler.

Bad Points:
- Combat is pretty basic and mostly involves just rotating between blocking and striking enemies.
- The game is a bit too easy, even the bosses dont provide much challenge.

25162017.review:
TL;DR: Are you a fan of Zelda? OF COURSE YOU ARE. So buy this game and don't look back.

Personally, the Zelda series is incredibly important to me. Every time I load up a new Zelda game, it feels like coming home. OoT was my first, and I have played almost every single iteration of Zelda ever. I buy the newest Nintendo consoles JUST to play the newest Zelda games. Not even kidding.

I have much longed for anything else to even come close to touching on what Zelda is. And while Oceanhorn does not, of course, replace our favorite silent protagonist, it holds enough similarity that I felt immediately and intimately familiar with its world.

Oceanhorn is semi-open world; you can explore most of the islands at your leisure, but many will require certain abilities or items to get to 100%. You will not be able to 100% some islands when you first visit them, and I actually appreciate this; that would make it far too linear.

The gameplay and, I would argue, the plot as well, are comfortably familiar. You play a young male protagonist known as the Kid, who is not silent; he awakes on an island, must acquire his father's sword and shield, and proceed on a quest to save his homeland.

Admittedly, the storyline itself is rather short, with no real sidequests except acquiring a couple of optional but helpful spells, getting more hearts via heart pieces/containers, catching a few fish, and acquiring 100%. I also felt that the voice acting, while good by itself, was a bit odd; the animations never matched up, and many of the characters' voices were really off for their appearance (most notably the Kid, whose voice was the deep timbre of a man two or three times the age he appeared to be).

Nevertheless, I found myself charmed as I traipsed through Arcadia, collecting Bloodstones and Heart Piees and dodge-rolling through enemies to strike at weak points or evade their giant swords from cleaving the Kid in two. Being originally a mobile game, it doesn't have a huge depth to combat, but it was super fun regardless. I thought most of the puzzles incredibly easy but (almost) never tedious, and there were even one or two puzzles that took me awhile to figure out - which is a HUGE bonus, as someone who loves to have their brain wracked by difficult puzzles (but not by stupidly and pointlessly illogical puzles, looking at you many point and clickers).

I hope that Oceanhorn receives a sequel, one that expands even further upon the game, ups the ante, adds more depth and complexity. Features of future games that would, in my (not so humble) opinion, appeal to the masses: being built for PC or console or both to have greater depth to controls such as combat; deep and meaningful sidequests; more items, spells, collectables, optional items, monsters, etc; larger and more vast world, populated with interesting characters and fulfilling exploration; a larger variety of puzzles requiring items, spells, and lateral or abstract thinking. I'd also love to see more easily-missed secrets added in, especially ones that elude to the lore of the ancient Arcadians or even of other civilizations.

Well now it looks like I'm waiting for the sequel to this as well as Zelda Breath of the Wild. And isn't that inredible! :)

24852126.review:
Quick Summary: Action RPG that is VERY similar to the old Super Nintendo game Legend of Zelda, Link to the Past. Despite looking like a 3D game, you can’t jump in this game, so you’re relying on ladders and stairs to climb between floors. Fighting is not the core of this game, so I wouldn’t really call it a hack and slash. Oceanhorn is a port of a mobile game, which is why gameplay is so simplistic, but it’s fun nonetheless.

You play an unnamed kid whose father has left to defeat the legendary monster Oceanhorn. Recovering your father’s sword and shield, you decide to follow in his footsteps, exploring the wide seas, “unlocking” islands by hearing about them from NPCs you encounter or reading about them in notes found on other islands. Each island you explore has its own quests, treasures, and challenges, until you’re ready to take on the beast Oceanhorn for yourself. 

I mentioned that the game is similar to Legend of Zelda, and frankly there are so many similarities that I’m surprised the developers weren’t sued for copyright infringement. There’s a “special sword” that shoots projectiles if you’re at full health, bombs to open secret passages, reflecting lasers with a mirror shield, fire and ice spells, a charged up whirling sword slash, breaking jars and cutting grass for item drops, collecting “heart pieces” to increase your max health, regular and master keys for dungeons, and so much more that you’ll recognize if you’re a veteran of Zelda games. 

Pros:
+If you like Zelda games, you should enjoy this one. The puzzles aren’t too difficult, and the game itself is rather casual, as you’d expect from a mobile port. Except that the game takes about 10 hours to complete.
+The graphics are stylishly cartoony, closer to Team Fortress 2 than Diablo, and it runs pretty well on my 6 year old computer. 

Cons:
-While each individual island and puzzle is not too difficult, overall you will be asking “where do I go next” a lot. This is the biggest drawback of the game as far as I’m concerned.  The game doesn’t have a good “map” function showing your quest objective, and some of the instructions from NPCs are quite vague. 
-The fishing minigame is annoying as hell, and doesn’t really give you much, but if you want those Steam achievements, you have to endure it. Note that this is one of those Steam games where you can get 100% achievements if you follow a guide. There’s no “hard mode” that you need to beat, just those damn fish need to be caught.

Overall, Oceanhorn is a decent game that you can finish over a weekend and then never think about again. I don’t regret taking the time to play it, but I don’t think I’ll play it again afterwards since there’s nothing really special about it.
