24789511.review:
Overall the game wasn't terrible, but not good enough for me to recommend to anyone unless you get it for 99 cents or in a Humble Bundle like I did. I had my eye on the game previously because of its clear inspiration from Legend of Zelda, and some of the game's odes to the classic series were enjoyable. As a mobile game ported to PC, the controls are kind of janky at times, especially spell targeting. The boat travel was extremely boring and tedious, and disabled any exploration on the open sea (which was my favorite part of Wind Waker). 

The end boss might have been the most frustrating, janky mechanics I have ever seen. [spoiler] The first phase you are supposed to use your shield to deflect light beams onto its legs, but about 90% of the time it just bugged out and never registered. Either I wasn't able to block the beam for some reason, or it would hit the boss and wouldn't register it was hitting him. I finally figured out you can just use arrows+bombs instead, although much more difficult as you will always take damage from his beam trying to do so. This part alone took me a good part of an hour to finally beat. Then the second phase you have to somehow realize that a flute you picked up JUST BEFORE fighting the boss is necessary to just autowin after a short fight against the main antagonist. Talk about cruddy design.[/spoiler] One of my least favorite boss fights in recent memory. 

The story was extremely mediocre and pretty much did nothing for me. I ended up just skipping cutscenes because I found myself not caring at all what was going on in the story. Overall, it was a dissapointing venture. If it was a $0.99 mobile game on the app store, I would say sure give it a go. But the PC port for $15? Not worth the time or effort.

24756259.review:
Since this game was originally designed for mobile, it's important to look at it two ways. both as just a game, and as a port. Before either of those, I'd like to say, as an indie developed game, and as a mobile developed game, there are definitely worse choices out there.

However, as a port, the controls are extremely frustrating as something on PC. The controls are remappable, but use, and run are mapped to the same button. This doesn't even make sense with the controller, as the game still leaves 3 buttons, all on the shoulder open. Eventually, I did get a controller, and that made this game a lot less frustrating. In other words, if you're going to play this game, do it with a controller. It's a lot less frustrating.

As a game on Steam, this is just awful. Sound and graphics are nice, barely above average, but gameplay and story wise, it's awful. It's obvious, if not immediately, as the game goes on that it was heavily inspired by Legend of Zelda:

You have a voiceless character who's father figure goes out to fight the big bad, and then fights using, among a sword and shield, which become sword and shield of legend, also fights with bombs, and a bow and arrow. He has a spin attack, and he shoots energy out of his sword when at full health. However, the game seems to miss the point of LoZ. The point was you had a world, and that you were growing in skill, along with your arsenal. You didn't just have a combo and a spin attack, your skills grew and you learned all these maneuvers, and the game rewarded you near the end for knowing these cool attacks.

In this game, you beat the final boss by [spoiler] using a flute you JUST got.[/spoiler] No, I'm not joking. It doesn't matter how many cycles you go through in the final fight, you just do a little trick, that's really not hard, you just don't know you're supposed to do it, and the game doesn't even suggest that you should do it, but you do it because why not and it works, and you want to mash your face against the keyboard.

There were so many little things that I wanted to turn off the game for, but it made up for it with these little nuggets of fun: fighting is generally fun, and I honestly can't remember another time I had fun with this game. There are walls to blow up, like in LoZ, another similarity, but this time, you don't get any tips on when or where to do that, which seems to be a trend for this game. The sailing is totally worthless. The original point in LoZ: WW was for you to sail the seas, with only a map and compass to show where you have and haven't been. Here, they put you on a rail shooter, because god forbid they put something fun in this game. 

Also, why, why, why did they put fishing in here. It's not fun. At all. And the worst perpetrator of this is the horrible robot fish that kills you if you don't hurry up and win.

Oh yeah, and the story is garbage. Doesn't make any sense, and the game doesn't try to make sense of it, except this huge info dump your dad(uncle?) drops on you after you beat the boss, in the stupidest way imaginable.

Honestly, i wanted to like this game. Originally, I couldn't run it that well, so when I upgraded my PC, I played the game again, and tried to have fun. But with the shallow, lifeless characters, and the convoluted, unexplained plot, it feels like a campy 60's movie turned into a video game. What is the Oceanhorn? Why didn't my dad go pick up all these weapons that I'm using? [spoiler]*Why did the flute he brought with him become the key in beating the Oceanhorn???* ***WHY??***[/spoiler]

In short, don't buy this game for full price, it's not worth 15$, or even 7.50$, in my book. And try to avoid playing it without a controller.

24626081.review:
This game is a tribute/love letter to the Legend of Zelda series. The way they reference certain 'tropes' that can be expected of Zelda games, I think, was well done. For example, collect the three sacred things in the three differently themed areas, that assemble into one magical thing so you can fight the big bad. The story itself (while not extremely involved or creative) is somewhat original as opposed to lifted from the Zelda series. Many of the cinematic scenes had pretty good voice acting, which I didn't expect at all.

However, most of the game was pretty subpar and in all honesty feels like a fancied up mobile game. The movement and controls were slow and clunky both with kb+m and controller. There is no button to view the map, so you have to work with the mini-map the entire game, including on dungeons with multiple floors. The sailing is completely on rails and unnecessary because there's no real threat and it only takes about 30 seconds. You can't have more than one item equipped at once so switching is a constant. Rather than have sidequests to add depth, there's an odd level up system for extra items + upgrades, which is tied to the achievement system. But most importantly, it's just not all that fun, with most enemies not presenting much challenge (apart from maybe mechanically because of control issues,) and not much actual meat on this platter.

The game also has autosave and no manual save option. This meant, when I loaded my save back up to try to get the stuff I was missing (I hit 82%), I soon discovered that I was automatically dumped into a room that existed between the final boss's two stages with no possible exit. So if you DO decide to get this game, and care to complete it, don't even go near the final area until you've gotten everything else done.

Overall I had too many problems with this game to fairly recommend it to anyone.

Edit: It's been 2 years since I wrote the original review, and the game is still $15 at full price. I considered changing this review to say it was maybe worth a try assuming it would be lower by now, but once again I find myself disappointed.

After trying a dozen times to beat this boss, I'm giving up.

I have nothing against a challenge, but I'd much rather feel like I'm fighting the boss and not the camera or the controls.

The game's obviously a love letter to zelda games.  It shows.  A lot.  And there's nothing wrong with that.

But once I get past the nostalgia, it's a very frustrating, tedious game.  Controls feel very "floaty" and unresponsive.  Half the time when I try to aim at an enemy, the main character is a sharpshooter.  The other half of the time, he can't hit the broad side of a barn and will just fling pots and arrows with wild abandon into the horizon like a drunken idiot.

Doorways have unnaturally large hitboxes.  I've unwillingly exited rooms while trying to go pick things up.

And then there's just baffling design choices like filling a dungeon with firebats that can only be harmed by a specific ice spell that you only have enough magic to cast twice.  The rest of the time is just running and being lit on fire half a screen away.

Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a RPG Advemture  game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]


There are many languages available.
You are able to play this game in fullscreen mode, Windowed mode or borderless mode.
It has many resolution sizes.
You are able to play on your controller.
Able to change your controls on the keyboard and controller. (Partially)
Game has multiple save slots.
You are able to change the Music, Voice and Sound with a slidebar. But you are only able to do this during the game.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

The game reminds me from "Legend of zelda", many things from this and Zelda games are the same. Like Collecting the heart pieces, "Dashing", The item selection at the top right, The inventory Menu and so go on. You are playing with a character that needs to retrieve his sword and shield from his dad. On the way you will find some coins and obstacles. You will see some grass that you are able to destroy and throw some vases and pots. Entering a new area will respawn all pots and enemies again. You can jump down ledges and small hills, but for some reason you can't climb up and so you will have to walk all around it again. You will see checkpoints which will respawn you back on those locations if you have died and the game will be automatically saved here.

A log from the last actions (like from reading signs).
Has challenges and completing them will give you more experience.
Levelling up will give you some coins and refill all of your hearts.
Great graphics! Great scenery! Great music!
Ingame tutorial.
Your character has a stamina bar.
The text has subtitles.
The game is voiced over.
Checkpoints that will automatically save your game and respawn you back.
Has a minimap where items and enemies are revealed.
Alt-tabbing pauses the cutscenes automatically.
Able to skip cutscenes with the Spacebar.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Sometimes alt-tabbing makes the game windowed mode instead of staying at the Fullscreen mode.
Has Legend of Zelda gamestyle.

-------------------

I Give this game a 8/10

Lo primero señalar que este juego lo adquirí en un bundle tirado de precio, aunque lo conocía con anterioridad por que fue uno de esos escasos "pelotazos" a nivel de ventas de juegos desconocidos, con la dificultad añadida de ser en las tiendas de las plataformas moviles.

Es imposible negar que desde el primer momento, este juego "bebe" muchisimo del Zelda Wind Waker de GameCube, no tanto a nivel de desarrollo (que también), sino especialmente a nivel estético. Esto que podría ser criticable, en mi caso no es más que un aliciente a jugarlo, ya que el Wind Waker, con sus debilidades, no deja de ser un juego que me encantó en su momento.

Aun así, el principal aliciente para avanzar por la aventura que propone el juego es encontrar el camino adecuado explorando las islas y jugando con las distintas alturas del terreno, de un modo que me ha recordado a un juego de hace muchísimo tiempo, el Little Big Adventure, al que tambien se parece en su combate simplificado hasta el extremo (quizás incluso demasiado).

En resumen, estamos hablando de una aventura entretenida (aunque no supone en ningún momento un reto) y con una apariencia agradable (aunque teniendo en cuenta de las plataformas a las que pertenece) que te llevará unas diez horas terminarla.

23693319.review:
For me these are the pros:

1. Atmosphere.
Indeed, it is not a legendary story which chains you down from dusk till dawn. But it has a certain calmness, a bit like being the main protagonist of those old tales which are were read to children from big old books.

2. Simplicity and still fun.
There is nothing complicated things in this game (maybe some puzzles?), but not a lot of skill points, inventory management, item augmentations, alchemy etc.  In spite of this still offers a decent relaxation.

3. Graphics.
I don't want to say that it has some uber hardcore graphics, but it has it's own "bright" style, which is kind of a refreshing after playing 200 hours of survival horror.

Cons: 
I really can't say anything really bad about this game. But if you are the person who needs some legendary stuff, and to feel feel like a mighty warrior or fearful mage, please avoid this game. :) 

As a summary: I really recommend this game to those who can enjoy a game without the urge to compare to other BIG titles in the industry.

23668822.review:
This game is not bad, but neither is it great. I like it, that’s it. 
I searched for a Zelda-like game, and that is exactly what I got. The similarities are, to me, pretty ridiculous and funny. The developers haven’t even tried hiding what they were trying to create. 

I like the storyteller mode, adventure, the openworld and the puzzles that aren’t hard enough. But it gets pretty repetitive, yet rather addicting. I don’t feel like I’ve wasted my money, since I bought it on sale for about 4$. It’s cheap entertainment. If you like the idea of Zelda, but think the games are too hard, this is the game for you.

As the Zelda-fanatic I am, I can’t shake the feeling of this being a total windwaker rip-off, and it pains me a bit. Even if the game has some of its own features. I give it 6,5/10 and I recommend this game.

Oceanhorn: Moster of Uncharted Seas is reminiscent of the Legend of Zelda series. A silent hero sets out on a epic quest to find his father and defeat the monster known as Oceanhorn. This quest will take the player across various islands. The boss fights are fun. The art style and story of the game are praiseworthy. 

Whilst the game borrows aspects from the Legend of Zelda series, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas adds their own mechanics and twists to the game.For example, the game incorporates a leveling mechanic. Players can level up the hero by completing the story, compeleting challenges. and killing monsters. The game also includes a fishing mechanic with leaderboard stats. 

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a brilliant game that is highly recommended for action adventure fans as well as fans of the Legend of Zelda series.

23478131.review:
Huh... I really tried liking this game. It's an ode to The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker, which is pretty much the only Zelda I haven't played (much).

It just... Feel too much like a rip-off. Puzzles are complete jokes, combat is kind of awkward, the whole experience mechanic feels like an afterthought far from well thought, and the whole blocky-style make the game feel very restrictive at time, especially since you can't jump if it's two block high... Except in certain places, which makes it far from consistent.

So many things that makes Zelda a fun game (series) are missing from it. Almost no important NPCs, there's no special sound for breakable walls, and most of the things are far from intuitive, which made me looks at a walkthrough every hour or so.

Graphics are really nice, but that's only when you see them from afar, like in all those screenshot. In cutscenes, we get close-up of the characters and objects, and everything looks really bad. (Like at 2:10 in the video)

The story feel forced and generic, and that's without talking about the character who like my character way too much for absolutely no reasons. I just really like one or two story choices, but those were things appearing near the end of the game, huh.

At least sounds and musics are really nice, which make the thing at least a bit enjoyable.

While trying to be it's own thing, Oceanhorn ends up being in the shadow of Zelda. 
In the end, it feels more like a rip-off of Zelda, trying to market to those fans who wants games like them on PC, and on mobile. (Since this is actually a mobile port, even if it plays well with a controller, or only a keyboard.)

If you're looking for a Zelda clone, try Ittle Dew, Bit Dungeon II, the Ys series, Secrets of Grindea, or even Darksiders.

An RPG/Adventure game clearly inspired by the Zelda series.

It's got a nice storyline to it which will have you traveling between plenty of islands although each area feels somewhat short.
The majority of the game is fairly simple and straight forwards, puzzles that aren't that difficult or puzzling also they're not that varied as most of them involve pushing boxes, pressing buttons and using bombs or arrows.

There's a nice levelling system which unlocks extra features or improvements, killing monsters and completing challenges gives you xp.

The graphics are okay but there's a few questionable glitches such as solid objects shaking around when you hit then and floating objects. Otherwise it's a pretty solid game.
I never encounter any bugs or something which stopped me progressing and was able to get 100% achievements and exploration in game without any trouble.

There's no reply value unless you wish to get all achievements and missed some your first time round, the game is short but the challenges can add extra time if you wish to go for them but their only reward is the XP which will help level up much faster which will help you out.
There's a fishing system, there's no benefits for using it but it's got a leader board for the biggest fish if you wish to compete with other players however it's repetitive and tedious.

Overall the game is enjoyable and worth getting if you like Zelda or similar games but you may wish to wait for a sale due to its length and simplicity.

23278079.review:
I feel like I would absolutely love this game if it had a little more polish. It's got some really good Zelda-esque aspects in here with the music being beautiful and all the people charming. But then it leaves out some really crucial Zelda-esque things (and I mean if you're going to go for it, go all the way). 

The good: 
+ Artstyle
+ Music
+ Story
+ Inventory/Item switching

The Bad:
- Movement controls are a bit sloppy
- Boss battles are boring
- There are unfixed glitches in the game that can really mess up your progress (for example, there was a boss that I could routinely get down to zero health and who wouldn't die. He would just fly around the boss room until I got impatient and let him kill me).
- The game is often vague on what to do and not in a "here is a puzzle to solve" way, but in a "you can find one of the most useful rings in dark souls by climbing out a hidden tower and these ruins that don't look climbable, so you can go back to this area you didn't think you could get back to with no real markers or hints beyond a crow watching you" way. 
- It has the FF8 syndrome where you can get locked into a village with no way to level, get more hearts, get better weapons, etc. And you can't get off that island until you beat a boss. That glitchy boss I mentioned before. It sucked.

There is just barely enough for me to recommend this game and a lot of the good will it had built up was destroyed by the that stupid boss glitch. If you're looking for a Zelda-esque adventure on PC that reminds you of Windwaker without all the sailing, but with more boring enemies? This is your game.

23234570.review:
Gameplay: 8/10
Visuals: 7/10
Audio: 6/10

This is a Zelda-like that was originally made for iOS and then ported over to the PC. Whoever ported it did a good job at making it run well on computer as well as setting up controls for a gamepad. The world is comprised of islands that you must sail between in order to get different items. There are three dungeons; in which you must collect magic emblems in order to defeat a grand mechanical beast called Oceanhorn.

Upsides:
- A cute cartoony style.
- Good enemy design.
- Doesn't over-explain everything to you. You have to explore and find out how to play the game.
- Once I got into the right moodset for solving puzzles there is an island later on in the game called the Island of Whispers and it has incredibly well designed puzzles and atmosphere.

Downsides:
- Boring on-rails sailing between islands.
- Some of the sounds are really annoying (like when landing from a drop).
- There is a spell that allows you to drop a random item onto buttons to press them, but it doesn't do anything outside of the first dungeon. There are so many times where I thought that would be a great solution to an area, being able to press a button from far away, but they instead introduce a mechanic that is never used again.
- Horrendously frustrating fishing mini-game. I really don't know why developers put these in they're never good.


Verdict - Great game with some minor flaws. Heavily recommend to anyone craving a Zelda-like on the pc.

First of all, I have to say that this is not a bad game, but it is not that good either, and it is not worth it for its 15 €/$ price unless you get it very cheap on a sale. Since there are few Zelda clones, this game became quite overrated by many people (maybe by fans of the Zelda franchise). Don't be fooled by this Zelda clone.

As many others have stated before, Oceanhorn is boring, excessively repetitive, and it just copies the worst of the worst of Zelda games. The puzzles are always the same, lazy puzzles with no innovation: pushing blocks and pressing switches. Some "puzzles" are illogical and make no sense: sometimes you are stuck and you are expected to put a bomb on some wall which is not cracked and seems like a normal wall (how the hell is one supposed to guess that without reading a walkthrough?). The battle sistem is repetive since the enemies are the typical ones (again, no innovation), and the hero moves quite slow. The graphics are cool (it is probably the only good thing of this game). IMHO, the story is boring. Of course, the NPCs of the game have zero charisma and no charm, as the game itself.

To summarize, Oceanhorn is a very boring game, with cool graphics but with bad puzzles, bad combat system, bad story, and no innovation. This is just the opposite of a good Zelda-like game, recommended only for casual gamers that do not expect too much of a game.

22987349.review:
My ultimate slant is about 6.5/10.  I lean more towards recommending it on the basis that it is at least a very good casual game that would probably keep younger gamers busy -- around 8-12.  For harder core gamers, it is a little too oversimplified.

The game has a very slick visual style (a couple of the monster models withstanding, such as the bird-like enemy) and the graphics run famously at maximum settings on my overclocked 2012 PC (3.4 GHz Intel i3570k tuned to 4.0 GHz clock) with a 2015 graphics card (Radeon R9 X290 OC).  It is gorgeously presented and utterly beautiful.  The reflections from the surface of the water are sublime and the environments are truly immersive.

The gameplay, on the other hand, doesn't live up.  Combat involves almost no manoeuvre and is a slog between holding down the block key and hammering the attack button.  From time to time it can be strategic to let go of the block key and dash away, although this is more often rewarded with an enemy stabbing you in the back than with any actual benefit to your character that it is usually meaningless to try.  When you unlock magic spells, you gain a moderate cost "magic missile" spell that never misses its target; enemies have almost no personality other than the size of their hit meter and how long it takes to hurt them.  The most inventive enemy in the game is one with a mask which can only be knocked off with this spell or by throwing an object at them.  The others are, more or less, simply hit point meters that walk.  This is made even worse by the fact that their AI is almost nonsense: they will either lock onto you and blithely pursue you, or will suddenly and arbitrarily go back into unaggressive wandering behaviour.  (If they wanted to create a morality play where I feel remorse for haplessly slaughtering non-hostile creatures, they succeeded there, at least. =))

To coin a phrase, it has a "none with a but" style.  None of the monsters are well-designed, [i]but[/i] one of them is.  None of the puzzles are difficult, [i]but[/i] one is.  None of the combat conveys a sense of danger, [i]but[/i] the ogres do the first time.

Controls are a bit twitchy, since the mouse controls your point of aim and is often relative to your character instead of relative to the position it is on the screen.  (This part might be better with a gamepad.)  The game doesn't have the responsiveness of a purebred action-adventure game and is really more of a pure adventure game with interactive combat.  For instance, once you unlock the bow, trying to shoot a flying enemy that is south-southeast of you will result in many wasted arrows.  There is no first person aiming and thus no ability to carefully choose your target -- your arrows are auto-aimed to a rather ridiculous degree at times, especially as the threshold for where the auto-aim kicks in seems to be unreliable.  There is no locking-on of targets to specify which one you would truly prefer to attack.

The game appears to be remarkably short (I figure I'm at least a third of the way through after 4 hours of play), made longer only by grueling semi-interactive travel sequences.  Where the game with a very similar visual style would allow you to control your boat, this game is oriented more for auto-piloted navigation.  Your first travels between islands are pointless as there is no user interaction whatsoever, and could just as easily had been done away with entirely.  That they were included at all implies that the game was trying very hard to emulate another.  After your first travels, your character unlocks an ability that does unlock interactivity during the boat travel, but all it does is turn the boat travel into a tablet-like point-and-shoot minigame which has extremely little variety while your boat still travels on auto-pilot.

Unfortunately the slick visual presentation is the only shellac over top of a samey plot and astoundingly shallow character interactions.  The characters completely fail to motivate the player: they are entities in a world in the same sense that a psychopath might view people walking down the street.  For instance, there is an implied romantic attraction between your character and another about 25% of the way through the game, with absolutely [i]zero[/i] exposition or setup as to why.  Even Miyamoto's games, with no more than a couple dozen lines per character, managed to express emotional attraction -- this does not.  I literally put my face in my palm for this one.  Literally.  I barely watched the cutscene through my fingers while shaking my head and laughing.  The only character I felt a genuine sympathy for was the "last of the Owrus", after visiting a grave nearby his house after reading the sign in front of the house -- the best example of "show don't tell" story writing, which (most of) the rest of the game sadly missed the ball on.  The game does express a hint of poignance in the bleak backstory now and then, but there is too little exposition for it to be more than fleeting.

The puzzles are very simplistic.  Never once did I have to pause for more than a second to figure anything out.  For instance, avoiding any spoilers, the supposedly cryptic messages that talk about gaining a particular item from a green chest are obvious exactly what that item is.  The only time I ever got "stuck" in the game is because I failed to notice that I could blow up a single barricade on the desert island at the very beginning, and even then I figured it out simply by double-checking the areas accessible to me and testing areas for vulnerabilities.  One of the puzzles later on in the game, en route to collecting the shield, is quite obvious in intent and solution and made frustrating only by the clunkiness of the movement and aim controls, including a need to quickly and precisely target two sword swings and a spell as well as several jumps.  Perhaps a gamepad would have served me better here too.

With all of those negatives, you would assume that I absolutely hated the game, but the game is well presented enough that, chore of gameplay aside, it is strangely compelling.  The music is utterly fantastic.  The game manages to capture "fun" without actually being particularly well done, and that is remarkable on its own.  It is a gorgeous romp through varied locations and all extremely atmospheric, even if all are extraordinarily short.  The voice acting is phenomenal and incredibly professionally done (not sure what VAs the other reviewers are listening to, but mine were great ;-)), although the characters are so one-or-two dimensional that it is difficult to develop any particular attachment.  There isn't enough of character interaction to make the world come truly alive, but it is certainly alive enough to watch as an external viewer: peering through the looking glass without ever deciding to step all the way into the rabbit hole.

An advanced gamer will probably turn their nose up at it, but it would definitely be something you could point a child at for mindless fun.

22973575.review:
[h1][b]The Legend of Oceanhorn[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]Full Review at [url=http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=148]GameDragons.Net[/url][/b][/h1]

[b]Presentation[/b]
The premise behind Oceanhorn's story is something you have probably seen a hundred times before, as the story kicks off with the hero's father leaving to save the world, only to put you in control of the hero with a quest to find your father and help him defeat Oceanhorn moments after. From there onward you'll experience an entire Zelda-like adventure, looking for the location and a way to defeat Oceanhorn and rescue your father. There is always something new to discover, but Oceanhorn's biggest miss is when you realize that all your discovery excitement that builds up as you move forward quickly goes back to zero once you realize that there are few things to experience besides the main story. There are sixteen different islands to visit, mostly serving as an essential part to the storyline, but only a few of those have gameplay value to encourage a full exploration such as Tikarel which serves as the main town where you can buy items and take on new quests. 

Unfortunately, the rest of many are only a one-time visit deal, as you can finish everything there is to see and experience in less than 15 minutes and never return to that island again. There are some activities such as finishing and completing the different challenges that might add a bit of variety, but even those feel repetitive and pretty basic to any RPG. The story itself has nothing much to offer as you can probably guess how it's all going to end from the very beginning, but nevertheless, the journey all the way to the final island is an enjoyable ride if you're willing to look past the repetitiveness and basic concepts.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Not only does Oceanhorn feel like a Zelda game, but it plays like one too; if you have played a Zelda game before the formula will seem very familiar to you: make your way to that dungeon, defeat the boss in order to obtain the item you need, return to town to gather more information about your next quest and repeat until you get to the end. Navigation is done via a Wind Waker-like boat mechanic that allows you to travel from one island to the next one using your boat, but there are very few things to do on sea, as the only thing to keep you preoccupied while you reach your next destination are the barrels and mines that randomly pop in front of you as you sail, but after a while, even those start to become more annoying than fun, as the whole concept becomes repetitive and unrewarding. 

On land, the gameplay is pretty basic, as you only have a few spells at your disposal and your sword attacks, but once you realize that some spells are only useful once for the boss battle that they were designed for, the whole adventure will only become more and more repetitive. There are only a few enemies that you will encounter throughout your adventures, most of which can be defeated with basic sword attacks that require no strategy at all, while the boss battles vary in quality, as some of them feel intelligent and rewarding, while others are just a very long game of poke-poke-hit. Apart from the main quest itself, there are few things to keep you occupied in your adventures and while locating all of the bloodstones feels rewarding in the end, that reward will probably come in too late as you would've already finished the game by then.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Noting the fact that Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas was originally an iOS game, it did make its transition to PC and consoles quite well, as the game does look beautiful on the big screen, but don't expect anything breathtaking, as even with an upscaled resolution the game still lacks the details a console or PC game would have. The design is basic, and there are only a few environments that vary from one island to another, but for most parts the world around you looks pretty similar no matter where you are. The animations could use a bit more work and the characters a bit more detail, but overall as a top-down RPG, Oceanhorn has enough to keep your hero on track.

[b]Audio[/b]
There are some great tunes in here, and if you didn't know different you could say there were in the soundtrack of a Zelda game, but they do start repeating after a while and it does make it boring listening to the same thing all over again. The effects are enough to justify the means, but the voice acting is absent, not that the game would necessarily need it since the quests instructions are pretty clearly delivered via text dialogue, but it would've been nice to have that option, at least for the main cutscenes to make the whole missing father story more personal.

[b]Extras[/b]
You can finish the whole game within 10 hours, add a few more if you're willing to revisit every island in order to gather all the bloodstones and complete all the challenges, but that's pretty much all of it, and since some skills are required to access a few areas, you can't complete everything in your visit visit, so you will have to deal with the repetitiveness of the main story first and then move on to the repetitiveness of the sidequests.

[b]Verdict[/b]
It's impossible to deny the fact that Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a Zelda clone since it feels, plays and looks like a game in the Zelda series, but it's a pretty decent one, so if you liked Zelda and want more of it, Oceanhorn might prove to be an entertaining adventure for you. The game does come with its flaws and lack of content, but in the end it will prove out to be an adventure worth playing.

[u]Rating: 7.1[/u]

The premise of this game is that it is supposed to be like Zelda. It successfully copies the style of Zelda (dungeons, enemies, items, levelling up health and item capacities, etc.) but it doesn't do anything as well as the Zelda games did. It would be foolish to expect them to do that, but it wasn't even close to as satisfying. The puzzles were too easy, the combat was too awkward, and the story just didn't grab me. The game seemed like it would be better if the camera was free or if it was 2D. Moving around just felt wrong in this and a large part of my dissatisfaction in the game came from not being able to see as much as I would have liked which caused the combat and exploration to suffer.

It's more or less good in most regards, but great in none. I would recommend this if you are a fan of the Zelda series, but I wouldn't recommend it otherwise.

22869510.review:
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is an action adventure heavily inspired by The Legend of Zelda. To begin with the story, it's not anything special, so you'll just live with the fact that your father left you to destroy the expanding evil. As a good son, instead of being hateful, you become a powerful knight that will save the world and unite all races, surpassing your father.

But from what exactly you'll have to save the world? Well, from three types of steampunk machines and a possessed living fortress, and few native creatures like trolls or orcs, which also have pretty low variety. Overall, Oceanhorn is limited this way, as you'll meet just few distinct NPCs and beat them with one of two swords, bow, bomb or one of your five spells.

The steam page says it's also an RPG but I think that's overestimated. Even though there is a leveling system, there aren't many character levels and each level up brings you a passive bonus, e.g. increased amount of bombs or arrows you can hold. There isn't any inventory system and even though there is a currency system, you'll save money for later anyway, because only appealing items in shops are the (two) expensive ones. All cheap stuff in shops are arrows, bombs, mana or health refills but you won't need to buy these - anytime you are missing something, the game drops it for you from the next enemy, bush or vase.

Low difficulty is something that really disappointed me. All puzzles are laughably easy and neither the combat is challenging, especially after you claim the second sword. Bosses might seem scary but they are easy too, it's like they want you to win with a single repeating pattern: Do something to stun them, tap your slash button until they stand up, and repeat two more times.

There are height differences on islands but the level design is pretty limited, you can't even jump down the cliff if it's higher than a block. After about 5 hours of playtime, you'll at least learn to roll and jump between blocks close to each other. Anyway, the game holds your hand in most moments so nothing bad can happen to you and if you fail anyway, you just respawn at nearest checkpoint and dead enemies are still dead until you leave the location. The game also have problems with occasional crashes, it crashed every hour in average but it's not a big problem since the game saves your progress often.

It's not complex, it's not hard, so what? Oceanhorn feels like a food for completionists. It has a good amount of achievements and it motivates you to explore all the areas, to find every treasure ([i]even though you know it'll contain useless junk like an old shoe[/i]). There are a lot of secret areas and there's also a well-made challenge system - Each discovered island shows you three new challenges that you can beat anywhere in the game. Those challenges varies from "kill X enemies" through "drown your enemy" to "catch your first fish".

There are two minigames in the game, fishing and sailing between islands. Fishing is completely optional but the sailing, that's something you'll have to do many times... and it's annoying. You set the place to sail to and there are boxes, mines and sea creatures in your way. To get through, you have a gun with unlimited ammo and attack speed - it just shoots everytime you tap the attack button. It's a boring playtime filler where you are just mindlessly shooting everything, that you can't skip.

The colourful graphic design is something that definitely stands up for Oceanhorn in the amount of negative facts around. At least if you don't mind that all characters look like kids. The soundtrack is fine, it contains average positive melodies that you won't mind listening repeatedly, but you forget them immediately after you finish the game. 

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Oceanhorn comes as a disappointment by many features - low variety of everything, poor story, low difficulty, very limited RPG mechanisms. But it has its positives, as it'll make many completionists entertained for being able to explore all the islands with many secrets and challenges. That's why I think it's worth recommending to people seeking relaxing and easy game, just don't expect much from it. If you think 15 € for this is too much, wait for sale - There'll be another one for sure, as it already was in 1 dollar tier of Humble Bundle.

22837741.review:
Oceanhorn is a mixed bag; it's definitely more good than bad, but it's clear that there is a lot of unutilized potential in it's design.

The most notable quality of the game is that it's derivative; of The Legend of Zelda to be specific, though that comparison is drawn quickly and immediately by anyone who has a passing familiarity with the Zelda franchise. Unlike many similar indie designs, Oceanhorn doesn't feel like an homage or a tribute (much in the way that Ittle Dew or Binding of Isaac do) -- instead it feels like a somewhat randomly curated collection of Zelda artifacts, patched together in to... something, without really knowing what all those pieces were meant to do in the first place. While it is an enjoyable playthrough, the game shows its most promise in the rare moments where it isn't trying to shoehorn another Zelda trope in to it's structure.

The story hurts the most of the trouble; many of the characters are direct references to Zelda staples, but they lack any of the history or context of that series, so instead of feeling like they contribute, they just end of feeling hollow or forced; the villain, for example, reads as a Gannon cliche, not as an evil peer. And in an effort to create gravity, many ridiculous plotholes are developed -- we're told that the world is in terrible shape, but we never see it; the Gillmen have been waiting for help for centuries, but it's not clear why they haven't sought help; the Sky Islanders watch everything, but are completely in the dark about anything meaningful (not to mention that they have advanced technology, but couldn't figure out a safe way to get to the ground). Heck, the game even tells you that you're liked in town, and drops a romance in your lap, which is crazy because when it happens you're little more than a pot-smashing drifter in town.

And with all the mirroring between Oceanhorn and the Zelda games, there is an unfavorable light cast on all its rough edges. The camera doesn't really work; there's mismatch between the overwrought dialog and its subtitles on several occasions; there's numerous small glitches and inconsistances that can ruin whatever it is that you're doing. And if Oceanhorn stood on its own, I'd probably be comfortable ignoring all of that; it's just how firmly planted in the shadow of another series the game chose to be that makes these issues pop to the fore.

That all said, it's a reasonable length for a good adventure; it's most tedious parts are either optional or far apart; and the game oozes with a respectible amount of polish. I think the dev team put some serious elbow grease in to brewing this game up, and they realized the concept admirably. They just need to get much further away from their inspiration before they decide to build.

Oceanhorn is HEAVILY inspired from the legend of zelda series, and while that may be a good idea the game fails in its execution. If Steam had a 'meh' option I would probably choose that. 22714741.review:
My playtime: 13:37:36 (100%) based on internal clock.


[h1]Intro[/h1]
Oceanhorn is another Zelda-clone game, although it's implemented differently. Between all Zelda games, this game is more like Phantom Hourglass, with some difference. Although i don't want this review to be Zelda-Oceanhorn comparison, i guess i can mention some similarities and differences between the two. Both games has "sailing" minigame, where you can go to other islands and sail, which there might be some obstacles and enemies that you can shoot along the path, minus the upgradeable ship, pirates, and travelling merchant ship which sells you items and a heart container (however, there is an island who sell the heart container). Both also has tricky puzzle and creative boss battle (only some bosses in Oceanhorn can be considered like that, though).

--
Well, enough blabbering about Zelda, since i want to review this as its own game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Oceanhorn serves you with its outstanding UI at the start. The font and style really matches so well, not to mention a beautiful soundtrack in the beginning. However, i must say that i was quite dissapointed soon after i start the game, because the 3D models isn't as good as the UI. The models look stiff and some facial expression (especially Neeti, a girl in an island) looks weird. The hero always looks angry. I know it's quite hard to make a facial expression, but if you decided to use one face from the start to finish, it better be a bright one. Also, some animations looks weird. One example is on the cutscene when the hero sleeps.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Although i said before that Oceanhorn comes with a beautiful soundtrack in the beginning, i have to say, that i forgot most of the soundtracks in there, or maybe i didn't notice there is a soundtrack at all. The soundtracks are quickly forgotten. There is no difference playing it muted or not. Well, graveyard island might be an exception though, because it's quite creepy.

[h1]Story[/h1]
If you think that Oceanhorn comes with a beautiful and captivating story, you are mistaken. The ending only gives me a "huh?" feeling, since it didn't capture an ending moment perfectly (for those who have played this game, i just didn't like the fact that they are talking normally like nothing happened). The story is already set from the start, with some details in each of the cutscenes. In the middle of the story, they made a pair out of nowhere, and it's not romantic at all, even if they are put together in the night sky watching fireworks. But luckily, cutscenes are skippable and you can rewatch it anytime.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Well, since i said that the models, soundtrack, and story are a no, maybe you are wondering as why would i recommend this game. Simply put, with all the defects, i am still satisfied with the gameplay. Let me elaborate.

[b]There are tons of dungeons and puzzles in this game.[/b] Most puzzles are creative enough to make you think, and there are some collectables which require you to solve some puzzles first. I must admit that i can't solve some puzzle and have to consult a guide somewhere, but it's not to a point where it's frustating enough and you have to see a guide in order to solve all puzzles.

Talking about puzzles, i must say that i was quite mad with the control at the start because you can't jump, only to find out that you can only jump after obtaining an item, which soon disappoints me because of the odd jump mechanism. You can only jump through one gap (you can't jump up and down one level). Also, you will roll if you can't jump, which makes you to really have to go through the corner in order to jump. I ended up stopping and jumping instead of running/walking and jumping because of that, which looks weird.

You can bomb some places to reveal a new path (and it doesn't looks bombable at all). However, it makes me stuck on some point. Although i have bomb the spot before, it didn't collapse, which makes me have to consult a guide to look for a new path, only to find myself to bomb the very same spot.

[b]There are some collectibles in this game.[/b] There are two collectibles, namely heart pieces and bloodstone. You might be wondering at the start on how to collect bloodstones (and it's quite annoying to do once you find out how to), though. There is an item to track bloodstone and although you can't track heart pieces, this game has a completed guide which you can consult to. However, i am quite dissapointed that you have to retrack all the way just to recollect all the collectibles after you can jump because it takes time as the map is quite big and travelling between islands costs time.

[b]Some challenging boss battles.[/b] Although i must say that the final boss is quite dissapointing (it's easier than all the bosses in the game), the others are quite enjoyable. Okay, maybe the first boss is easier because it's similar to a boss in Zelda game (i forgot which), but it's still weird to think that the final boss is super easy if you already know what to do. The other bosses are more creative imo, especially that shadow thingy, because it has two phases. I was expecting the final boss to have something like three phases, but it's only two dissapointing battles.

[b]Minigame[/b]. There is a fishing minigame in this game. Luckily, it's quite easy. You can get the fish you are looking for in less than 5 tries. However, some fish are exclusive in an area and most fishes took quite long to catch. There are some "specials" in some fishes which can make it harder, but overall, it's just the same as catching other fishes.

There is also a minigame where you are traveling between islands. You just need to shoot everything and it's relatively easy though. However, in my opinion, it's taking quite a long time, especially on the "cutscene" when it docks, which can't be skipped.

[b]Challenges[/b]. There are some challenges which is linked to steam achievement and you can unlock it in other island. Sadly, you can't see the achievement list in one go because it's only listed by 3 in every island. Some challenges can be done as you progress the main story and some needs you to grind a little or do a certain trick.


[h1]Conclusions[/h1]
This game is great for casual gamers and can be 100% quickly. The challenges aren't hard and doable.

Should you buy this game?
I would highly recommend you to buy this game when it's on sale, but if you are dying for Zelda games right now, why not just press that Add to Cart button and buy it?

22650985.review:
From top to bottom, a straight up clone of Zelda, but minus all of the charm, intrigue and green attire.

----

+ Excellent Soundtrack

+/- Plenty of secrets and collectables

- Nothing stands out as making this particularly worthwhile
- The story is cliché and boring
- Protagonist is a hollow paper doll
- Not a fan of the blocky environment asthetic - cubes, cubes everywhere

----

Oceanhorn is essentially The Legend of Zelda with a reskin, so inevitably comparisons are going to be drawn.

Zelda works as a franchise because it has buckets of charm. It's quirky, imaginative and full of life. This is just about as close of an imitation as you can get without calling the protagonist Link and giving him a green tunic with a hood, but it has none of the appeal of it's ancestor.

The Zelda games were designed to consistantly amaze you. In Ocarina, climbing Goron mountain for the first time, exploring the Zora water caves, even travelling across the world on horseback, all of it is inspiring and innovative. The worlds tell their own stories. This has none of that. It's a mediocre copy/paste of Windwaker that does nothing particularly special to cement it's own place.

Just about the only things it has going for it are a pretty decent soundtrack (which is never really complimented with spectacular scenary or tense circumstance) and the fact it's on PC and the Zelda games are not.

There are far worse games in existance, but why settle for this when it is decidedly average.

22623912.review:
Got it on Humble Bundle where this game was just a bonus.  If you can get it cheap, then it's a good play-through, but otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it.

[b]Unlikeable protagonist[/b] - silent hero who's default and only expression is a scowling face.  Has zero personality; a robot could replace him and it would be an improvement.

[b]Generic story[/b] - there's a lot of excellently voiced dialogue in the game, except the story is so boring that it's really hard to care for any of these characters or their motivations.  Even the ending doesn't really resolve anything.

[b]Bad game design[/b] - several levels where you can get stuck while exploring, stamina gauge that limits your mobility for no reason, cheap boss fights offset by cheap items/spells, windwaker world map that serves no purpose other than to artificially prolong the game, fetch quests that require you to carry items slooooowly from point A to point B, legendary sword that is famed for its power yet a common rat can withstand two hits 

This game had a lot of potential.  It has all the pieces for a great game, and yet somehow all the flaws amalgamate to a disappointing experience.  Overall, it's a zelda clone devoid of the things that make a Zelda game good.

22496921.review:
Definitely a Zelda clone, and definitely not a bad one, either.  However, the fact that the camera is in an isometric view rather than top-down that can't be (from what I can tell using a controller) rotated, combined with a rather hilly landscape means tht there will be some things that you can't see in the game.  Sadly, that sometimes includes both you and hazards. Of course, that is my only real gripe, as the other controls are well-mapped (to the point that it really FEELS like Zelda), the landscape - well. seascape - itself is beautiful (tho it REALLY should have emulated Wind Waker more, IMHO.  I liked sailing to my destination myself, rather than picking an island and just going there with what amounts to a minigame or five along the way), the music is nice to listen to, and the story is also good (even if I find some dialog lacking). It's a good game, don't get me wrong, but it really pales in comparison to the series that rather obviously gave the creators inspiration.  Play it if you need a Zelda fix right now but don't have access to any actual Zelda games, or if you want something a LITTLE different from them.

EDIT:  After doing a casual playthrough, I have disturbing news for those looking for a cheap Zelda-like experience:  A liesurely stroll through the game doing a bit of exploration in optional areas gives you a 71% completion rate in just over 7 hours of playtime.  I would estimate that a 100% playthrough would only take about 10 hours.  Considering that is less time than an average LoZ game, I am a little disappointed.  Still, it is respectable given the price.  Still recommended, but know you're basically getting a truncated game in comparison to LoZ itself.

22491500.review:
So close, yet so far, from being good, good. But, there is still fun to be had!

Heavily inspired by Link/Zelda games Oceanhorn slowly, eventually, groggily delivers an adventure. It doesn't quite get close to Link but the inspiration is there. The early parts of the games feel like if you injected Link with horse tranquilizers and fed him 50 muscle relaxers and gave him toddler toys as a quest. The game just never decides its identity between ultra-casual young child adventure with no repercussions or something much more broad and deep with semi-complex puzzles and story nuances. And I think it struggles at that in a gameplay sense, at least in part, because of it being a mobile/tablet port. But thankfully by the second half it does evolve to a game with some average difficulty and challenges that most definitely a small child could not complete. Its just a very broken flow and stride to get there. A stride that was always a few steps too slow for my liking.

The world and story is complete though. And combat and puzzles do become quite fun. There's a fun adventure to be had. The pacing, or lack there of, pushed me into wandering and grinding. I'm not big on arbitrary video game "achievements" or "trophies" but going for them all in this game majorly contributed to my fun factor. What you get out is what you put in with Oceanhorn. You have to make a concerted effort with the game, but I think it was worth it. 

There's more I could complain and nitpick about too. The fishing system is absolutely silly. The gun on the boat should've just been mounted to explain why you don't get to have it anywhere else. The boat travel in general could've had more variety. Blah blah blah. The point is, the game has issues. But never did I consider quitting or did any of them ruin my time. Quintessential casual controller game.

Swords, bombs, arrows, keys, treasure chests, and baddies! There's fun to be had if you want it. Just keep grand and lofty expectations in check.

22391913.review:
At first I took the subtleties of this game's story as a Zelda inspired creation. However, it wasn't long before I started to enjoy the game in it's own right. It reminded me more of an old Playstation game by the name of Alundra more than Legend of Zelda. There is as much exploration and puzzles as there is adventure and fighting. Oceanhorn's story doesn't take too long to get into and honestly if I put down the game for a few days I would forget what I had to do despite the ability to review previous cutscenes. It's a really cool isometric game that deals with exploring various islands in a water ridden world.

The story was solid and never deviated far from the main goal of finding your father and defeating Oceanhorn. There were side quests a plenty along the way that brought you a little closer to your goal. Some featuring puzzles that required very little thinking, quick or otherwise. The general fighting was simple but gave you a few ways to approach how you would kill enemies. Boss battles took a slight learning curve before understanding their combat patterns. What I find surprising in this adventure RPG was the pace that it went. 

This wasn't by any means a long game. The majority of my time was spent backtracking to find stuff or remember to do one of the quests when I ran into a road block. Clues were scattered around areas that alluded to other locations which I'd ultimately neglect to explore, which made things tedious. I noticed a few things that could have improved my experience.

One of the things I would have liked was a notebook that maybe jotted semi useful information that you found on your journey so that maybe I could remember where the honey was located without having to go back to the source to get information on particular items needed to progress. Another thing that I found a little mundane about it was the actual traveling between islands. You don't have the freedom of navigating yourself rather you select a route that your boat moves along. I did appreciate the obstacles in the water that I had to be vigilant and shoot with my cannon but after the 10th time it was repetitive to the point of boring because there was so much back and forth travel happening. It would have also been nice if your character was able to interact with people he met on the sea. With so many islands you really wonder why the sea was so barren. 

Despite the critical observations I did enjoy this game the time I did spend playing it. the visuals were beautiful the controls tight and the music was well done. The atmosphere and pace of the gameplay was all one note with the exception nearing the final boss. This would be a nice game for anyone interested in Zelda-esque adventure.

22365592.review:
A 2.5D Zelda clone for the PC that isn’t quite as good as Zelda.

You wanted more?

Fine.

Oceanhorn is a game about a kid who is looking for his dad. His dad took off to face off with Oceanhorn, the last of the Living Fortresses, great monsters which were left behind by an ancient civilization. Your goal is to go from island to island in search of your dad.

The core gameplay is very familiar to Zelda fans – you have a sword and a shield. You wander around stabbing stuff. While the game has 3D graphics, it is fundamentally 2D – indeed, it is a major gameplay mechanic that you can fall down one “floor” worth of blocks, and can only go up via stairs. This is pretty much how all the dungeons are arranged, and numerous puzzles center around your inability to jump.

This is not a sophisticated game – you walk around and slash stuff with your sword. There is no Z-targeting or anything of the sort, but the game does have a sort of auto-aim feature.

Over the course of the game, you acquire items – bombs (for blowing stuff up), a bow and arrow (for shooting targets to trigger stuff, as well as certain enemies), a fishing rod (because what is Zelda without fishing?), boots (for jumping over one-square gaps)… really, exactly the most basic items you’d expect in a Zelda game. You also get spells – a fire spell, a spell that drops stuff on switches, an ice spell to freeze stuff which seemed unnecessary, a cure spell that I only used on the final boss, and a black hole spell that is super overpowered but useless on bosses.

That said, the game is pretty easy, and the puzzles basic. There’s nothing here that you haven’t seen before many times.

And that’s really the problem with the game – it is nothing new. It is just a kind of mediocre Zelda-ish game that doesn’t do anything new, just sort of treads the usual ground. The bosses are nothing impressive, the ordinary enemies are mostly boring and samey (and you find them a lot – there isn’t a whole bunch of variety, having even less variety than Zelda games), the environments didn’t feel that varied (you’re on a bunch of islands, but few of them feel unique)… really, there’s just very little here to excite you.

It isn’t bad, and the voice acting is decent (even if the script is often not great), but there’s just little here to get excited about. You’ve probably played Zelda, and if you haven’t, this isn’t a great introduction to the genre – games like Darksiders felt like they were much more interesting new interpretations of the Zelda formula than this was. This was same old, same old, and fairly mediocre. There’s nothing great about it, and while it isn’t bad, there’s little to recommend.

22289085.review: There's some good and some bad about this game honestly, but I would say overall a worthwhile experience. It's one of those things where there are weird little things that stand out like a sore thumb in an otherwise excellent piece. Oceanhorn is very Zelda-esk, which is what I went in looking for, what with the slowly unlocking new gear to open up new areas around the world. It also has an actual leveling system, which is nice, although it doesn't do a ton, it mainly just upgrades the number of bombs or arrows you can carry and whatnot. The challenge system is nice and provides an easy way to track achievements in a way that gives in game experience points. The story is kind of meh, but they don't shove it down your throat and generally just let you go explore. There are quite a few instances where they don't tell you about something and you're supposed to kind of just figure it out. That is to be expected from this kind of game, but there were several times where I had to utilize something in a way I wasn't even aware was possible and that was a bit frustrating since it wasn't clear. My main gripe with this game is the movement mechanics. I understand what they are going for, but it feels almost moronic to get stopped by 1ft high rocks CONSTANTLY and not being able to fall down more than one ledge space at a time. I feel like if they had given it more physical depth, it would have been a more immersive experience since it really pulls you out of the game when you have to navigate in ridiculous fashions that no normal human being would ever have to deal with. You also have to unlock the ability to jump via an item, which is stupid, and it only lets you jump horizonally across one space and not vertically at all. The movement structure also causes some confusion about progression since the rules get bent a bit here and there. Like you can normally only drop down 1 tier, but in certain spots to progress you have to drop down 2 or 3 and you weren't thinking you could even do that. The boss system is solid and very refreshing. It is something that genuinely awards paying attention and trial and error. The boss battles themeslves are actually extremely easy, but only if you know what you're doing. For instance, I would go into a boss battle and die over and over again until I learned something new and then I could go in and kill it without almost any problems at all. The fishing system in this game seems forced and pointless. You don't gain anything by doing it and it is complete random luck and there are far too many achievements revolving around fishing. My goal was to 100% this game and I got to the last few achievements and was just like NOPE. I see no enjoyment in running all round the world looking for fish and hoping they are the right kind. I was also a bit bummed that the sailing in this game is on rails and not open world. It doesn't feel bad or anything, but I didn't expect it to lock you on your path. Overall an enjoyable game though that satisfies the Zelda itch for a good price. I picked mine up in a Humble Bundle or something, so it was only a few dollars and it was money well spent.

I should probably start off by saying I have never played a Zelda game (and have no intention to). So I won't be making the kind of comparisons that would be expected here, because I can't.

And maybe precisely because this kind of gameplay is still somewhat fresh to me did I enjoy the game so thoroughly. The gameplay is very solid, the mix of exploration, puzzles and action just right. The world feels somehow alive and vibrant despite its absurdities of scale. The fairytale visuals are appropriate here (and are of quite high quality). The music is top notch, especially the epic choral pieces. 

I was never stuck for very long. Difficulty is not adjustable, but it is kinda on the easy side. The same could be said of the collectibles, they're suprisingly manageable, not too hard. All that is great in my book. There was the whole Botfish episode, which threatened to produce a negative review [i]all by itself[/i] but it quickly resolved itself once I had 9 hearts so I will speak of it no more. There are some bugs that can cause you to get stuck in an impossible location and force to suicide/reload the game but they're rare.

If you're looking to go on a grand and fantastical adventure flavoured (in a good way!) with childish wonderment, this would be a pretty good choice.

22243688.review:
Unless you're incredibly bored & brain dead just looking for a time waster do not buy this game. If you can get it on a massive sale, or for free, and have some time to kill... here's 63 trivial achievementsl. Also just a note going in, you never get to sail the boat yourself D: It's like a loading mini-game that's just spam the mouse to shoot things in your way.

Firstly, enemies. There are barely any bosses and a severe lack of mini-bosses of any sort, leaving you to spam click your sword through low level enemies in every dungeon without any real threat to your annoyance. The Graveyard, Riptide, Old Fortress... none have a boss of any sort. Just the same ol' boring low level enemies. Not only that but pretty much every boss could just be taken down by a few bomb throws from across the arena. Very boring.

Secondly, level design. The trailers don't lie: the levels are small and cramped. But alright, you can still do great things with that limitation. Sadly Oceanhorn doesn't. The puzzles can barely be called that, and yes this is coming from a puzzle lover who's crack is a challenge that could take hours to figure out, but holy applesauce this game... There is more than a couple instances where the 'puzzle' is literally a box right next to the switch. The 'increased' difficulty for puzzles in this game just seems to be: add more boxes and switches sitting next to each other.

This game feels like it was made for young children with its 'difficulty'. The only reason I have so much time on this is because it was an easy grab for achievements and it felt like it would be an embarrassment to not have them all with how trivial it is. The amount of time is because of how slow it is to move around, fishing, & the time it takes to skulk about an area murdering all of one type of enemy.

Thirdly, the story. While the main points are fine and dandy... there's a huge problem with everything else that gets one emerged in the game. There are no interesting or fun interactions with any NPC and despite them never doing anything, learning anything about you, knowing anything about what's happening, the game forces an advancement in their generic uninteresting NPC comments as if they are all omniscient. There are promises of a fun side note/reaction to something you've done, like the “Don't break the pots” sign or the “You will never reach Master Level” sign sitting right next to the 'Master Adventurer' but just... nothing. It's all glossed over.

Another example is Neeto. No introduction convo, she doesn't acknowledge you're different than the regular townsfolk, yet when you meet her for the 2nd time suddenly she's waiting on the docks for you to arrive and help her cause you're the only one she can count on. Really..? It goes even further with the fireworks scene with her acting like she's the protagonists girl friend, asking to be taken to see the world, and then the kid gives her the super special thing he just got! Wat... Where did that all come from? Where did any of these relations come from? We never get to see, participate, or develop any of it. We only get the after notes, which leaves a player rather uninvested in everything.

I didn't have a very high bar going into this game but I had hope it could be a shadow of a Zelda game as it likes to so proudly tell everyone. But this... this was a fanfic AU of a couple Zelda mashups (majorly Windwaker if one couldn't tell from the videos) where they had to make a few minor character design changes so they wouldn't get dinged by the trademark. Featuring the Zora, the Evolved Bird-Zora, the Hylians, Octoroks, Moblins, Buzzblobs, Keese, Peahat Larva, the Master Sword & Mirror Shield, the 3 Emblems (Green, Blue, Red), Islands as remnants of an ancient civilization... I'm surprised I didn't see any Cuckoo beyond the weather vanes.

22171614.review:
Analizar este juego resumiendo lo máximo posible, bastaría con decir que "es un clon de Zelda", lo cual dice muchísimas cosas de como es su jugabilidad, mecánicas y atmósfera, pero quedaría la duda de si es buen clon o es malo, todos mis amigos fans de Zelda lo consideran un mal juego, inferior al original, sin embargo a mí me ha gustado y paso a describir sus características:

El juego se esfuerza en mostrar una evolución del personaje (algo heredado de los RPG), así al principio nos hace ver que somos un chico sin habilidades más allá de saber golpear con una espada, no podremos ni saltar, pero con el tiempo seremos una suerte de mago-guerrero con varias armas, magias y habilidades, dando una sensación de progresión muy agradable, también hay un nivel de experiencia que va aumentando, dinero con el que comprar objetos y mejoras, y todo ello para luchar contra una cantidad enorme de enemigos comunes y algunos jefes finales. La mecánica es tipo hack'n'slash y plataformas, con bastante de crafteo y exploración. La historia parece simple pero vemos que según se va desarrollando tiene su magia. Las zonas jugables se diferencian en islas, cada una diferente de la otra y con su propia historia o recurso que las hace únicas, si bien comparten una estructura común, y están separadas por un mar que debemos navegar una y otra vez, remarcando así la importancia de la exploración. Los puzzles son sencillos en su planteamiento pero algunos nos harán dedicarles un buen rato, incluso desespera si hemos olvidado algo o simplemente nos falta una zona intermedia que visitar, pues a pesar de su aspecto de aventura libre, esconde un camino casi lineal, y zonas que debemos revisitar para completarlas al 100%. En principio el juego fue diseñado pensando en smartphones y tablets, por lo que su nivel gráfico no es algo que deslumbre, muestra un aspecto simple pero eso sí, muy resultón y bonito, con un marcado acabado infantil bastante propio también de (muchos de) los juegos de Nintendo, y decir que justo eso hace que tenga un rendimiento excelente en prácticamente cualquier PC, también sus controles han sido adaptados y tiene una gran cantidad de opciones gráficas. Cuenta con una banda sonora cargada de melodías bien hechas e incluso pegadizas, que le da un acabado entrañable al juego. El control con mando es excelente, así como con teclado y ratón.

Como puntos negativos solo podría decir lo ortopédico que resulta al principio (lo expliqué antes), algunos bugs de quedarse atrapado entre un objeto y una pared sin posibilidad de salir (aunque como el guardado automático es bastante continuado no supone mayor problema que perder un minuto en repetir nuestros pasos), y sobretodo la falta de expresividad de los personajes, lo que no ayuda a meterse en la historia.

En definitiva, un juego largo, variado, entretenido, y que supone una experiencia bastante original en PC ya que apenas hay juegos que se le parezcan, por todo ello, si nunca hemos jugado un Zelda o no buscáis en este que sea otra entrega más de esa saga, os lo recomiendo.

22009343.review:
Videogames are in love with themselves. Or rather, they’re in love with the monoliths of gaming history, the games that for many form a mesh of absolutes and ideals which other games continually seek to emulate. Sometimes this leads to the betterment of an idea, a concept first imitated and then refined so that it then becomes synonymous with this new game that did it better. Other times though the ways games so constantly seek to recreate their predecessors never extends beyond rudimentary or reductive replication, seeking success by playing to familiarity and nostalgia. This is where we are met with Oceanhorn: Monster of the Uncharted Seas, a would be Zelda clone that is the gaming equivalent to that off-brand action figure your grandmother mistakenly bought you for Christmas, on the surface indistinguishable from the original but whose inadequacy becomes immediately known once the disingenuous packaging is breached.

Oceanhorn mirrors not only Zelda’s style of play, but its aesthetic and structure. Its art design is inarguably seeking to reflect that of Zelda’s more cartoony iterations, specifically the nautically inclined Wind Waker and Phantom Hourglass. Oceanhorn’s world is bright and colorful, segmented into different islands you access by sailing on those supposedly uncharted seas, with a bouncy demeanor that is unable to distract from the overwhelming feeling of artificiality present in every aspect of Oceanhorn’s design. This isn’t wholly due to Oceanhorn’s status as a poor man’s Zelda, but the result of a world that feels entirely synthetic. The whimsical charm and history always so paramount to Zelda’s world design is entirely absent, replaced with a cold and alienating feeling of obligation. Oceanhorn’s world exists entirely for the sake of housing its plot, a plot which expands and shrinks in whichever way it finds convenient, pouring out backstory when it needs to feel grandiose and then receding into the background when it fails to back up its attempts at magnificence with anything more than words.

Where Zelda constructs its narrative to intersect and enhance its mechanics, Oceanhorn uses it as a crux. Things happen because the game needs you to move to the next dungeon. Plot is only ever employed for the sake of giving context to your actions, but the writing is so stale and inconsistent that it causes the game as a whole to feel even more so the product of recognizable but unofficial parts. Details are always given in terms meant to imply a storied history to this land, with caves and lost princesses being hidden away for thousands of years, and yet within minutes of arriving to these areas you are able to overcome whatever obstacle was standing in the way of the local inhabitants, often by such trivial means as to call into question whether anyone has actually cared even a little about the fate of their world until you arrived. There is an astounding level of pointlessness to Oceanhorn’s plot given how much time it dedicates to selling you on it, to the point I feel it would be better off simply tearing it all out and letting the mechanics speak for themselves.

It seems fair to say Oceanhorn’s main draw isn’t its plot but its mechanical similarity to Zelda, so its true test is in how well it manages to reconstruct a formula that has changed little over the years and yet remains incredibly well regarded and popular. In this Oceanhorn is…fine. It manages to mirror many of Zelda’s most recognizable aspects, from item based navigation puzzles to dungeon layouts and boss designs, but it never loses that feeling of being a cheap imitation. One of Zelda’s biggest strengths is in the multilayered design of its world and dungeons, where puzzles build upon themselves as your means of solving them becomes larger, each knew item bringing with it a host of immediate and secondary applications.

Oceanhorn in comparison is much less intricate in its design, presenting you with new items when it sees fit but never giving you much to do with them. There are puzzles here they are more like speedbumps than roadblocks, tending to hold you up for a moment but ultimately tedious to overcome and often of the same block-pushing variety. The lack of intelligent level and puzzle designs causes Oceanhorn to feel intensely segmented and linear, each dungeon serving to send you on the next but having little for you to actually do while you’re there. Exploration is nearly entirely absent both within levels and in the overworld, the former due to the narrow design of each island, and the later as the boat you use to travel between islands is entirely on rails.

Even as one of the few who enjoyed Wind Waker’s sailing, traveling between islands in Oceanhorn is excruciatingly obnoxious. There is so little to do in these segments that their inclusion is as worthless as the plot attempting to justify it. The ocean itself is tepid and lifeless and the only thing populating it an abundance of trash you need to clear away with your cannon, a task no doubt meant to keep you occupied until you arrive at your destination but only serving to make sailing even more annoying as you are then required to pay attention the whole time you are cruising along lest you bump into a mine someone carelessly left floating around. The monotony of sailing caused me to lose any interest I might have had to return to previous island to pick up a collectible I missed or finish up some of the sidequest objectives I hadn’t gotten around to, though these additions contribute so little to the game that the only real reason to pursue them is for the sake of completion.

Oceanhorn’s only truly alluring aspect is its novelty as the closest PC and mobile players can get to a native Zelda game. With so little like it on these platforms it is tempting to accept and justify Oceanhorn’s middling to bad attempts to replicate Nintendo’s iconic franchise, solely because it’s all we are likely to ever get. But for as hard as it might try, there is no mistaking Oceanhorn as anything but a knock-off, and not a good one at that. Its design is uninspired and meandering, a chore to navigate and a bore to solve. Even excluding comparisons to Zelda proper, Oceanhorn isn’t fun to play, and if it wasn’t for bearing such a striking resemblance to that series I doubt anyone would have paid it much attention in the first place.

[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2016/03/23/oceanhorn-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]
