21942908.review:
[b]Thoroughly forgettable[/b]

The line above sums up the entire experience, sadly.
Oceanhorn is a really nicely presented game - the colourful, stylized graphics and really pleasant music are a highlight in the category of presentation - that brings the Zelda-like style of gameplay to PCs, but is nowhere near good enough to live to the reputation of aforementioned Zelda games. What we get instead is a stroll through several islands, hunt for collectibles and a story that barely does anything.

Let's start with the last on that list - while not overly complicated, and often obvious with its revelations/suggestions, the story of the game seems like an excuse thrown together without much thinking. The motivations and some connections are very sketchy, to the point where they don't get any explanation at all. Add to the fact that there is no real closure, the start and the end of the story feel almost random and... you have something that lives in the background, but that's about it. The big discrepancies in the performance of voice actors don't help - some of them sound like they just couldn't care for a single moment.
Unless we count shoe-horned insinuations of romantic interest and the like, which were as unnecessary and clunkily handed as possible.

Collectible hunt is actually fun, if you are after completing your games 100%, then this is a thing for you. There is plenty of exploring, bombing, jumping and otherwise figuring out how to get to that elusive last blood gem or chest. Coupled with the fact that the labyrinthine, complicated structure of the islands makes it interesting to poke your nose in every corner - it works well. 
Which can't be exactly said about the puzzles, as they are divided into two categories, as far as I am concerned - relatively easy ones and those you will frown at because they are timed. Why would the latter be a problem? Because of how some of the control scheme works. The biggest offender here are Trencher Boots. For reasons I cannot fathom, aside from their primary function of jumping gaps (Zelda's ladder basically) they also have a roll function, which doubles the role of the dash the character has from the very beginning. Now, this roll can cause you to fall down from low-height platforms when you would rather jump from one to another, because both of these functions are tied to one button and which goes off is dependant on your position. And when you have a timed puzzle, you want to cut corners.
There are several more control gripes like that - throwing objects can be finicky, sword combat doesn't feel all too nice either. Bow has the same issues as throwing object which means... you will be okay, but sometimes it takes a wild guess whether you can hit something at all, and times when you will waste three arrows because you weren't just precise enough with turning your character around will happen.

All the issues and positives combined, Oceanhorn is... okay. You will probably enjoy yourself, spend 10-20 hours in it, then put back onto the virtual shelf. And forget about it, because what this game lacks the most, is anything that would make it leave a mark on your memories.
I would gladly give this game a neutral review if I could, but as it stands, a thumbs down is in order. Because the game isn't bad, but it is not worth recommending either.

21939710.review:
First of all, I never played Zelda WindWaker, so i don't know if it's a tribute and i don't know if it's a good tribute, but one things sure, oceanhorn is a poor game.

[u]Fight mechanics are dull[/u]
Why is that ? For most enemies, you only have to hit and parry. There is only two exceptions. One were you need to parry and shoot from afar and one were you first need to use a spell for destroy some sort of shield. Even the bosses aren't challenging at all. In many games, phases are added to boss so you have to get a patern and use it against the boss to defeat it. Here, you don't have to pay attention to the patern, you only have to see if it's following you or not. And the "phases" are in fact the exact same patern that repeat faster.

[u]Puzzles are dull[/u]
Honestly ... I finished the game in ten hours, literally watching tv at the same time. And i didn't focused on the game.
The puzzles are so easy. Push this and you succeed. Walk on this and you suceed. Walk on this and walk quickly here and you suceed. That all. I know it's not easy making puzzles. I make some for passing time. But the only thing i ask is some intricacy. You finish a puzzle to pass a room and continue until you find an other room with a puzzle. For example, on easy puzzle is asking to push buttons in a certain order, this order gived by hints in the level.
Some time i learned there was hints to puzzle i didn't even know were puzzle. 

I can't help have the feelings that the princess of fish people ( don't remember their name) and fish people themselves are some bad  plagiarism of zelda. Even if it was intended to be a tribute, i don't think it's "healthy" for the game and the gamers to see almost the same design between two characters ( and species of two different games.

Goods points are : good soundtracks and good graphics (until you watch a cutscene) but this don't make a game.
The story is not bad. It feels like, beside some incredibly "borderline inspirations", there is some background and some interesting furthermore.

Well, I don't recommend this game (or buy it for a low price) but if the developers want to make a number two and want to improve what the game is lacking, i'll be glad to buy the second opus.

The ocean travel is boring (and you do a *lot* of it); it's like Wind Waker without the sense of freedom and exploration, while giving you more random stuff to shoot.  The clincher was that there are some annoying bugs; you often have to push boxes into spike pits so that you can walk over the pit.  Unfortunately, sometimes the game will still let you fall into the pit, right through the box that you pushed into it.  You have nothing to do but wait to die, and then wait for all of your resurection pots to get used up (since you res in the place you died) so that you can respawn at a save point.  It's happened to me enough times that I've given up on the game, and so I'm not recommending it.

21937480.review:
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas was an iOS game ported to PC. This game pays homage to the Legend of Zelda series, specifically to Majora's Mask, Windwaker, and A Link to the Past. To me this game felt like it was a love letter to the LoZ series, a game that brings the same feeling with it's gameplay and great music, not on par with LoZ's music but something that you can listen to hours on end without getting annoyed. Though my hours on this version of the game says 2.1 hours, as of writing this review, I have already beaten this game on iOS and it was really fun to play on both versions each with their own good parts and bad parts.

The story for Oceanhorn is fairly straight forward, a big sea monster known as "Oceanhorn" has come to your island and your dad goes to fight against it while you sleep. As you awake you're left alone with your mother's pendant, that acts kind of like a guide, and you're off on your journey to fight against Oceanorn on your little boat, just like in Windwaker.

Though this game doesn't hold your hand and guide you through the game telling you which way to go, you're encouraged to explore around the different islands that you discover and sail to. You'll find interesting inhabitants, vast dungeons and enemies with their own unique design, though still looking very similar to their LoZ counterparts.

With just your sword and shield you'll fight off interesting bosses and solve some puzzles along the way. Now onto the controls, I highly recommend playing this with a controller, you can play with a keyboard just fine it's just gonna take a lil' while to get adjusted. The controls are a little loose but nothing too bad, especially noting that this was an iOS port, and the camera controls are a bit unnecessary since there is no use for it, especially since there is very little movement when you do move it.

The game itself has you fight off rather easy bosses, where you rarely take any damage, solve fairly simple puzzles and collect four elemental powers. Thought the gameplay doesn't have anything that really jumps out at you the islands make up for it with it's rich design making them immersive and best of all fun to explore. Sailing though is a bit of a let down, clicking on where you want to go without any controls, other than the gun that you fire later on in the game, but at least the amazing soundtrack helps pass the time while you sail from one island to another.

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a great and fun game to play, though it can be a bit too easy from time to time it's still something that I would recommend for someone to buy. As of writing this review Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is on available for $16.99CAD, about $13-$14 USD, and if you're planning on buying it I would say to wait until it's on sale for $10-$12CAD, $7-$9 USD.
7.5/10 Great for a rainy day when you want to lounge around and play a relaxing game.

Juego inspirado en el Zelda wind waker, transportado desde IOS a PC. Si vas a llorar o gruñir porque se parezca al Zelda, no lo jueges, así de simple. Es el primer trabajo de una compañia sencillita sin los recursos de la gran Nintendo, que ofrece aproximadamente 10 horas de juego. 

Graficos 17/20: Inspirados por la estética plástica nintendera, se resiente en algunas ocasiones la calidad gráfica que puede ofrecer. 
Personajes 18/20: Personajes con una motivación, con un sentido y una coherencia en sus actos. Incluso algunos secundarios con cuatro lineas describen su pasado para entender el porqué de lo sucedido.
Sonido 20/20: La música es épica, me gustaria que fuesen pistas descargables a parte. Me encanta y es perfecta.
Jugabilidad 18/20: Es un juego sencillo y sin grandes pretensiones. Bajo mi criterio, falla a la hora de cambiar de hechizo que puedes usar, pero tampoco tiene una importancia vital en el juego. 
Historia 20/20: La historia, aunque breve, está bien hilada. Como es habitual en éste género de juegos, nos habla del viaje del héroe para cumplir con su destino. 

Valoración final: 93/100
Me parece un juego barato y breve, imprescindible para todos los fanes del género que hemos abandonado las videoconsolas a favor del PC.

This was a fun little clone of Zelda that was very pretty. The graphics were charming and the water looked really great. The game had a good combat system and inventory management was simple to use. There were two issues with this game.
First were the puzzles. All the puzzles were so ridiculously simple. Some 'puzzles' were switches placed in front of you to simply toggle - which literally opened the next area.
Second was with the voice acting. All the characters didn't sound like their respective character models. An old guy with a beard didn't sound old; A princess with gills didn't sound like a merfolk at all.
Apart from these to things, the story made sense and efforts were made to explore the background.

Also it looks great despite being originally for mobile devices.
7/10.

21912270.review:
No voy a limitarme a lo obvio y decir que es un zelda-like.


Un Action RPG sencillo y sin pretensiones aparentes más allá del homenaje. El personaje protagonista carece por completo de carisma, así como algunos NPCs, nada novedoso. Carece de énfasis y dramatismo, las escenas/cutscenes quedan sosas (como cuando matas a un jefe final y se corta la escena o consigues un nuevo objeto y no suena más que un escueto 'fanfare'), aunque quizás estoy mal acostumbrado.

Tiene una historia correcta y, aunque tiene ciertos huecos, puede dejarte con ganas de una secuela (precuela sería más apropiado e interesante).

Es entretenido, sobretodo eso. Si nos ponemos exquisitos se puede hacer un poco repetitivo, los puzles de las mazmorras son simples y obvios, pero son un buen punto de partida. En general el diseño de niveles es muy bueno, con alguna colisión mal traída, pero nada que no se vea en los mejores AAA. 

Los enemigos, los típicos, aunque las batallas contra jefes finales, a pesar de repetitivas y un poco aleatorias (puedes tardar 5 minutos como 20, dependiendo de como le dé por comportarse al bicho), tienen cierta originalidad.

Su música no destaca, hace su función de acompañamiento y se adecua a cada situación. Varias pistas repetidas la dejan en evidencia. Pero repito, cumple.

Para mi lo mejor es su apartado gráfico. Modelados acertados y texturas muy bonitas y llamativas, un buen uso de la iluminación (aunque no siempre, eh). Las ilustraciones son geniales. Parece que olvidaron retocar algunas animaciones del personaje principal, a veces parece un robot.

Lo peor es el diseño del juego. Concretando, no siempre te dejan claro qué tienes que hacer, dónde o cómo, por lo que, si no hechas mano de una guía, te pasas medio juego de una isla a otra. No suelo usar guías, pero llega un momento que se hace desesperante y cuando lo ves dices: "¿¡En serio!? ¿Cómo pretenden que descubra eso?". Una recomendación: Cuando tengas dudas, pon bombas por doquier, aunque parezca que no (una grieta o algo, no es mucho pedir). Lo gracioso es que hay partes super lógicas en las que sí pistas.

Hablando de bombras; Los items. No se arriesgan y van a los básicos. Tiene también hechizos, que bien podrían haber sido otros items (p.e. Hechizo de fuego = Cetro de fuego). Ahí sí, un toque de originalidad (aunque llegados a este punto ya no hacía falta). Y es aquí cuando te das cuenta de que el juego salió también para dispositivos móviles y esa dualidad nunca ayuda. La pesca es insufrible, pero en su defensa diré que me parece insufrible en todos los juegos (e intuyo que también en la vida real).

Logros correctos, ninguno imposible. Además, te dan experiencia.


[i]Lo recomiendo, sencillo, si te gusta mucho mucho la saga Zelda. Sinceramente, es por lo único que jugarás.

No lo recomiendo, claro, si no te gustan los Action RPG. Es un juego con potencial, pero intrascendente. El enfoque es erróneo, casi imposible olvidar que no estás más que en un (intencionado o no) homenaje a The Legend of Zelda. [/i]


Este es un análisis para la versión de Steam, obviamente. Quizás en dispositivos móviles sería diferente (es una plataforma más casual y no se es tan exigente).

This is a barely playable homage to 3D zelda that badly ports 2D zelda mechanics to mouse and keyboard.

It's inconsistent about the controls, equating clicking in certain spots to pressing spacebar, but only in certain contexts.  It's inconsistent about it's geometry, having the character sometimes but not always be able to jump off edges or climb, depending on what the game feels like allowing without any visual indicators.

The game starts off with a boring cutscene monologuing about some mysterious monster that an NPC has to go fight voiced by character that isn't there yet (reused voices?), before a voice that is never even given a character tell you to wake up.  With that backstory, the game hands you a list of controls and a list of achievements as your primary motivation for doing things.  From there the game assume the player will get the hidden chest nearby and only then explains why it was significant, while still refusing to give any in-game motivations, and even contradicting its own setting.  The mc was not supposed to get the sword and shield, despite living on a tiny island with monsters alongside an old man who can't defend himself?  I call BS.

And then the sailing section occurs.  The game gives no indication of how sailing works.  I won't hide it.  I stopped playing here, because I couldn't convince the game to do anything.  Even after I looked on the forums, all I could find was a tip saying to click a couple hundred times and it'll work.

If anyone tells you this game is like zelda or the closest to zelda you'll get on PC, ignore them, and go look up Ittle Dew.  It's an actually playable game that pays homage to zelda.

21857709.review:
This game is a zelda-clone, in particular a windwaker/phantom hourglass clone. However, it's a much shorter and smaller game. The gameplay and graphics are pretty decent, but the story, characters, and puzzles are relatively lackluster. Some of my favorite things about windwaker were the large, mostly open world to explore, the quirky characters and their accompanying side-quests, and the variety of items to use. However, those aspects were not really present in this game.

The sailing in this game is very boring to me. You're on a track to whichever island you choose as your destination and then there are a few obstacles you get to shoot in the 30 seconds or less it takes you to get to another island. No sunken treasures, outposts, or islands to discover(you just hear about them from other people and then go from point A to point B). The characters are not terribly memorable at all, although I did enjoy the designs of the rito and zora clones (owlbros and gillfolk). The only real items you get are bombs, arrows, and the ability to jump. There is also magic, but I think it could've been used more for the puzzles and bosses. [spoiler]You get this super cool black hole spell if you get a certain number of bloodstones and it's not effective against bosses and isn't nearly as cool as the name implies. [/spoiler] The story is about as cliche as it gets, but this time you're helping your dad instead of a princess. 

That said, the quality is really nice for an indie game. The music is solid, but falls short of the glory of zelda soundtracks. The art is pretty and while the environments are blocky like in phantom hourglass, they're still made to look relatively natural. The combat works nicely and there are a fair number of enemies that you can't mindlessly hack and slash without first getting behind them or breaking their guard somehow. I also liked the fishing minigame. 

I'd recommend this for people who really like Zelda games, but expect a game about a third (or less) as long and half as good. 

7/10

21856707.review:
The short of it is that if you greatly enjoyed The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker(or games like it), and you have a ton of free time on your hands, than you should give this game a chance. Otherwise, if you didn't, don't have that much time, or have access to Wind Waker, than you are better off skipping this game (and just playing Wind Waker instead).

The long of it is that this game is a mediocre adventure game with some charming elements to it, but lacks polish. Which is very disappointing since it is easy to see how this game could have been much better, had they just done a little bit more.  The lack of polish in this game is shown in nearly every part of it, but the two that I think best display it are these. 

First, the game has a problem with visual cues, or to be more exact, it sometimes doesn't display any, or displays the wrong ones.  This happens at several places throughout the game, for example, sometimes there are floor tiles in a object moving puzzle section that will use the same texture as the border tiles, even though, you can slide things onto them. Not only is this confusing, but it is also very frustrating, since the solution ends up being very simple.  This visual inconsistence is bizarre, since at times it seems like it was done intentional. Like they wonder why no one else does this kind of thing (using the same texture for both a valid and invalid movement space) before, and they figure that they would.  Also, there a part in the game where the player run across a spiked gate. Not only does this looks goofy, but it doesn't make sense, since throughout the game spikes are used as a hazard.  Except in this one case, where it is the intended path.  These visual cue issues don't break the game, but they do happen enough to be a problem, which is disappointing, since they seem like they would be easy to fix.

Second, most of the game's puzzles, aren't challenging and feel meaningless, since they are just one step. For example, some time you'll run into a barred gateway, and to get past this gateway, all you have to do is use a switch. And most of the time the switch itself is within 20 feet of the gateway with nothing blocking you from using it. Other times you'll run into a pathway that splits into 2. Down one path is a locked door, and down the other is the key for that locked door. It is this simplistic design that makes most of the game's content feel shallow. There are no a-ha moments, no sense of achievement, and really nothing remarkable about running into a puzzle and then spending 5 seconds to get through it. In the end it feels like they have all the pieces that are used to make a puzzle, but missed the point of why gamers like to solve them. 

Overall Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a mediocre adventure game. It can be fun at times, but it usually isn't. The game has a decent foundation, but it execution of those ideas is lacking.  The game as is, isn't worth it, but I found its potential to be interesting.

[b]If you love Zelda, you will hate Oceanhorn.[/b]

I have no problem with games coping other titles and belive it can be a good thing. But the developer of Oceanhorn seam to lack a understandig of why Zelda is a good game. They copy mechanics and implement them in on of the worst ways I have ever seen.

My favorit example would be the bombs, that can be used in combat or to destroy walls. Zelda introduces bombs in a logical way and shows the player different ways of using them. Oceanhorn on the other hand gifs you said bombs and explains nothing. Of course if you know Zelda you will also know that you can destroy walls, they're clearly damaged and indicate that an explosion would destroy them. In Oceanhorn there is never a clear indication and it's more guessing than knowing. Rarly will you see a small part of an staircase or similiar to guide you the way.

21796498.review:
A stunning combination of modern graphics, old-school Zelda gameplay with modern Zelda goals, a touch of Windwaker islands, no restraints from fan-service and a clear amount of love and dedication to the format. This will be the best non-third-person Zelda game you've played for a long time, but don't let that comparison fool you as this game has so many good, well-followed-through ideas that you'll be left feeling Nintendo needs to catch up.

It's got everything you'd expect from the years of Zelda variations we've had: elemental relics, fish and bird people, arrows and bombs, heart pieces, and a silent protagonist. But it's also got a lot you woulds: XP and levelling up, fishing, built-in non-grinding acheivements that award XP, far more subtle secrets than Zelda's ever had, and persistent rooms that don't reset when you leave. This isn't some cheap indie cash-in. This was made with love, for the sole purpose of being a [i]good[/i] game.

[b][Update][/b]
The further you get into the game, the more you see that this really is a shameless Zelda clone, which is very sad. It had so much potential to be special, but beyond simply a tribute game, they've stuck to the same old formula to the same detriment as Nintendo. The primary-coloured tunic, the carbon-copy Zora fish-people who are frozen and you save their princess, the legendary sword that looks identical to the Master Sword with a palette-swap, the three elemental gods whose elemental symbols you collect to gain their favour, refurring to Cuckoos by name (Zelda's name for chickens), and I mentioned it before but the silent protagonist is entirely unnessisary - characters converse with you like you're talking back, and this is a game where there is spoken, english dialogue, quite unlike Zelda. 

Using an item to jump and casting ranged spells is a welcome change from the formula, but it's not the gameplay that's the problem - the fighting, puzzles and level design are all really fun. No, it's the strict adherance to creating an off-brand Zelda that really lets this game down. If you've never played a Zelda, then fantastic, but I imagine a lot of the people who bought this game were drawn to the aesthtic and familiar mechanics. This game could have been so much more and stood out on its own merits- the foundation is there -but its reverence to its inspiration is its downfall, highlighting all the stolen ideas and overshadowing the innovations.

If there's ever a sequel, and I would like there to be, I do hope they take a seperate path and turn this story platform into something unique.

21703094.review:
Accion/Inteligencia

-Dificultad de la accion: casual.
-Dificultad de la inteligencia: rebuscadilla.
-Dificultad general: asistente, a favor del jugador.

Si la mayor dificultad está en la inteligencia seria principalmente un juego de inteligencia.

Libertad del jugador bajo la simetría:
Uno de sus puntos fuertes es la libertad que nos dan para estar aquí o allí. Esta libertad nos irá dando acceso o semi acceso a otras áreas o lugares escondidos, y esta libertad es la que nos hace familiarizarnos con el juego y como jugador. La libertad está presente en más del 50% de la jugabilidad.

Esta libertad que tendremos para movernos por los mapas será común bajo un factor simétrico para el escenario, los elementos y las mecánicas de juego. De esta forma sólo pensaremos en el escenario como un escenario isométrico lleno de cubos o elementos, para quizás centrarnos más en las posibilidades lógicas y espaciales en la jugabilidad que pueden crearse o que se han creado.

Bajo su factor simétrico añadimos la historia, el guión y las tramas y la libertad para ir a un sitio o a otro, potenciando una matemática generalizada que cubre toda su dificultad en la inteligencia. El juego es totalmente cosciente de esto y así esta basado y enfocado de principio a fin.

Escala y profundidad de campo, matemática aplicada:
La medidas parten sobre la isometría, cubos isométricos y elementos y planos simetrícos. 
Para potenciar más esta matemática no se podrá girar el escenario.

Jugabilidad, lógica o intuición, matemática aplicada:
Objetos destructibles, muros quebradizos que se rompen por bombas, cajas que se pueden mover para por ej. formar un puente, posible interruptor alejado o inaccesible que sólo podremos accionarlo con flechas o una magia a distancia, bosses.

Acción:
De base y a través de la creatividad para descubrir los puzzles, la intuición para averiguar o intuir resultados, y la lógica y la matemática para las operaciones, compenetran una acción del personaje y un tiempo real de los enemigos o trampas, que servirá perfectamente para los paréntesis de la inteligencia, para que en todo momento seamos nosotros los que decidamos avanzar o descubrir los puzzles, y no ''ellos'' a nosotros. Esta accion tiene la misión de hacer de parentesis(Kit Kat), siendo su dificultad asistida para no quedarnos atascados y por tanto para no presionar al jugador para que se centre en la inteligencia.

Realmente el toque ''chic'' radica en la propuesta de la accion, la fluidez y la libertad, perfectamente asociados a la inteligencia. Como se dice: buena fórmula y gran concepto.

En resumen:

Este análisis está dedicado a cómo un género casual que sirve de fachada y pilar, y otro más importante o esencial, que es donde radica su grandeza, pueden trabajar armónicamente para ambos darse fuerza.

Trabajan armónicamente porque la acción casual pero completa en todos sus facetas apreciables, multiplican todos los factores o aspectos resultantes de la inteligencia. A su vez la inteligencia sirve de esa profundidad y esa seriedad, con lo que que la accion puede trabajar más holgada o libre. En este caso, la acción desahogada transcribe en la libertad para el reconocimiento del juego y en la estructura del juego en general, y también en las posibilidades en la jugabilidad.

21531342.review:
Summary:
Oceanhorn tries so hard to be a good Zelda clone, that it forgets to be good at all the little things that make a Zelda game a good game.

After spending a lot of time with Oceanhorn, I can give a thorough and fair review.
To give the game it's due, I will present the good before the bad.

Pros:
-Great looking visuals (minus character models). Colorful, thoughtful, visually appealing.
-A great game for particular gamers (Legend of Zelda fans, completionists, collectors)
-Zelda for PC! VERY Wind-waker inspired, which is touching for the nostalgia.
-A good wealth of game for the price. Many achievements and collectibles.
-Sailing doesn't suck! A good idea to make it more of a mini-game than a chore.

Cons:
-This is a Legend of Zelda clone that doesn't add or improve upon it's base material. The characters, the story, the puzzles, are all generally unappealling and forgettable. 

Games in notable concepts and mechanisms have been copied in the past with the aim of doing something different or better. Oceanhorn is not that game - it is unashamedly a Zelda clone. This point wouldn't be so bad if it Oceanhorn didn't go in the opposite direction at times and do things WORSE than Zelda - something to be examplified in further cons.

-Puzzles are not challenging, and are often an exercise in tedium.

Most puzzles are not difficult for the problem they present and how to solve them, but are often about a game element responding the way the player intends it to. This is further coupled with the next point...

-Oceanhorn is arbitrarily made trying and longer with backtracking.

The game presents very early several problems that can only be solved after having particular items, which isn't anything new. However, one vital item to solving these problems isn't obtained until the 11th hour of the game, which presents the player with the (reluctantly optional) task of spending hours backtracking through every location for collectibles, treasure, etc. Without this, the game would probably have been about half it's actual length towards full completion, and with that in mind I can easily add that it outstayed it's welcome.

-Bombs OP.

Talking about a Zelda clone and getting down to brass tacks... When 90% of puzzles and encounters are solved with "bomb everything", it is a not a compliment to the other mechanisms present in the game. For puzzles, it feels like lazy game design, presenting the player repeatedly with, "Which wall do I blow up?"
For combat, this is largely a three-fold problem. 
1) All other combat abilities afforded to the player are slower and less effective than bombs. Spells are slower, sword-play is dull and risky, bow and arrows are slower and weaker. 
2) Bombs are plentiful! Often times, due to how the mechanisms work, you are rewarded a bomb for killing something with a bomb. You hold many and everyone and their mother has them too, so go nuts! Why not? 
3) It takes the guess-work out of encounters. Bombs work on everything from puzzles, to minions, to bosses, and after a while of slinging a sword and learning dodging patterns of enemies, it becomes increadibly simpler to chuck a bomb at whatever it is and win. There were two notable boss encounters where there were present some puzzle-like attribute in order to thwart the target, all of which was completely ignored because boss was vulnerable to bombs.

Conclusion:
Sadly doesn't live up to it's source material, despite so much effort going into the game to make it what it is. I don't blame anyone for being curious about the game, or interested in it's Legend of Zelda roots enough to warrant a purchase, but I can't deny that the game is disappointing. There are plenty of other minor complaints that I haven't listed in cons due to it becoming already apparent that I cannot recommend the game. Unintuitive obstacles and bugs aside, the game left me feeling more annoyed than satisfied.

21512609.review:
[b]*EDIT*[/b] [i](Improved the review)[/i]
If you're looking for a good Zelda-esque experience, look elsewhere.
I know people really want a good PC Zelda-style game, but Oceanhorn is very mediocre.
I am honestly puzzled as to why Oceanhorn has so many positive ratings, given how many clear faults it has.

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Decent Music.
-Solid Controls.
-Environment visuals are ok.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Extremely short dungeons.
-Uninteresting/Forgettable dungeon design. (Both in layout and visuals)
-Uninteresting items. (With the exception of Force Spell, and Trencher Boots.)
-No Overworld to speak of. (It's a glorified level-select)
-Boring sailing from island to island with almost no interactivity.
-No open exploration at all. (just level-unlocks hidden in other levels.)
-Terrible animation.
-One Spell has no animation at all.
-Bad voice-acting.
-Very limited enemy types.
-All of the enemies are too easy, including bosses.
-Late game enemies are very sword-spongy.
-Collectables take a long time to harvest, wasting time for no reason.
-No sense of urgency in the plot, ever. Because [b]*Mild Spoiler*[/b]: it does not actually progress at all until the absolute end of the game. (As an example: It is like if the entirety of "A Link to the Past" was spent just looking for your Uncle.)
-Shallow and uninteresting characters. (with the mild exception of the father due to narration on each island, but you never really get to know who he is, just that he did some stuff and has a kind of gravelly voice.)
-Painfully awkward "emotional" scenes, where you're supposed to really care about character(s) you've barely even seen before, let alone talked to.

[b]In Conclusion:[/b]
With all of these Cons, Oceanhorn still might be worth getting if it's on a [i]very[/i] steep sale, (ie. for $2.00 or less,) because the Dungeons are at least somewhat entertaining, and it is a mercifully short game. But it is [i]not[/i] in any way shape or form, worth anything close to full price.

21414450.review:
I bought Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas spontaneously, because I found the graphics interesting and because it reminded me of Zelda - I thought it deserved a shot, although I did think twice about buying it due it being slightly pricy. After two hours of playing it, I was hooked. I loved every bit of the game and I don't think my money could have been better spent.

What makes the game special? The parallels to Zelda games are numerous, but that doesn't have to be a minus. The game has its own charming character and still completely captures the fun of similar games. But I'm not here to talk about Zelda, I'm here to talk about what really fascinated me about Oceanhorn - the extraordinary art style, as well as the great atmosphere. Also, the puzzles in the game just had the perfect difficulty - not teeth-grindingly hard, but not pull-lever-and-win either. I've finished the game at 93% and have enjoyed 22 hours of wonderfully crafted exploration and RPG fun. Thank you Cornfox.

tl;dr: If you like Zelda, buy this game. If you like Zelda A LOT, don't get turned off by the games' Zelda-copying reputation. It has its own mind and it will give you the same magic spark as Zelda did. If you don't like Zelda, Jesus doesn't love you.

21225340.review:
Definitely a solid "worth if its on sale" game. If you're really craving a nice Zelda clone, its probably worth full price (though it can be a fairly short game, if you just beeline to the end like I did. There's a pretty big chunk of sidequests I skipped over - I only got about 50% completion overall)

It has some noticable flaws, though many of them are forgivable and understandable given that this is an indie game originally released for iOS.

The game has a good visual style which fits well with the level design. The isometric perspective, and 3D-but-blocky design create a somewhat unique gameplay style that fits somewhere between the 2D and 3D Zelda games.

This game has really got me wishing for a more fully-fledged successor, and for more indies to tackle 3D adventure games. For now though, Oceanhorn is pretty great.

21223897.review:
A lot of people tend to compare Oceanhorn with past installments of The Legend of Zelda series. I can understand why, but in my opinion, it evokes far fonder memories of an old beauty called Landstalker. The platforming style used in Oceanhorn mixed with it’s gorgeous graphics and expansive world make it a pleasure to play. Find our more in our Oceanhorn Monster of Uncharted Seas Review!

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas’ storyline is fairly basic. Boy’s father sets out to slay a twisted beast, boy heads out to find father, boy learns he needs to collects emblems of Earth, Ocean and Sol to help defeat said beasty, boy makes friends along the way, finds beefed up equipment to help him with his journey etc.

However, I feel that the true beauty of Oceanhorn isn’t the story. The storyline plays second fiddle to the satisfying exploration and combat system. The most enjoyment when playing Oceanhorn is from the many different islands you’ll visit and landscapes you’ll explore.

Environmentally speaking, each island is beautifully portrayed. One such island is covered in abysmal fog and rain, whereas another depicts an incredible rocky landscape. The islands are all unique and each hold their own secrets for you to uncover.

Some players notice when playing Oceanhorn that the whole thing really is quite reminiscent of Zelda games. The enemies are similar; certain characters seem to have walked straight in from another franchise; and the sailing mini-events that take place whilst traversing the ocean waters will have you thinking you’ve accidentally launched another game.

However, I implore you to ignore the feelings that you’ve played this before. Overlook the fact that some concepts seem borrowed, and think more along the lines that Oceanhorn is a culmination of different concepts brought together into one vast gaming experience.

Oceanhorn easily holds strong in today’s gaming world and delivers a fulfilling experience from both it’s gameplay and design.

[h1]Controllation (yes it’s a word)[/h1]

When playing the Steam version of Oceanhorn, the main character is controlled via the ‘WASD’ keys, whilst aiming and attacking is controlled by your mouse and mouse buttons.

Various equipment can be acquired throughout your journey that, not only plays an integral part in combat, but also helps in gaining access to areas of the game that would otherwise remain inaccessible. Such items come in the form of bombs that can be used to blow away boxes or rubble; and a bow and arrow that can be fired at strategically placed targets which act as buttons to open doors or move pillars out of your way.

There’s also a few spells to procure along the way, such as fire to melt ice, or a force spell which summons objects to the area you’ve aimed your cursor. There’s even a secret spell to unlock by obtaining a certain amount of items known as bloodstones. If you’re lucky to chance across one, it can be acquired by hacking away at it with your sword until it gets added to your inventory.

Box puzzles await your brain and act as a nice little break between taking on constantly respawning enemies. When completed, these box puzzles will reveal pathways to destinations unexplored or drop treasure chests that contain a nice little bonus of gold or XP.

Gold doesn’t seem to play much of a role in Oceanhorn but it’s still handy to accumulate. Merchants provide the service of stocking up your extra items, I.e. bombs, arrows etc. and they can also sell you extra hearts to increase your maximum health.

Levelling up is great fun because each level you reach will unlock a little extra bonus for the game. Some of these bonuses are gaining a gun to shoot monsters or obstacles when sailing around the world, or decreasing the amount of stamina used when blocking attacks.

Another thing I quite like about levelling up is the title rewarded with each level. For example at level ten, you’ll be given the title of “Voyager” and eventually you’ll work your way up to “Legend”.

But one of the most fun additions to journeying through your quest is fishing! Yes!! Everyone loves fishing in a game!

Basically at a certain point in the game you are awarded a fishing rod. Take this good ole fishing rod down to a body of water and commence your new adventure!

You’ll catch different kinds of fish and you’ll also be catching fish of differing lengths. The bigger the better.

Catch all species of fish and I wonder what happens…?

[h1]Combatitation (really? you don’t know this word?)[/h1]

The combat in Oceanhorn is simplistic in nature and does away with all the bells and whistles seen in some hack’n’slash games. Left click swings your sword; right click utilises whichever extra weapon/item you’ve got equipped; the ‘f’ key casts whichever spell you’ve equipped; left-shift brings up your shield to act as defence against attacks; and space-bar toggles sprint, picks up and throws an item or acts as the action key.

If you’re expecting a massive challenge from Oceanhorn, you might be a little disappointed. Monsters found throughout Oceanhorn aren’t that difficult. Some of them will do a lot of damage when they hit you, but you can always block those attacks with your shield. Most enemies will wait a few seconds before commencing their first attack which usually buys enough time to defeat them quickly.

Some enemies are a bit more dastardly and will manage to get a few hits in before you kill them. This will result in a heart or two of your health being taken away. Health can always be replenished from hearts that drop from monsters, or are found when destroying an object like a vase or cutting down grass. If you do end up dying, you’ll respawn at a previous checkpoint.

Thankfully, bosses happen to be quite engaging and fun! Each boss will tend to follow certain patterns or require you to perform a specific action before being allowed to damage them. However, bosses found earlier on in the game can be quite easy and you’ll find yourself being able to handle them with little difficulty. When you get further on in the game, the bosses become more challenging and you’ll be relying on your reflexes, as well as your gear, to dispatch them successfully.

[h1]Aesthetic Charm[/h1]

Graphically, Oceanhorn shines brightly. The environments and colours found throughout are gorgeously detailed and display beautifully on a sharp screen, be it computer or iPad.

Enemy design is well thought out and you can see that a lot of love has gone into their creation. Boss design is brilliant and each one brings it’s own flare to match the area you’re traversing perfectly.

The music is nice to listen to but certain areas might have you reaching for the mute button. In particular the Hermit’s Island. Sound effects aren’t too bad but some sounds, such as when your character runs out of stamina and starts puffing, come across as a bit forced and sound like it could have been done better.

Voice acting isn’t that great. The actors sound wooden and devoid of emotion. That’s why I preferred to play with subtitles on so I could still follow the story without having to listen to the dull voices.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]

In summary, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a splendid release from both FDG Mobile Games GbR (iOS version) and Cornfox & Bros. (Steam version). The whole game is a joy to play and would be best enjoyed by younger gamers as an introduction to RPGs.

The game’s main story takes around ten to fifteen hours to complete, but if you want to fully explore everything and get one-hundred percent complete, you’ll probably find yourself investing quite a few more hours.

Beautifully designed and superbly created, you’ll find yourself wanting to jump back into the world of Oceanhorn quite often. Definitely worth a look!

21220907.review:
Great little Zelda clone. Even though it's an iOS port, I didn't know that when I purchased the game and thoroughly enjoyed it. It's compared to Windwaker, but I never played that one, so I can't comment on that.

Pros: Works well for mouse, keyboard, or game pad. Decent graphics; nothing flashy, but about on par with a good GameCube game. Plenty of side content and extras to hunt for. Good challenge; not too difficult, not too easy. It's a bit on the easy side, but not disappointingly so. Some of the puzzles and encounters make you think. I encountered no glitches and was able to unlock all the achievements without issue. The different areas and dungeons are fairly diverse. Leveling up unlock new perks in all aspects of the game which is fun; only one level up seems to break the difficulty balance.

Cons: The sailing has no value in the game; it's little more than a mini game while you're loading the next island. Poor economy; once you access the shop, you've seen all there is to buy, No way to effectively use the mini-map; no zooming or marking points of interest. There's not a whole lot of monster variety.

For the price (especially if you can get it on sale), this game is worth the money if you're a Zelda-type fan.

21220581.review:
I expected this game to be so much more than it is, but sadly it's just a mildly entertaining zelda clone. The soundtrack and art style are both appealing, and you can tell the devs ripped a lot from Windwaker (one of my personal favorites), but thats probably the only good thing about this game. 21053095.review:
A very fun, if often fairly easy, Zelda-like puzzle game that is absolutely worth your time to play. Set in a world following a huge magical war, you set off in search of your father, who in turn is hunting a massive sea monster known as Oceanhorn. Follow in his footsteps as you gather some strange relics in order to finally have the power to confront the beast and perhaps find your father.

The story is fairly lighthearted and quirky, with a very Zelda-like feel. Characters are all sketched out very quickly and loosely, and you're expected to really like people quickly. I didn't always find this to always be the case, but warmed to what the story was aiming for pretty quickly. I'm about 2/3rds of the way through the game at time of speaking (as far as I can tell), and am looking forward to diving even further in to what this game has to offer.

Pros:
- Lighthearted, fun story, with a rich backstory and lore
- Controls are really solid for PC, especially with it being a mobile port (don't let that scare you off, the game looks and plays like a PC native game, and the price is more than fair)
- There's plenty of content to explore, lots of fun secrets, and cute puzzles
- Great unlocks as you progress, opening more of the game to you and rewarding players who note down places of interest earlier in the game.
- Interesting monsters to fight, with tactics to learn as you move forward.
- Some really fun boss fights!
- Graphics are charming

Cons:
- Your character's attacks are sometimes a bit unresponsive about specific directions
- The storytelling can be a bit weak sometimes
- Puzzles are occasionally quite unclear, and solutions are sometimes just finding a hidden button under some breakables
- Sailing is often pretty dull, which is a shame

Overall, this game is a solid 7.5/10 so far, and is well worth picking up and playing. The asking price is more than fair, but getting on a sale is just icing on top. Will update if necessary when I finish this game!

21041486.review:
First of all - I got 100% at this game and saw just about everything in it.

This game is something I'd recommend to every Legend of Zelda fan who has already played all Legend of Zelda games and searches for something alike. It has nicely created areas with fitting atmospheric music - the gameplay is very enjoyable and the puzzles are great!
I enjoyed sitting down and exploring the areas while trying to unlock achievement after achievement.
What probably was my biggest + was the fact that this game combined two of the things I love most in game, what is Leveling up (Collecting Xp) and a Zelda like combat.
Pros:
-Great looking Islands
-Beautiful Music
-Very good puzzles that also are appropriately difficult
-Good controls
-Achievements and ingame xp awards for getting those

Cons:
-Beginning is a little confusing (where to go next)
-Boss fights are sometimes more annoying than difficult (Angler >_> )
-Some explode-able walls are almost unfind-able
-Sorta short story

I finished this game after 14 hours with 100% and all Achievements unlocked - I enjoyed it a lot, and finished the game during 2 days on a weekend. Maybe not the longest game, but definitly worth picking up for everyone who calls himself a Zelda fan, consider doing it during a sale and you wont regret it!

21006932.review:
Oceanhorn is one of the best games I´ve played recently. Whereas most games have lovely ideas but lose the big picture, this game has, well, only a small idea but nails it. The idea: to make a smaller and indipendent version of "The Legend of Zelda". Some reviews compared it to The Wind Waker and they´re probably right. From the first to the very last moment you won´t get rid of the feeling that a certain Triforce and a green hat are missing. Nevertheless I´ll leave out comparisons and focus on the things that hit my eyes.

This game is not for hardcore adventure gamers, I fear, as it misses the great challenges. However, for beginners or "easy players" this game will be a great experience. You should read my notes under this assumption.

+ short game time: A fact I like most of the times is if a game doesn´t take too much time to complete it. There may be some collectables left, but I finished most of the game and the story after around 9 hours.
+ appropriate graphics: The game is designed lovely and nice to loook at
+ easy and accurate controls: Played on a controller, there were no difficulties and the buttons are occupied cleverly
+ easy puzzles: Whenever a chest is hidden or the way blocked, it won´t take a lot of experimenting to find the solution
+ lovely music: well-composed, supporting the settimg - you will love to listen to it
+ cute settings: suitable even for children
+ easy boss fights...

- ...which are really too easy. Once you found out the right tactic you can´t fail

As I said, Oceanhorn will not be the right game for hardcore gamers, however, fans of "The Legend of Zelda", beginners in the field of Adventure and lovers of cute stories will definitely have their fun with the game.

This is a Legend of Zelda copycat, which, on the face of it, shouldn't dissuade someone from playing this game. Although obviously a lot of work went into the game, including the art and sound, it feels like a bored intern stitched together stock game engine assets over the course of a few afternoons, said "it's good enough", and released it.

Of course it's still plenty playable, and somewhat fun to boot, but I can't recommend someone purchase this game unless there's really not much else to do.

20576159.review:
While this game is undoubtedly fun and charming, it has a number of rough edges that make it fall short of the franchise that it unashamedly mimics. A few examples:

1) Generally low difficulty and complexity in puzzles. 
2) When destructible terrain comes into play, the "weak points" in a wall or structure are often only vaguely hinted at, ultimately encouraging the player to pepper entire areas with bombs in an attempt to uncover secrets.
3) Outside of boss fights, combat is usually a cakewalk, with lost health being easily and switfly replenished when you do make a mistake. Yet there are a few isolated instances in which a single mistake during a boss fight will kill you outright, regardless of how many hearts you have collected.
4) When fighting certain foes, a projectile counter-attack mechanic can (and some times MUST) be used. But the accuracy/efficiency of this counter-attack is based entirely on luck, rather than skill.

Ultimately, you will get more quality and longevity out of a genuine Zelda title, but Oceanhorn is still a fun and engaging romp that will keep you entertained for a few days.

... Just be sure to bring a controller. The mouse+keyboard control scheme sucks.

20554688.review:
Análisis a día 16 de enero de 2016:

No llevo muchas horas jugadas, pero lo que he visto por el momento me está gustando.

El juego no empieza con un argumento demasiado elaborado, ofrece la excusa necesaria para justificar el inicio de una aventura: una extraña energía sale a la luz, un monstruo poderoso anda suelto y tú, el héroe elegido, emprendes una búsqueda que te llevará hacia Oceanhorn y a descubrir qué fue de tu padre.

La estética, jugabilidad, ángulos de cámara y diseño de personajes me recuerdan demasiado a Zelda de Nintendo DS, concretamente al título "Phantom Hourglass". No sé si es un guiño a la saga o una copia descarada que imita un modelo que funcionó bastante bien.

El escenario es variado a nivel visual, y se reparte en mazmorras y habitaciones pequeñas, espacios más grandes y abiertos, y un mapa por el cual desplazarnos de un lugar a otro en un viaje automático en el que no podremos dirigir el barco pero sí disparar a los monstruos u obstáculos que nos salgan al paso.
En tierra hay bastantes desniveles y plataformas escalonadas. Actualmente no me es posible saltar, no sé si se podrá saltar y sortear obstáculos más adelante, de momento lo que llevo jugado obliga a dar rodeos y a buscar un camino que tenga una escalera o una cuesta.


ASPECTOS POSITIVOS:

-Apartado gráfico muy cuidado, bonito y colorido.

-Cámara estática, casi cenital (salvo en el modo de viaje en barco), que no da problemas. Los escenarios se han creado pensando en ser vistos desde ese ángulo y no es difícil orientarse. En general pueden encontrarse objetos, interruptores y caminos con facilidad.

-Música agradable y diversos efectos de sonido.

-No he experimentado bugs ni crashes ni problemas de ningún tipo mientras jugaba.

-En general es ideal para niños dada su violencia edulcorada y la ausencia de contenido sexual.

-Se parece a Zelda de Nintendo DS (suponiendo que guste esta estética).


ASPECTOS NEGATIVOS

-La mecánica de juego es bastante simple, los enemigos no ofrecen dificultad alguna y los puzzles son sencillos. Esto no tiene por qué ser necesariamente algo negativo si lo que se busca es un modo de juego relajado.

-Tal vez su aspecto infantil pueda ser un punto en contra para aquellos jugadores que busquen algo más adulto o dinámico.

-Se parece a Zelda de Nintendo DS (suponiendo que no guste esta estética o que no agrade encontrarse con una imitación barata).


VALORACIÓN GENERAL:

Una joya visual con una dificultad de juego baja y creada con mucho mimo. Te la recomiendo si te gustó Zelda Phantom Hourglass.

20551592.review:
This game was originally released for the ipad and now ported to PC. In general I tend to find those two things normally equate to that of total crap. Surprisingly however, Oceanhorn stands out as a shining example of how a solid port should be done.

No hiding the fact it's a total Wind Waker clone. Pretty much everything in this game draws direct connection from much of the Zelda series. Trying to fill those shoes can be a pretty huge task, which it at least does a pretty good job of emulating. It manages to capture the nice open colorful world in the same fashion as Zelda. The characters, monsters and bosses are fairly creative. Most of what you encounter tries to mimic the art style of Zelda quite closely. Not quite as charming of course, although to be fair it'd be hard to live up to some of the most beloved games of all time completely. 

Sometimes you can sense a bit of the restraints from this game originally being intended for the ipad. The combat is good, but I feel like it's not quite as fluid or polished as it could have been. Had it not been originally designed around the ipad. For the most part at least it comes off rather well on the PC using a controller. It also allows for the use of mouse an keyboard controls. 

Unlike Zelda, Oceanhorn features a leveling system. Gaining a level can result in earning coins an item refills, increasing the number of bombs you can carry, but it also serves to unlock other things such as a cannon item for your sail boat early on. The boat is your main source of transportation for island hopping around the world. Travelling by boat is done on a rail system unlike the free roaming in Wind Waker. I guess to try to make the travel portions a bit less dull, they decided to add in things like explosive mines and enemies along with crates and things you can shoot for experience and coins as you travel along. This portion can become a bit tedious at times. 

The music is nice and the game looks good enough for what it's intended to be. Saving is done either automatically when entering a new area or when activating checkpoints. Not having the option to save manually however can be a little annoying. The game itself is pretty forgiving however. If you find yourself being killed, you're automatically transported back to the location of your last checkpoint save, while retaining any items and exp you collected beforehand. For the most part the difficulty is rather mild.

In the end for what faults it does have I would still recommend this to any fan of the Zelda series. All in all it's bit like a smaller Wind Waker lite. It does do a pretty good job in filling a nice niche, in which it's hard to find many similiar games on the PC. If you're looking for something to fill that Zelda-esque desire you probably won't regret buying Oceanhorn. Overall I'd rate this game at maybe a close 7 out of 10. Probably won't wow you, but enjoyable enough to be worth the time.

[b]Let me first just say, I'm a massive 'Legend of Zelda' fan. 100% completed all LoZ games apart from Triforce Heroes.[/b]
I've been looking for a LoZ type of game and I came across this amazing game. It reminded me of 'Wind Waker' (The art style, ocean, the boat.) Has elements of 'A link to the past' (birds eye view, lots of spells.) and the DS style LoZ games (When you open doors with keys, some puzzles.) as well as 'Skyward Sword' (Floating island, Durability with shield / running.) Even Twilight Princess (The clothing you wear, hair style, Fishing rod.)

[b]What is good about the game.[/b]
-Art style.
-Very LoZ inspired.
-Unique story.
-Unique Leveling system to earn extras.
-Some what has challenging puzzles.
-Amazing soundtrack.
-IT HAS HEART PIECES/CONTAINERS!
-Challenges/quest/task to complete to earn more exp / achivements.
-Can be difficult at times.
-The ability to see where chest are on your map without use of compass like LoZ.
-Durability when hit while holding shield/running. (Shield doesn't break it's more like stamina bar/meter.)
-Just fun to play.
(The List could go on and on. So many positives.)

[b]What I though could of been improved.[/b]
-Movement. (Feels just slow.)
-You have to unlock the ability to jump and roll. (So worth the wait though as I can now get chest and objects I couldn't before.)
-The odd one or two areas you can get yourself stuck and have to exit the game to get out.
-You will attack something and it doesn't always register you hit. (Could just be me but has happend will fighting.)

[b]Do I recommend this game?[/b]
I fully recomend this game to anyone who has played and enjoyed the LoZ franchise as well as adventure rpg type games. Worth the money and the gameplay.

Here's my opinion on Oceanhorn. It's a beautiful looking game, it has a great soundtrack, and when you first play it you will love it. That being said, you quickly find out, this game is not all it appears to be, it tries to be a Zelda game, that just lacks some elements that make a Zelda game good.

First off all the island hopping is just obnoxious, given the fact that when you hop on your boat, you don't even get to travel around the sea, you pick the island you are wanting to go to, and it just sails you there and gives you some "mini-game" that you can play to kind of give you something to do while you travel between islans.

Back to the whole island hopping thing, this isn't something you do once, maybe twice, it's almost like every island has SOMETHING on another island that you have to go to and get just to progress through the first island, and sometimes you have to go to a third island, because you haven't gone through the second island yet to get the item for the first island.

To be honest, i wanted to like this game, i really did, but there was just too many things about it, or too many of a couple thigns really, that just ruined the game for me, personally this game for me, is what makes me wish most, if not all games on steam had a demo, just so i knew what i was getting before buying it.

19644280.review:
Blah blah Zelda Blah Blah

Oceanhorn takes place in an archipelago inhabited by several sentient races. From fish dudes to eagle people. From several types of humans to even machines. Also the occasional demon. There're also ghosts in the postgame dungeon. Like all video games, it starts out peacefully but everything turns to hell and some random kid with a destiny has to save the world. To do that, you hunt an ancient relic from the technologically advanced past named Oceanhorn but there's a twist...which I'll save for those who play the game.

The main character is the aptly named Main Character (or Hero). At the start of the game, his father writes a note saying how his (the father's) destiny is linked to Oceanhorn, which also means the Hero's destiny is too because that's how video games work). He then goes to attack a giant robotic crab. The Hero then wakes up on a different island inhabited by one guy named Hermit who sends you on your way to avenge your father and save the world. All the while a Black Boat stalks you from just off screen except when plot demands otherwise. 

The game then continues like all action games: you visit scenic locals; a desert, a dense forest, some ruins, a quaint little town, a floating rock, etc. and you upgrade your gear, learn to use magic, and learn just how special you are because your parents are doubly special. Once in a while, you fish or throw plants at the head of their gardener/Hero's love interest because you (as the player) are a sociopath. 

The controls are exceptional for a game that was originally an iOS game – at least with an X-box controller. The only issue that can, and totally will, happen is how easy it is to fall off a ledge and have to redo entire sections of dungeons again. It's not game breaking but it can be annoying having to back track several screens because you were pushed off a small walkway or you just got to close to pick something up or to avoid another thing. It's great that being able to jump down ledges is a thing – it allows for a bit of a different type of exploration – but it's frustrating to no end when you've done it too many times. Other than that, combat is fairly fluid. Arrows and magic go where you send them and there are never too many enemies on screen to make one have to panic. The puzzle aspects don't interfere with combat when they're intermingled (meaning boss battles). 

Sadly, the plot isn't all there. I'm not saying there are any plotholes but some of it just feels rushed and just didn't feel deep to me. A random girl suddenly being your love interest is the most obvious one. It's not a main plot in the story so it might just be something that bothered me slightly and you might be totally fine with it. The game is all narrative which, is fine, but it's easy to miss things or important information can be easily forgotten. For example, if you don't talk to the correct people or find certain bottles then certain side quests aren't going to be available to you. Nothing story related is missable but you might not get to full health, arrow/bomb capacity, or challenge completion (if you're into that though, you're probably using a guide). The game keeps going after you beat the main boss so even then, you can go back and find what you want to. Nothing is permanently missable. Some of this might just be mobile limitations that unfortunately show in this PC port. I don't do a lot of mobile gaming so I'm not sure what is and what isn't great. 

Music is a very subjective subject but I can say that I found it to be perfect. It fits the mood and helps provide immersion. Nobuo Uematsu wrote a track for the OST so that's all you really need to know. I like to add official sources where one can preview it so here's a link. 

[url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHFXufiOhqkAstu8CibFvEw/videos]Youtube[/url]

This is Cornfox & Bros first RPG (and second game after a top-down Carmageddon/Twisted Metal style remake – [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/108700/]Death Rally[/url]) and these Finnish developers already have my attention. I'm looking forward to anything they might release in the future. Zelda games don't come out very often so go pick this up if you're feeling a lull or just want a short, fun adventure. $15 might be a little too steep for some but remember, holidays and summers are always just around the corner.

This game is really close to good... but it's not quite there. 
It's very much Zelda Windwaker, but there are a few things that that the game does not do well. One of the huge ones is in Zelda when you need something (heart, bomb, arrow...) and you're out of them, one of the next few pots will have it. In this game it's a complete crapshoot. You might be completely full of mana and have only half a heart, and get 10 pots in a row that only contain mana or coins. This is especially annoying during boss fights. 
Speaking of boss fights, that's the only time the camera does anything interesting - and it can make finding those pots extremely difficult.
So it's a game on very small islands... but your character can only swim for about 5 feet. I'd think that someone who lived on an island their whole life would be able to swim for more than a few seconds. And you can only sprint for about 5 feet too.
The game is really close to good... it's just not quite there. I found a lot of points needlessly frustrating because the game doesn't always lead you in the right direction. One time trying to exit an island, I died a half dozen times because there was no obvious path out - which I later found hiding behind a tree.

19081455.review:
[h1]A Paladin’s Review: Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas. A Disappointing Sea of Content and a Boring Combat System.[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: Isometric Adventure RPG.
[*]Developed and Published by: Cornfox & Bros. 
[*]Platform: iOS, Windows and Mac OSX
[*]Business Model: Base Game.
[*][i]Copy Purchased by Myself[/i] 
[/list]
[i][url=http://wp.me/p4fZDz-2u2]Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/i]

[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is an isometric RPG clearly inspired by the Legend of Zelda series, at least the isometric/Game Boy versions. Everything from the lock-on sword play, the story about a hero gaining three valued artifacts of power to overthrow a growing evil and much of the visual design shows that inspiration in spades. Due to that inspiration, the comparisons to the Zelda series are easy to make. I hate to say this but more often than not, Oceanhorn doesn’t compare well. Whether by limitation of the iOS platform or the inexperience of the developers, a lot of ideas and mechanics were pale imitations of what’s been done before.

[b]Story Thoughts[/b]
The story is ok at best. It’s a traditional story of a young boy who goes out to find the three magical Emblems of the Elements and put a stop to an evil entity. At first, we’re introduced to Father, who goes out to fend off a living fortress known as Oceanhorn and what happens to him is ultimately unknown. After gathering Father’s sword & shield as well as preparing yourself for sailing, Hero goes out to gather these circles. He has Father’s journal with him which will narrate a little bit every time you visit an important island. Hero goes to a forest island, a desert island and an island in the sky to collect all three magical sources of power. Along the way, Hero meets two different races that have fallen into ruin due to the evil machinations of Mesmeroth and some of minions. So, through some dungeon crawling, Hero will eventually right those wrongs done and those races will eventually rise from defeat….in maybe another game. Once the pieces of the puzzle are assembled, with help from Hermit along the way, Hero will go to Father and fight Mesmeroth once and for all. During this quest, a few side characters will come in and out of the story but otherwise, Hero is on his own for this journey. Having only the guidance of Father’s journal and the power of the elements to “guide” him. The emblems are only in the game to push the story along, nothing else.

[b]Combat Thoughts[/b]
The combat has the worst problems. Using a sword and shield most of the time, you’ll have a lot of slap fights with bullet-spongy (sword-spongy?) enemies in the game. They will often require a ton of hits to bring down and there are a lot of enemies per level which also happen to respawn rather quickly. It definitely feels like grinding through a level, if the experience system didn’t make that particularly obvious. Bloodstones in particular, while not enemies, seem to require 20 or so sword attacks to collect. Why? I don’t know but I thought that was a waste of time. As far as blocking projectiles/attacks with the shield, this seemed to be hit and miss on which attacks would and wouldn’t be blocked, leading to a constant source of frustration while fighting. As a whole, the system works and you can get through the game. But it’s not going to be a whole lot of fun. Oh and there are spells which are used for some puzzles and can be used for the fights. However, I found they often used far too much mana so I usually only used them for puzzles. This is thanks to the lack of an adaptable inventory system. There’s no bottles you can hang onto to replenish health or mana, everything has to be found in the levels. It makes boss fights a lot less interesting as well. 

[b]PC Settings & Port Report[/b]
It’s got a pretty OK selection of options. You have four different graphic presets including low to ultra. There’s a bunch of different options that turns various objects including clouds and soft shadows on/off. V-sync and anti-aliasing is included. Fullscreen and borderless windowed are here as well with a reasonable choice of resolutions. FPS can be set to 30 or 60 FPS locked/unlocked. In the pause screen, you can adjust speech, effects and music with individual sliders. You might want to consider lowering the music slider which I’ll explain later on. Keyboard and mouse work ok with Oceanhorn but it feels off. Not that controller is a lot better either. Some of the action keys can be rebound but the implementation limits where they can go. Mouse keys can only be rebound to other mouse keys and the same goes for keyboard ones. Why did we decide this was a good idea? No clue. It’s a big no-no.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Ultimately, the frustrating part about Oceanhorn is how much this game treads the same ground so many others have in this genre. Sure, it’s one of the better iOS to PC ports I’ve seen in a long time. There’s nary a mention about touching the screen or buying microtransactions in the App Store and I respect that. Unfortunately, the game still suffers problems inherent to the mobile platform. It’s a mechanically boring game that’s a chore to get through rather than an experience to be enjoyed. The gameplay is filled with repetitive and somewhat unresponsive gameplay that completely lacks meaningful feedback to hook the player in. The optimization is questionable too. The story, honestly, the story feels like it was missing a chunk of itself. There are two dimensional characters abound and its hard to stir myself into getting interested while I’m playing. 

Oceanhorn was just a drag to get through, especially towards the end. The entire time, I was constantly reminded of what this game could have been instead of what it was doing. I was constantly disappointed every time a new mechanic was introduced or an area shown. Most of the time, what they had implemented was done on the most basic of levels, giving me nothing to sink my teeth into. Other reviewers constantly talk about how much this is like Legend of Zelda except on an iPad. This, at best, is a passing imitation to that series. I myself cannot recommend Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas. 

[h1][url=http://wp.me/p4fZDz-2u2]Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/h1]

Good game, looks good and gives provides a decent amount of fun. Still, I am not so happy with it as other reviewers. This is a Zelda clone, ok, maybe the story is original, and the voices are pretty good too, but there are so many things just exactly like you would find in a Zelda game, chests, heart containers, mirror shield, coins, even a tryforce reference. I'm fine with subtle references, but this is too much, it's not that hard to come up with something different and original. Then there's also the dungeon and puzzles design, which are kind of dull, but it gets better later in the game.

Another annoying thing is the controls, which relies too much on the physics engine, the player moves around kind of slow and it feels weird when going up stairs, because the weight and gravity makes the character move slower and even it seems like it gets stuck. You get used after a while, but still feels weird.

I understand that this game was made by very few people, but that doesn't justify anything, this game needs more polish.

Despite all that, I liked it and I would recommend it, as I said, the game is fun and the story is not bad.

18883715.review:
Oceanhorn immediately caught my attention as an IOS game. I eagerly awaited the Android release because of the rave reviews and many comparisons to Zelda. When it came to Steam, I said "good enough" and made the purchase. Mistake.

On its face, Oceanhorn has a cute art style and interesting Zelda-like premise. Evil monster, father killed, dungeons, items, puzzles, bosses, you get the drift. But from the moment you set foot on your home island the first time, the game clobbers you with a very un-Zelda feel. 

To say this game's controls feel clunky, does not really convey the true badness of how this game plays. Moving your character around is a chore, and dodging enemy attacks is almost impossible. Fortunately, that is not really an issue, because 90% of the enemies are dumber than a bag of hammers and so slow to act that there are no attacks to dodge. The few enemies who are actually a threat to you are easily dealt with using items that are far too powerful to make any part of this game a challenge.

The boss fights are really the true disappointment. In almost every boss fight, the game switches perspective to lock the camera so that it always faces the boss. This was kind of interesting, but when most of the bosses have no attacks except to charge at you in a way that almost feels like they're bored, it really lets down. I never took a single point of damage from a boss until about 3/4 of the way through a game when a boss pleasantly offered a real challenge. This boss, the lone exception, features battle mechanics that require weakening him and avoiding his counterattacks. Part of the challenge comes from the camera always changing perspective while he's shooting at you, but hey, I'll take it.

There are more annoying gameplay elements, like the completely-extraneous boat travels scenes between islands that took 3-6 minutes of firing an infinite-ammo gun at every single thing that isn't water. The challenge is so low for this part that I don't understand the point. It is not fun and adds nothing to the game or story.

The plot for this game is plagiarized from Generic Adventure Game. Literally nothing surprising happens. Ever. 

Comparing this game to Zelda is like comparing a Ferrari California to a Chevy Cobalt. Yes they are both sports cars, but that hardly puts them in the same category. Save your money.

Great game altogether, however I'm going to say 3 out of 5 stars. Here's the pros and cons from my experiences of the game:

PROS
- great story, it follows through very well despite the side quests
- Graphics are A+ from what I can manage on my computer. However...
- a lot of chances to explore and the way you sail around really does remind me of LoZ: Windwaker. Although...
- FISHING! I love fishing, and I'm a fan of collecting.
- Dungeons reward you for exploring everywhere.
- Boss battles are challenging, yet still easy for casual play.

CONS
- [b]Graphics:[/b] Despite the game being visually appealing, I was forced to lower the resolution because the game would go haywire if I went to better graphics. The screen would flicker and the game screen would black out like some creepy haunted video. 
- [b]Movement:[/b] The character moves too slow sometimes, making me wish there was more of a dashing chance without it eating up stamina so quickly. It wasn't fun walking around a boss and hoping they wouldn't hit you and kill you so quickly.
-[b] Camera Angles: [/b]The biggest reason I can't give a better score on this game. In my fight with Mesmeroth's Spirit, when you're trying to wack the little flaming orbs to find him, the camera angle would TWIST YOUR VISUALITY AROUND SO MUCH that you would STRUGGLE just trying to simply hit all the orbs. I couldn't hit them in time because THE CAMERA WOULDN'T LET ME. I died many times because of this. :(
- The second time I was fighting the fish boss, he got stuck on one of the pillars and couldn't move. It ensured my victory...but...
- [b]Exploration[/b] - I love exploring. The map is great and going everywhere is fun, but I wish instead of going on a set course, you could sail on your own. It'd have a more Windwaker feel, but it'd also feel nostalgic.

Either way, great game!

17736810.review:
Lets get the big one out of the way here. Yes, its basically Wind Waker.

However, its less 'obvious knock off' and more 'loving tribute'. The themes, art style, and combat are all so fucking Zelda that it's a wonder the King of Hyrule hasn't filed a restraining order (or had the offending person beheaded because, y'know, king), but its all done very well and offers a few things that the Zelda franchise actually doesn't use like a level-up system that rewards the player with new equipment that directly enhances gameplay.

Some of the monsters are a bit of a bitch to fight, especially the big goblins early on, but once you learn their attack patterns you'll be okay.

While this game got it's start on iTunes as a mobile game, the PC port is distinctly better because you can actually use a gamepad instead of touch screen controls. I remember having this on my iPad and giving up because it was too frustrating to try to  play with them, then coming on here and having bosses that'd taken multiple attempts go down in a single shot because I wasn't cursing at the little directional pad on my touch screen for ignoring my thumb completely.

So is it worth it? Yes, I'd say so. If you like Zelda but are bored of waiting for Nintendo to release the new Wii U one this'll probably tide you over. A good solid Zelda-style game.
