17515472.review:
This is a great game for those who long for another Zelda game reminicent of the SNES / N64 style but amped up graphics and gameplay.  Zelda veterans will find the gameplay natural, as if an extension of an actual Zelda game.  The puzzles work very similar if not the same, items are familiar, core objectives are mostly the same.  Veterans will also find this game a bit easier, and therefore feels a little too short; even with the extra level from the "Game of the Year Edition".  Zelda noobs (are there any?) will be eased into the genre without being overwhelmed by the puzzles which are significantly more difficult in parts of the Zelda series.  Then go tackle all the Zelda you can get your hands on...please.  This is a great game to play in addition to any of them. 16948651.review:
OVERVIEW

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is an RPG, fantasy mobile game that was ported to Steam in 2015. The story is simple - find your father. The execution is effective, making this one of my favorite games. Let's take a look at why.

PROS
- The story is basic, but never boring or cliched. Subtle, yet deep. Characters are well-done and engaging. I really look forward to the development between the hero and heroine in the sequel, as well as seeing his father and others grow.
- Overall, at least as far as story advancement is concerned, the difficulty level is pretty good. It may be a bit high when it comes to finding all bloodstones and such, but, overall, it's solid.
- Gameplay is enjoyable, with multiple weapons and basic puzzles to solve.
- Boss fights are pretty well done, though the last boss might should be a little harder. The boss before him was actually harder.
- The game's morality is solid. No bad content of any kind (profanity, sexual content, etc.), solid view of right and wrong, no female warriors, etc.
- The graphics are excellent, though the frame rates do seem a bit low.
- Trading cards!
- Lots of content. I got all of the achievements, and almost 100% completion, with about 20 hours of gameplay...Walkthroughs helped. ;-) But a better gamer than me may not need them. It will provide a lot of game time nonetheless.
- Music is excellent.
- Being able to progress in pretty much any order you like is nice.
- Island designs are good.

CONS
- No jumping, excepts across ledges, and only then with "trencher boots."
- No long-term swimming in deep water (even though he can swim indefinitely in shallow water). These two things are actually, I think, the worst design flaws of the game. They're only there because the gameplay model needs it.
- No story after defeating the final boss. You were supposed to do something with the heroine, which I really wanted to do, but I guess that's for the sequel. :-) It would be nice if people would talk about how you defeated the monster and all that jazz.
- Fishing might should be a tad bit easier, though, if you change up spots a lot, which is good fishing advice, anyway, it's fine.
- Being able to control the boat would be nice.
- There's no sequel yet! D-: So, yeah, I loved this game.

CONCLUSION

Oceanhorn is well worth the money, with a good story, solid gameplay, nice graphics, and an enjoyable soundtrack. The world is immersive, never feeling dull, but like a real adventure. I highly recommend it - buy it today!

Thanks for reading my review; I hope you found it helpful. Have a great day, and Godspeed!

16946442.review:
*[b]Disclaimer:[/b] Review originally written for [url=http://walawalagames.com/]WalaWala Games[/url]. 

In Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas you start your gameplay as a young man who wakes up to find his father gone; he disappeared after going in search of a monster known as Oceanhorn. With only your father's notebook and your mother's mysterious necklace as clues, you set off in his search and thus begins the adventure.

Oceanhorn is a very nice casual action/adventure RPG, complete with puzzles, which is quite reminiscent in many ways to Legend of Zelda. The gameplay revolves around you finding clues from NPCs, battling monsters, solving puzzles and collecting keys and treasures from the different islands around the vast world while you search for your father and discover more to the story and lore of the place. The story and lore might not be too in-depth, but it's deep enough to keep you going through the game.

As I understand it this game was first made for iOS and then ported to PC, and although the port and game play are smooth enough that you might not have realized it, you can tell it was meant to be mobile by the way certain things work - such as in moving the world map, sliding the menu and other specific touch screen features.

Although the developers lean to the simplistic side, the game's graphics are beautiful: bright, colorful, and they feel quite alive. There is something definitely cute about all the characters you encounter and the sights are gorgeous. The way all islands are a bit different, each with their own little biome, some even with weather, adds interest to the gameplay and makes visiting each one a slightly unique experience. This spontaneous element helps keep it from being tedious.

The music was also wonderful, fitting to the world and the islands. The voice acting was a bit hit and miss, but for the most it was pretty good. I just wish the main character would have spoken, too.

The camera I found a bit annoying at first, as it's not free roam; you can only move it a little bit left and right, but I got used to it quickly and it did not hinder my enjoyment in the end. The camera follows you during boss battles too, which was both extremely helpful (as it did not get in my way), and extremely dizzying when my main strategy was “back up in circles and wait for an opening”.

Having tried both ways I can definitely say that the game plays a lot better with a controller, still, I used my keyboard through most of my play through without any major issues. The key distribution is decent enough and, if I’m not mistaken, you were able to rebind certain keys.

Starting up the game for the first time I could see the menu was simplistic, which was good and fitting for the game; but I was not overly pleased with the windowed mode option. The only option available was "Windowed (borderless)", which was... still defaulting to full screen as I could not even change the resolution for it (but I could change the resolution for full screen). However, I read the developers were working on this. I'll be happy to see the option to use regular windowed mode to play it, hopefully in different resolutions.

The world, as I already mentioned, is quite large. You get several islands to explore, but the islands must be unlocked first by talking to NPCs. If you're not paying much attention to what they say, it'll be easy for you to get a bit lost on which of two (or more) options you're supposed to go to first in order to follow the main story line; still, at most you'll need to do some backtracking. The game has a few tutorial bits (conveyed to you through little signs and pop ups), yet some things were still learn-as-you-go, such as how to deal with the world map.


To travel from island to island you sail a ship. I quite liked the idea of this initially - there'll be monsters to shoot at and boxes to sink. Once more I was reminded of Zelda with this. The first couple of trips are quite nice, however, it soon becomes a bit bothersome to go from island to island, even once your ship gets upgraded to sail faster. I think it might have been much more entertaining if we'd been able to steer the ship ourselves (auto-pathing and steering both as options would have been fantastic!). This would have made it more interactive than just sitting there and shooting at things. It's not much of a challenge to get to your destination though, just like the majority of puzzles are not much of a challenge either. They're good, but they're simple: perfect for a casual gamer such as me. Yet if you're into hard, challenging puzzles, you might find oceanhorn a bit disappointing.

Interacting with items was fun: everything that could be hit or bumped into would wobble, which I found was super cute. You could even bump into people (as opposed to getting stuck by running into them), a little detail that I quite love in games. The way interaction with picking objects worked though was a bit annoying, since the attack button would suddenly serve the function of picking and tossing an object if you were near it; thus, if you were in the middle of slashing your sword away at an enemy and walked by a rock, you would end up getting the rock instead and thus getting hit by the enemy. That you could not walk off large cliffs to your early death was also quite nice and a little feature I was thankful for more than once. Be careful if you choose to go swimming in the ocean, though, as your character will quickly run out of stamina and drown.

The fighting system was quite easy to get a handle of, and I found myself thankful for the little auto-target while defending, at least most the times. Sometimes it would lock me into the wrong target though and leave me open to a second attacker I was more interested in defending myself from. I liked the way the character leveled up, but it was a bit odd that his leveling did not modify the way his hits affected monsters. Stuff that took 3 hits to kill would still take three hits on level 1 or level 5. It wasn't too troublesome as the enemies are easy to defeat, but I thought it was a bit odd. Even though you can explore the islands, the game is rather linear, needing some interactions to happen first before you can unlock others.

The mini-bosses require a bit of strategy, but are also not overly challenging once you get the handle on them. Once again this makes it good for casual gamers and the younger crowd, but those seeking challenges might not have as much fun with it. In whole, the game offers you just about 10 hours of gameplay to finish it without any side-questing or aimless exploring, and some 4-6 hours more if you’re a completionist.

Oceanhorn plays quite nicely in older PCs and I kind of like the way things spawn on your screen as you come closer to them, slowly popping into the map with their little bouncy animation. It adds to the overall cartoony cuteness of the game. It also helps that it has an extremely small size (at ~380mb) so it's quick to install and start playing it.

I heard some talk about crashes and bugs, but to be honest I did not experience any such. At most I experienced a bit of lag when video sections began or ended, but that was about it and it and it did not occur all the time. The game was truly fun and a delight to play. If you’re looking for a relaxing, casual RPG, I definitely recommend it!

Brief Summary: Extremely similar to Zelda games of yore (LTTP etc) that is hampered only by it's lack of length and items variety. The game consists of a handful of dungeons and towns with with inter island travel very similar to Zelda Wind Waker. The game relies on arrows, throwing jars, and bombs, and even sports its own version of the master sword as an example of how similar they are.

Over all score from me: 7.5/10, a worth while adventure for any Zelda style game fan.

Break down:

Graphics: 8/10

Solid graphics, again extremely "Zelda" in nature but enjoyable none the less. It has a simple cartoonish style similar to  Zelda Windwaker without the cell shading.

Music and audio: 6/10

It's not bad by any means. The music is okay, but is not memorable. It serves its purpose without adding much more. Voice acting is similar in that it gets the job done, but I did not find it memorable or overly well done. 

Controls/Playability: 8/10

I played with a controller, and I'd recommend playing it that way. Controls are responsive and natural. There were only a few times I was frustrated with the ability to aim at objects in the distance, otherwise the game will largely correct aim on your behalf.

Do I recommend it:

Heck yes. My biggest complaint is the length, beating it in just 8 hours of total play time without referencing any outside guides. I'd like to of have given more of such a good thing.

16715858.review:
Ah, yes, [strike]The Legend of Zelda[/strike] [b]Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas[/b]
I've played this game for about an hour and a half, and I feel like I'm playing some weird mix of the Legend of Zelda: Link Between Worlds and Phantom Hourglass. My nameless little Link clone handles well on foot. Combat feels good, I never felt like I got killed by something because of the way the game is designed. I do wish I had more control over the camera, that isometric perspective is sometimes hard to navigate. The animation is a tad rough in some of the cutscenes/enemy animations. And there's voice acting. I'll let you decide if that's a good thing or not.
I'd recommend a 360 gamepad, the keyboard/mouse controls felt really awkward. There's a Pause button mapped to the Back button, which is really handy during the story telling. Also, you can go back and watch cutscenes if you want.

16715452.review:
Overall this is a fairly good game and I enjoyed most of my time playing it. The main story happens at a reasonable pace and doesn't involve too much backtracking. Going for the 100% completionist, though, stretches out the gameplay to the point where it starts to become tedious and less enjoyable.

The general combat is fairly decent though it's not very responsive, dynamic, or varied. Hack n' Slash is holy writ for the most part. One [b]major[/b] gripe I have with general play is that enemy loot doesn't spawn until a second or two later when the enemy bodies have despawned; this means you have to force yourself to wait around after killing something, backtrack, or ignore the loot. On the plus side the experience "drop" is an automatic pickup even if in the grand scheme of things not worth much (you get most of your XP from [i]doing[/i] stuff, not [i]killing[/i] stuff.

I greatly appreciated that there wasn't One Way to defeat bosses, largely because that way would result in longer and more tedious fights. Many of the boss fights had a particular gimmick to disarm them based on the arena but this effect could be replicated by bombs, arrows, and/or magic. On the other hand there isn't much depth to any of the fights except the very last one as all the others are just 'disarm, bash-bash-bash-bash-bash, disarm, bash-bash-bash-bash-bash, disarm, bash-bash-bash-bash-bash, done'. Despite that I'm still not sure how I beat the final boss (deus ex machina, literally).

Its style shares vague similarities to Wind Waker but it lacks a certain depth that Zelda games tend to have. There's only basic gadgets, half of the spells are unnecessary, and the fishing mini-game is largely there just to pad the XP growth potential (you can't sell the fish, they can't be used in any way, and none of the NPCs care what happens, but you get tons of extra XP the first time you catch a fish type).

My personal recommendation is to get it on sale, play through the main story, maybe track down some heart pieces for the final boss, and leave it at that.

16626777.review:
The Good:
- Art design and music lend perfectly to the genre. The game obviously emulates Zelda, but it also reminds me of other classics like Landstalker (Genesis) and Alundra (PS1).  If you’re into these types of games, you’ll definitely enjoy what Oceanhorn has to offer.  

- Certainly, the upgrades and variety of gadgets could have been more robust and there could have been more towns to explore, but as a five hour experience (if you're just focused on the main story), Oceanhorn didn’t need these extra elements to be enjoyable.    

- Unlike other reviewers, I really liked the sailing segments. It’s essentially an on-rails shooting gallery that gives the player an opportunity to refill their inventory and health before reaching a new island. 

The Bad:
- For the most part, Oceanhorn ran smoothly; however, there were a few times during my play through that the frame rate plummeted. This occurred mostly when entering the towns, but thankfully it only lasted for ten to twenty seconds before returning back to normal speed.  

- This game desperately needed an active mission hint system to give the player suggestions on where to go or how to accomplish certain goals. For me, this would have been helpful after major segments of the game as it took a bit of trial and error to figure out where to go next. 

- Boss fights ranged from tedious to overly convoluted.

- If you’re an achievement hunter this game is not hard to fully complete. But, some of the fishing challenges (The Botfish) were ridiculously frustrating.

Final Verdict:
I recommend this game, but only if it’s on sale. While there are numerous positives to Oceanhorn, there are design and game play elements which unquestionably detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

16016152.review:
What happens when you take an all-too-familiar formula like Zelda, tweak it ever so much, release it on iOS, then eventually on PC? Well, you get Oceanhorn Monster of Uncharted Seas. What seems like a Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker clone with an isometric camera, Oceanhorn has a style all its own. From sailing the high seas, spelunking dungeons for new items, and defeating bosses in a “spot and exploit the weakness” motif; sure this does sound a lot like Wind Waker, but hey, if you’re going to be influenced from a game series, why not one of the most renouned and beloved? Bonus points for borrowing so heavily from one of the strongest games in said franchise.

No one who plays Oceanhorn will be able to deny the various Legend of Zelda inspirations throughout, but just because it has all of these various ideas and tropes in place, is that a bad thing? Yes and no. Yes because a lot of Zelda fans are rather tired of the same Zelda formula the recent games have instituted: go to dungeon, get a new item, use that item on the dungeon’s boss, repeat 6-8 times, learn midway through of a legend about a green tunic’d warrior that will save the land, exposition a bit more, Triforce wielders confront, roll credits. We realize that’s a snarky critique, but it’s also valid. Oceanhorn at least avoids a lot of these tired ideas and throws us back to a more retro Zelda premise. Those who have played the very first Legend of Zelda on NES will recall the game was rather obtuse and almost too open. Players load the game up and are thrust into a world, onto a screen that has three directions: north, west, and east, with a single cave wherein player will find a weapon (sound familiar, yet?). Oceanhorn feels more like a 1989 Zelda than anything else in terms of world design and instructions.

A few players may be turned off by the lack of hand-holding and direction in the opening hours, but for us here, it was a refreshing take. We’ve become spoiled by overly-simplistic tutorials and being lead through opening segments with lengthy cutscenes and explanations about the world around us. Oceanhorn does seem to abandon the uniqueness it begins with after a few hours and lean on the Zelda formula, but it’s done progressively, making it a forgivable sin. There’s still the “collect x number of relics and defeat the ultimate evil” blueprint in place, but the dungeon exploration and puzzle solving is there to prevent boredom from overwhelming the player.

The gameplay takes place on dense lands ranging from single-tiered isles to several levels of housing and dungeons. Don’t be fooled by an island’s size while sailing up to it, there’s typically more below the surface than shown. The scale is lesser than Wind Waker, but this is no short game; expect to spend 10-15 hours with Oceanhorn, with an extra few for those that aim to collect any and everything the islands hold within. Puzzles will range from block-moving to hitting ranged targets with arrows. It’s never anything too strenuous, but a few were noodle scratchers that provided “eureka” moments when solved. Boss battles aren’t too genre-defying, but are more complex than one would think an iOS-to-PC game would be. Most bosses require a specific strategy to affect them, and finding out that strategy while strafing and dodging can provide a sense of tension few Zelda games can even subject us to. Tight rooms and multi-powered bosses can keep players on their toes during a fight.

Visually and audibly Oceanhorn is a like-it-or-leave-it presentation. Just like with nearly every other aspect, the main character borrows heavily from Link, even seemingly borrowing his Skyward Sword garb minus the hat, to head out on this adventure. Characters look great, full of colors, design, and polish, but few enemy types and marginally different skin swaps of some of them leave a lot to be desired. Lush environments and dark, diluted dungeons accentuate each other very well, but only vary by the end rather than consistently throughout. Nearly every over world island is practically the same look with a different layout; at least every themed dungeon has a personality and appeal. Voicework and composition are impressive given the small staff at handling the game, with many cutscenes providing adequate storytelling and delivery. Music is acceptable, if not a tad bit safe in the end. As fun and upbeat few of the songs are, there’s little that keeps us coming back to listen to more after the fact. It’s passable, and the influences are there, but the music just doesn’t have that lasting appeal that comes with other games, and especially Zelda games.

What was probably a great iOS game, where aside from DS titles, there were not many Zelda-esque games on the market; Oceanhorn was a relief and refreshing. Hitting Steam and diving into the deep end where Zelda clones are a dime a dozen, this little trek has heart, but fails to sail far enough from the rest of the pack to standout for too long. If you have a Zelda itch to scratch while waiting for more, Oceanhorn can fill that need, but don’t expect new ideas, only tweaked presentations on acquainted themes. Oceanhorn has depth and should be explored for those who truly enjoy its implementations and setup, but do be reserved when raising your sails and setting out, the seas aren’t as “uncharted” as they would like you to believe.

YES

+ Its small differences and appeal is good for Zelda fans

+ Engaging gameplay and puzzle-solving

- It’s an unapologetic Zelda clone, through and through, so your mileage may vary

- It’s likely a more impressive handheld game, not a great idea to port PC with even more competitors to compete against

(Review Front Towards Gamer: http://ftg.operationsupplydrop.org/2015/03/28/oceanhorn-monster-of-uncharted-seas-review-pc/)

16010425.review: Awesome mix of Zelda (better stolen then badly created), Golden Sun and much Eyecandy. Play it.

16007898.review:
An interesting setting, solid gameplay, nostalgic sense while innovating a genre in ways that make me wish THIS was the 3D Zeldas instead of OOT, MM, WW, TP, SS, etc...

Fully 3D environment, using a comfortable isometric view that is somehow not at all confusing or nightmarish (probably due to a lack of platform jumping), and 8 directional movement.

Sword swings and thrown objects track your pointer, unfortunately the pointer is invisible when i play, so i have to guess where my sword will swing first. Throwing is still ok because you can direct your throws with the wasd keys.

Music is nice, fits the atmosphere of the game, but i noticed a bit of repetition where the same theme was used for different similar environments. To be expected i suppose.

My biggest complaint is that the longer i play, the more it begins to lag. Fortunately the game saves between rooms, and if i feel a lag coming on, i just close the game and reopen it, that seems to reset the memory. Saved games pick up where you left off, either at a doorway or save point.

First boss wasn't challenging, and actually glitched, running into a corner instead of moving around the room or attacking. This creature was reused as a general monster later, so i don't think it was supposed to be as big a deal as what i anticipate will come later.

Boat travels are nice. You don't control the boat direction like in Wind Waker, but instead point out your destination on the map and it auto routes you to it, and after going up a few levels you get a gun for the boat and can then shoot crates and barrels, floating mines, and "octorocks" that are in the way. Fun little minigame that breaks the pace of the dungeon crawling and exploration.

I love the fact that, once you get bombs, you can really start going crazy with the combat and exploration. Only 5 bombs at first, but as you level up you can carry more. If there are visual clues about bombable walls, i haven't noticed any. I bombed a wall to see if it opened a path to a chest i couldn't reach, and it did, but noticed no discoloring, blocks, or cracks to indicate i could do so. This is oldschool wall bombing at it's finest.

Got it on sale for 8.99, and would strongly recommend this game at that price. Even for the normal price at around 15 dollars it is still a nice game.

If devs could fix the issues causing lag and my disappearing pointer, i'd give this at least a 9/10, as it is, i'll say 7.5/10

If you're a fan of the 2D Zelda series, Alundra, Landstalker, Light Crusader, or even Neutopia, give this game a try, you won't be disappointed!

15874389.review:
“Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas” is an interesting game in concept. It accurately compares itself to the “Legend of Zelda” titles and is definitely reminiscent of the core gameplay in that series. The interesting part however comes from the game being on mobile devices and PC, whereas Nintendo has so far only released Zelda games on their own consoles. “Oceanhorn” attempts to tap into a niche, and does it fairly well, despite lacking the polish that Nintendo fans have come to expect.

The game is a mostly isometric dungeon crawler game akin to Zelda games. Using a sword and shield, along with various items unlocked through the game, the goal is to progress through various dungeons and reach the boss of each area. At times this is much easier said than done, as the level layouts can be a bit confusing at times. The levels themselves however look fantastic, and generally speaking the game’s graphical quality is up to the standard of the Zelda games, just with a bit less bloom which is very welcome.

In fairness to the game, as of yet I haven’t run into any major issues that have stopped me from progressing or caused me to wonder what exactly the developer was thinking, however my problems with the game arise from a series of small things that are missing. The easiest way to describe it is unfortunately just to reiterate the first paragraph; the game lacks polish in many areas.

The graphics of the game, as previously mentioned are pretty great, the game genuinely looks gorgeous, especially the water used to sail between islands. However some texture glitches and clipping can stand out while trying to solve a puzzle, and the isometric viewpoint can be a bit of a problem at times even with an adjustable camera. The game’s combat is generally solid, however hitbox issues can make fighting a bit unsatisfying, and the music sits comfortably in between being great and defining the landscape as Zelda games use their soundtrack, and being fairly mediocre. I never found reason to complain, but unlike some other games in recent memory, it never left me wanting a soundtrack to slap on my phone.

However, a lot of the issues I’ve raised with this game are present in others like it, and are usually forgivable, however for something that compares itself to a Zelda game, it’s hard to not judge it in the same vein as those titles. That said, this review has been a bit harsh so far -- while the game definitely lacks the polish of Zelda titles, it brings some of its own traits to the table which add to the game.

An experience system and a sprint function without having to wait to unlock the Pegasus Boots is likely the biggest improvement, as being able to zip around places you’ve already been through means hopping right back into a dungeon is always just a couple seconds away. The challenges offer experience as a reward and can add some interesting depth to the game, assuming it’s not a simple one like breaking several pots, something Zelda fans were going to do anyway.

Overall, the game does a decent job at mimicking the Zelda series, but as stated before multiple times, the lack of polish can stand out and may put some people off from the title. That’s unfortunate, because the game is generally enjoyable. It makes some legitimate improvements to the formula of Zelda titles, it’s just hard to not look at some aspects of the game and wish the developers had a bit more experience behind them so they could smooth out the rough bits. That said, it’s an enjoyable experience that at the least attempts to shake things up a bit.

3/5

15859635.review:
This is a mobile port and it definitely shows. The game is pretty enough, voice acting is decent, but the gameplay itself is dull. The controls feel clunky, especially in combat where your hits do not always register if you attack the enemy too fast. Magic takes too long to be useful most of the time, and even when it is needed it feels underwhelming. An item you get lets you jump across small gaps and dodge roll, both of which are keyed to the same button. The game will let you fall from areas up to a certain height, which means you can be doing a timed puzzle and then inadvertantly (and commonly) dodge roll instead of jumping to the next platform and have to do the entire thing over. 

Damage is inconsistent, with bombs doing massive damage to some enemies but barely a scratch to others... and yet those other enemies will take a big chunk of damage from a random pot thrown at them. Speaking of pots, you have to either throw, shoot them, or throw a bomb at them to break them... your sword is evidently the sword of not smashing pots.

Bosses are few and far between, and most are unimpressive. I died a few times to them, not because they were hard, but because of completely unavoidable attacks, the boss freezing (status, not game freezing) the mechanic to damage it and the only way to unfreeze it aside from letting it time out is your magic with the very long windup, or just poorly designed.

Travel between islands is set on pre-set paths, you tell the game to go and it drops you into a little shooting gallery where you spam the attack button to kill anything that gets in the way until you reach the island. On mobile I'm sure it was neat, tap to kill the things, but on pc its just feels like a boring, spam your mouse button and go add-on. 

Overall, the game is probably very good on mobile platforms, but not a very good pc game, and comparing it to zelda is like comparing a perfectly cooked steak to a $1 Banquet microwave dinner.

15398527.review:
Oceanhorn is shamelessly inspired by the Zelda franchise but unfortunately it doesn't quite hold up to the big "Z" in terms of polish. More specifically, there are just too many inconsistencies with the gameplay and visuals. Some players may ignore these issues considering it’s an indie game but it's apparent that several of them are due to sheer laziness and that's something I can't forgive.

I'll give you an example. The first issue I spotted, even from the trailer, is that the animations are simply stiff. The main character's idle animation is a big offender here. This is because almost all of the animations use a linear transition which creates a really rigid and unnatural feel. This can be solved with easement scaling and a little bit of hand-crafting. Basically the animators were lazy. A minor issue, but the game is FULL of  these minor issues and it's incredibly abrasive after a while.

At one point I fell down a "hole" that I thought was suppose to be the entrance of a cave. My character stopped shortly after falling only few feet, landing on solid ground.  His head bobbed in his rigid little idle animation for a brief moment. I thought that maybe I was mistaken about it being a cave entrance but then the game transitioned into another scene where my character was falling from a cave ceiling. I then realized that the developers simply made the entrance hole too shallow and this broke the illusion of actually falling through it. When I later got back out of the cave the grass that had grown over the entrance when it was undiscovered was there again, floating in mid-air. See what I mean by lazy?

Another huge problem is the absolutely shameless use of invisible walls. Many games use invisible walls but it's pretty hard to forgive in this case. You can only walk off ledges in very specific places and it's not nearly as obvious as it should be. In fact it's almost arbitrary. It just feels weird trying to constantly mime your way off a short ledge.

The allusion to the Zelda series can't just be called inspiration. It's actually a little offensive how much they rely on established Zelda mechanics. For example there are pieces of heart and they work pretty much like you would expect them to. You find them in random chests and you need exactly four of them to create a heart container. I mean, they are literally called "Pieces of Heart". Not convinced? There are crustacean-like enemies that shoot projectiles at you but dig into the ground when you come near them. You defeat them by shielding their projectiles which bounce back at them. I'm not even kidding.

The intent of copying Zelda mechanics are so desperate and obvious that the game should be called "Shoehorn". Exploration is based around the open-ocean feeling of Wind Waker, for instance. That itself isn't a bad thing but they copied the mechanic in the most superficial way possible. Instead of having any sort of interaction with the actual sailing of your ship, you simply click your destination and then watch as your tiny little vessel coasts its way along the featureless ocean at a snail's pace. This may have been somewhat scenic if it weren't for the main character looking around like a dork with his robot movements I feel like any time a game makes me want to get up and make a sandwich instead of actually playing is a huge red flag. I'm sure some players find this relaxing but for the less patient of us, an option to skip this would have been nice. 

I think the real thing that bothers me is that I really had high expectations from the game but it feels more like a Zelda cash-in than a love letter. There may be in fact a real gem under here, but I certainly didn't feel the need to find it.

15257210.review:
It's true: Despite its own graphical style, isometic viewpoint, and some other quirks, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is essentially a Legend of Zelda style game inside. But why is this a bad thing? As a diehard Zelda fan, I welcome the gaming industry to create their own attempts at Zelda-like games, whether from AAA developers or indies. And Oceanhorn does a fine job of being a fun game, even though almost all of its major elements are pretty much lifted from the Zelda series. But let's be fair here, bows, bombs, swords, shields, and sailing are far from monopolized by Zelda.

Getting into Oceanhorn itself, there's a lot to like about this game. The art style has its own charm, the isometric viewpoint is neat and a nice callback to games like Mario RPG and Landstalker, and the music... sublime. It all comes together in a wonderful presentation package that should delight anyone who can see past the game's obvious inspiration. The controls, for the most part, are pretty fluid, especially considering this is a port of an iOS game, and it felt just right on a controller, although the main character does move just the smallest bit slower than I'd like him to. The sailing atmosphere is gorgeous, and it's fun visiting new islands and charting them out, learning what secrets and people dwell there. The puzzles, while not entirely brainteasers, were the right amount of clever and made the game feel fluid. Dungeons are clever and designed expertly, with creative boss fights I quite enjoyed. In some ways it's a bit on the easy end, but no easier than your typical Zelda game.

The cons with this game are minor. There's the often-cited lack of a map screen, which would have been very handy. I find it odd that you can't dash or roll up steps, which would be nice for speeding up action. And the sailing is even more restrictive than that of Phantom Hourglass; in that game you could at least plot a course, but here, you can only select a destination. I would have liked a little more control, especially in that gorgeous atmosphere, but it's a minor concern.

Also, the game is too short. :(

But that's both a pro and a con; a con, because the game did feel a bit on the shorter side, and a pro, because I only wanted more.

In short, Oceanhorn is worth it if you're a fan of adventure games, especially Zelda obviously, whose only shortcomings are minor. Hopefully the game becomes successful enough to warrant a sequel in the future. Great product, Cornfox & Brothers, and may you see continued success!

15067812.review:
***Disclosure: Key was provided by the developer for review purposes***

It's basically a Zelda-clone. And it really doesn't hide that fact at all. One of the very first things you encounter are pots you can pick up and throw in order to destroy them. There are bushes you can cut down with your sword in order to collect money, bombs and arrows and you have to explore dungeons in order to collect three pieces of a mystical item that helps you defeat the final boss. You also get a new, stronger sword and a new shield over the course of the game. The only thing it doesn't directly lift form Zelda games is the fact that there isn't a princess in this. Otherwise it's an extremely faithful homage to Link's adventures, especially Wind Waker and Phantom Hourglass, since it incorporates a lot of sailing as well. 

I think the most interesting aspect about the game is the fact that it actually came out on mobile devices first. Because while playing it on PC, I honestly wouldn't have guessed its origins. The interface is perfectly adapted for PC and it's playable with both controller and mouse and keyboard. And for a mobile game it's definitely quite a lengthy game to play. It took me on PC around 10 hours to get through and I haven't even collected all the hidden secrets in there and even for a proper PC game the length is adequate enough. The only thing it's lacking is good bossfights. There are only really six bossfights and two of those don't involve any strategies beyond holding up your shield and countering when the enemy is exposing himself. Three of the boss fights are the ones where you collect the faux-Triforce shards and then the last one at the very end. Even though you need to employ different tactics to beat them, they're not all that challenging to figure out. 

And since there's only three shards to collect, there are only really three big dungeons to explore. The other dungeons are very small and don't contain many puzzles. And speaking of the puzzles, they're mostly very easy block pushing or switch pressing puzzles. Only one of the puzzles was rather hard for me to guess, the rest is fairly straightforward. 

Other than that I can say that I'm very pleased with the art style. They really managed to capture the typical whimsical Zelda aesthetic. Though what elevates the experience is definitely the soundtrack. It does take a lot of inspiration from other video game composers, but it's still very enjoyable and very fitting to all your surroundings. 

If there's one problem I had, at least with the beta build I got for review purposes, it's the amount of crashes I suffered. The game constantly crashed on me for no apparent reason, and it had tremendous difficulty maintaining 60 FPS on my rig which is saying a lot. Though I did notice that the crashes subsided on the day prior to release, so maybe they've fixed it. Though really, the crashes were only annoying in the sense that I had to restart the game. Because the auto-save function is pretty damn awesome in this game, I barely lost any progress while playing it, so there's that at least.

In the end, it's an obvious Zelda-clone because that's exactly what it wants to be. And for an effort from a small indie studio form Finland it's definitely not a bad one. It obviously can't hold a candle to a proper Zelda-game, but keep in mind that they're created by an army of programmers, artists and composers who basically swim in Nintendo-money.

15052968.review:
***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a zelda-style RPG Adventure game currently available on Steam. In Oceanhorn you play as a boy who's father has left him a notebook and a mysterious necklace, you read the notebook and follow in your father's footsteps in attempting to slay the legendary Oceanhorn. In order to be able to defeat Oceanhorn you must travel the length and bredth of the Uncharted Seas to find ancient artifacts and powerful magic all while solving puzzles and fighting enemies.

Just to say I have actually played the game longer than Steam says but due to disconnecting it hasn't saved all of my progress.

+Nice graphics which are bright and colourful
+A large map filled with many large islands for you to explore
+The world itself and the stories behind the different locations are quite interesting
+Outstanding soundtrack
+Quite a lot of items to unlock as you progress through the game
+The three biomes as well as the islands that make them up are very different to the others
+The game's puzzles are challenging without being painfully difficult
+Nice variety of enemies
+Simple combat system which for the most part is good (I'll come back to this later)
+Very relaxing to play
+Appropriate for all ages
+Full controller support and I suggest you do play with a controller

+/-Voice acting is very hit and miss in Oceanhorn, some of the time I thought it was quite good other times it just falls flat

-The story isn't particularly interesting
-I experienced a lot of framerate slow downs to pretty much single digits, judging from other reviews this is a problem for more than just me
-Sailing between islands is pretty dull as you can't steer your ship, only shoot objects with a gun you unlock and these sections cannot be skipped

Worth a mention:
-Oceanhorn was originally an iOS game which has now been ported to PC which could explain some of the performance issues

Verdict:
8

A fun and relaxing RPG, Adventure game with nice graphics and an outstanding soundtrack that helps to prove that not all iOS ports are bad.

El K.

*Recommended for Zelda lovers.

I'm about half way through the game.
You can tell it took a lot of influence from the Zelda series, but it lacks that feeling of true adventure.

I'm enjoying the game, and I think it's worth a try. It's not terribly expensive, but I would probably wait for a sale.

Each area is fairly linear with only a few secrets on each island.
The travel method is automatic, so don't expect to explore the ocean. I haven't hit a fast travel option yet, which would be nice.

The difficulty is like a rollercoaster. Minions are very easy and have a simple AI, while bosses are extremely powerful and use cheap tricks to destroy you.

The story is good enough to keep me interested, but I'm not burning through the game to find out what's going to happen.

While my laptop is older now, the game isn't optimized well for Windows. The framerate drops often. It's most likely using OpenGL instead of Directx (especially that using DX would require severe amounts of recoding)

Overall, I enjoy the game, so I recommend it. I just wish they gave us a bit more to explore.

15022075.review:
[i]Oceanhorn[/i] is clearly inspired by the games in the [i]Legend of Zelda[/i] series. I mostly see it compared to [i]The Wind Waker[/i] because it takes place on a series of islands, but it's really more similar to [i]Phantom Hourglass[/i] and [i]A Link to the Past[/i]. You don't have free reign of your boat like in [i]Wind Waker[/i], but instead select an island from your map and a path is automatically charted. During the trip, you must shoot down attacking octopi and mines, but everything is on-rails. Most of the map is locked away at the game's start, but additional islands appear when you learn about them from NPC's or other sources.

The main game takes place on an isometric grid. One thing to keep in mind which is very important for puzzle-solving and finding hidden secrets is that you can only drop down from above by a distance of one "block". If this isn't possible, then you will simply walk to a cliff's edge and stop. Combat is simple and a bit loose, but it works okay. You have access to items such as bombs and arrows which help out in combat. In particular, I found bombs to be very potent against stronger enemies.

Block puzzles are featured fairly often, though they never become too complex. Most of the other puzzles are more of the navigational variety, and you'll really only find a challenge if you look for optional collectables. [i]Oceanhorn[/i] features "Challenges" similar to what you see in many mobile games. Each island you visit brings with it three new challenges, some that are general goals (i.e. "Defeat 50 skeletons") and some that are specific to that island. Completing these challenges rewards you with a large amount of experience points. You can also gain experience by defeating enemies, but it can be a bit of a grind. When you level up your abilities become more efficient (require less stamina), you can hold more consumable items, or other various bonuses. 

There are also optional items to collect called Bloodstones, which eventually unlock a powerful spell. I noticed these items early on, but I thought I had to get some sort of shovel or something to dig them out. It turns out, you just have to whack them with your sword like twenty times to collect them. I don't think the game ever mentioned this, so I was kind of annoyed when I realized this after I passed by so many during the first few dungeons.

The graphics are nice and clean, although in motion the animations could have been better. I played this game entirely on a 37" TV at about 10 feet away, and sometimes the text was a bit too small. (Though it didn't help that I played it until 1:00 A.M. the last few nights.) This originally started as a mobile title, so at times you can see its origins peeking through. Overall, though, I'd say this port was pretty good. The music is nice, although it does sound pretty similar to Wind Waker at times. I had heard that the mobile version [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=zJwSAru1ZyA#t=130]featured several songs by Nobuo Uematsu[/url] of [i]Final Fantasy[/i] fame, but I'm not sure if his songs were replaced for the PC version as I did not see his name in the credits at all.

The controls worked great with my Xbox 360 controller. I did have the game lock up on me a few times, but it was usually right when I launched the game so I did not lose any progress. I did have to exit to the title screen once because I got my character stuck somewhere they weren't supposed to go to. Fortunately, the game auto-saves frequently so it was no big deal.

Like Link from the Zelda series, the main character of [i]Oceanhorn[/i] is mute. In most Zelda games, however, some sort of proxy character is present to give some sort of voice to Link. The nameless main character of [i]Oceanhorn[/i] lacks this, and coupled with an always emotionless face, you really don't get a feeling of any personality for him at all. The other characters in the game fared a bit better, though none of them were too memorable. In addition to other humans, the world of Arcadia features bird-like Owrus and fish-like Gillfolk. While a bit clichéd, the emerging backstory was interesting enough to keep me playing, and had a slight twist that I didn't expect.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with [i]Oceanhorn[/i]. It's not perfect, but it's a decent substitution for a Zelda game on PC. It's much shorter than recent Zelda titles and isn't padded with a lot of filler. It may be a Zelda clone, but it's certainly a competent one so I'm not going to complain.

15017605.review:
I have no idea why anyone would recommend this game to people who like the Zelda games. Why would you want to play an inferior version of Zelda? Because that's essentially what this is, a bad version of Zelda. I love the design, and the atmosphere is cool, but other than this game is pretty mediocre. The camera is locked, you're kind of weak (I haven't gotten the Coral Sabre yet, however), the stamina system stinks (although it does make sense, it just hampers the game, it doesn't add anything), your ammunition is super low until you hit the max level (where you can hold 99 bombs and 99 arrows), the monsters drop far too little money and experience, the items lack originality, the puzzles aren't that creative. 

The one thing I think the developers did well is the drop rate, which is very high, so your low amount of maximum ammunition doesn't severely hamper you as it's pretty easy to fill your bomb bag and quiver up. The ship travels quickly from island to island as well, so that's another good point. So yeah, if you've never played a Zelda game and you want to get into the Zelda series, then do play this. If you HAVE played Zelda, don't play this, as it's worse than pretty much any Zelda game ever released.

Edit: Also, the music is fantastic.

15012783.review:
Oceanhorn is an adventure game heavily inspired by the legend of zelda series, namely The Wind Waker to be exact but even though it resembles a lot of that series, it in it's own way has it's unique flavor and gameplay to it making it just different enough from the series it's paying homage to.

There are some things the game does that is a bit more seamless, like the ability to swap your sub-weapons on the fly without needing to go into the menu by just pressing the d-pad in that direction, the boat sections seam to be more straight forward that resembles Phantom Hourglass and a level up system that grants things like more bombs, faster boat traveling, money and such that takes the hassle of having to find some of the upgrades yourself.

Some of the things that could have been better, would include the puzzles which while simple and fun were a bit too simple and pretty straight forward, majority of the boss battles a tad on the easy side,  the graphic options can be taxing on the best of PCs, and the storyline. 

The problem with the story is that while once again seams to resemble the ideology of TLoZ series, it seams rushed in some parts, and dis-jointed in others with some of the ambiance it tries to convey lost due to odd timing in cutscenes and dialog, which seam out of place with some characters.

The Graphic problem on Pcs stems from graphic options that cause slow-down and need some optimization for PCs, which isn't all too bad on custom settings or medium settings as the game itself looks fantastic visually.
 
However with those problems, it doesn't take away from the enjoyment of the game nor the fun you have in this game which is presented with a nice looking isometric view.

If your a fan of TLoZ series and want to try something simular on the PC. This 8 to 14 hour game is worth checking out.

If you can get this game for $5 bucks, give it a chance. Otherwise don't purchase.

15011779.review:
This game was marketed as a Zelda clone.  However, it is not even close.  The only similarities are, bows, bombs, and swinging a sword.  It ends there.  There are no original gadgets, no compelling storyline, no challenging boss fights, and no challenging puzzles.  The entire game feels extremely limited.  There is no real mystery to character development and the storyline is petty.  All of the mobs require the same logic to defeat and there are very few variations of them.  

If this were to be a clone, then where are all of the extra gadgets and related puzzles?  The only extra "gadget" you get is the ability to jump over 1 block.  There are a total of ~10 types of creature to defeat, but really only 4 different types: flyers, biters, sword swingers, and archers.  All of them are weak against everything.  So there is no real need to mixup your playstyle.  Bosses show a little bit of variety, but are too simplistic.  

The competition offers variance between mobs.  Some mobs can only be killed with bombs, others with the bow.  You could use a boomerang to stun them or grab what they dropped.  The puzzles in the competition actually required thinking.  This game blatently points out what exactly needs to be done to solve just about all of the puzzles.  

So, if you want an incredibly easy and boring ripoff, this is your game.  Otherwise, I'd only consider purchasing this during summer sale at the price it is worth - ~$3.

15002765.review:
Landstalker meets The Legend of Zelda. There are obvious nods to The Wind Waker in the world setting and locales right down to an ocean landscape dotted with islands, but that did not stop Cornfox & Bros from developing their game the way they wanted. The isometric view harkens back to an era that has long since disappeared in the realm of Z-targeting and free roam cameras - a programming art that was funnily enough perfected in The Wind Waker.

The story starts off simple enough with a young man's father having disappeared in the search for Oceanhorn. The main character sets off with an interaction level akin to the Zelda titles; jars are picked up and smashed on the ground, grass blades are slashed, boulders are blown apart by bombs. However there is an enjoyable yet simple physical meat to the main character in Oceanhorn. Even something as basic as wading in water brings about a speed penalty. A sign that the developers pay attention to the minutia of videogames.

The graphics are gloriously bright and colourful. The story won't set your imagination alight with wonder but it does the job. And the music is outstanding - sooner or later you'll be humming and whistling to the overworld theme.

It's a pity that this game may fly under the radar despite the reception it could and should achieve. Games like this don't come around too often anymore considering the monopoly of Zelda, so don't be deceived by the "smartphone game" approach by some commentators. Oceanhorn is a delight and I look forward to whatever else comes out from the Finnish caverns of Cornfox & Bros.

14982511.review:
8.5/10
[h1]The game itself[/h1]
"If it has to be a ripoff, then at least make it a good ripoff."

It seems the devs of this game took that to heart, because it feels a lot like The Legend of Zelda - The Wind Waker, but not in a wrong way: The world is a huge ocean with a bunch of islands on it, you have a boat and sail from/to said islands, you collect heart pieces to expand your [strike]dong[/strike] health bar and you get a lot of items which, of course, have to be used in the dungeons you found them in.
The biggest and probably only differences: You can learn and cast spells, and you level up by getting experience points from killing enemies and by completing challenges (e.g. "Sail to all islands" or "Kill 50 Skeletons"). Don't worry about the latter, you only get passive bonuses like being able to carry more bombs or sailing a little faster when you level up.

The only annoying thing: You can't skip sailing from island to island. It's not the sailing that is annoying, it's the flotsam, mines and even Oktoroks (I don't know their name in this game, so I'll use the Zelda one) which you have to shoot EVERY TIME you're traveling via boat. If you don't, you either arrive at your goal with low health or you die on the way to it.
Wind Waker made it so that you can lean back while your boat rushes across the ocean. If an enemy shows up it either gives up chasing you after a couple of seconds (Gyorg) or it keeps missing you with its shots (Oktorok). You can always choose to fight them for some extra rupees, arrows or bombs, but you don't have to.
Oceanhorn makes sailing a pain in the behind, because it always spawns stuff into your way and because your boat always sails TOWARDS it, which you can't prevent, since the game does not allow you to control your boat. A third of the game is literally "just sitting there and shooting at stuff".
Enough about that.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Although it's a port of a smartphone game, the graphics are pretty nice. The faces may lack emotions, the talking animation looks a little jerky and the terrain consists of blocks (which you can NOT mine, dear hardcore Minecraft fans), but all that gives the game some sort of "unique artstyle".

[h1]Music[/h1]
The (quite repetitive) soundtrack reminds of Final Fantasy, which is probably the dev's fault, since they "hired" Nobuo Uematsu and Kenji Ito.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
You're a Zelda fan? You enjoyed Wind Waker? Get this game.

The music, voice acting and sound effects are all on point. Visually the world and monsters are a colorful treat, even if they aren't the most original. Bottom line, if you're a fan of the Zelda series then I believe you'll love Oceanhorn!

14972474.review:
This game totally caught me by surprise. It's an incredibly well done Zelda clone(circa Link to the Past) with a healthy dose of the elevation-based problem solving from the classic Genesis adventure Landstalker. The game takes all it can from Zelda right down to the pieces of heart collectibles and block pushing puzzles to the simplistic but effective hack and slash combat. Heck, even the world map is itself a total Windwaker copycat(however nowhere near as tedious or annoying). 

It adds it's own features here and there such as a leveling system, quests and a tad more open exploration than certain Zelda titles, and a more involved story but it's part and parcel a huge homage to the trend setting franchise. In no way is that a knock to the game's character because it's all done nearly as well as an indie dev could do so.

The music is another feature that struck me as well. It's another high quality aspect of an already high quality product, even if it sounds slightly Zelda-ish at times (when you first leave your house, you'll instantly get the feeling you've been here before).

If you're someone who loves Zelda or hack and slash adventures in general, you can't go wrong with picking this game up. It would seem so far that it's going to be at least a solid 20-30 hours to fully complete also, possibly more so it's totally worth the price for a game that even begins to touch the greatness that is Zelda.

14972427.review:
[h1]1. Intro
2. Technical
3. Gameplay
4. Pro's, Cons, conclusion[/h1]

[h1]1. Intro:[/h1]
Hello review readers! The fact that you're reading this review means you're either potentially interested in this game or have played it & want to get another guy's opinion on the game you have been playing. I am currently still playing the game and have not finished it, about 5-6 hours in.

[h1]2. Techncial[/h1]
The game has full controller support (using xbox 360 controller for pc) and I would recommend playing it in this way. It is possible to play with mouse and keyboard, after testing both I decided to stick with he controller.

It's possible to change some graphical settings (shadows, screensize, etc.) up to a given point, I would have liked to have seen a little more options for this to make the game prettier/uglier depending on your hardware, but the basics are there.

What annoys me a little bit is that it seems to be poorly optimised for PC at this point. Meaning: even though you might have a high end gaming system, sometimes you will get the occasional FPS drop or screen tear here & there. Nothing major & gamebreaking though, but it did cause me to tone down the graphics a bit for more consistent FPS.
Nevertheless: the game has vibrant colours & is fun to look at, despite it not being "graphically advanced". The cartoony atmosphere grows on you, and I would not want to see this game with realisticly drawn characters & backgrounds, it feels fine the way it is.

I have not had any crashes yet & the game runs flawlessly, people on the community forums have reported otherwise and I did see dev responding to these topics regularly. If you are unsure if you can run this game, better ask people on the forums with similar specs what their experiences are.

[h1]3. Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay in my eyes, at first, was a bit "easy". Meaning: if you're looking for a "hard" game you will find little joy playing Oceanhorn. I'm not sure what age group i'd recommend this game for but i'd say something in the lines of 6+. If you (or your kid) can play games like Spyro the dragon or Skylanders/Disney Infinity, they can play this. It's not very hard, but to fully play the game they will need to understand the English language, be it to follow the story or just to read clues / where they should go next. The game starts off easy & keeps on making the puzzles more difficult, having you look around & go "hmm, what now" at regular intervals, keeping it interesting.

You get some freedom as in where to travel at any given point, yet, until you get some basic things handed to you by following the storyline (*minor spoilers, mouse over to show* [spoiler]bombs, a bow, a jump ability, stuff like that[/spoiler]), there is little to do other than follow the main route. It's a fake sense of freedom, but a sense of freedom nevertheless. After gaining a certain item or ability, you will often backtrack on the map or take sidepaths to reach areas you could not reach before.

The music is catchy at some points, making me hum it in the background while inside a dungeon / traveling around the world. They chose to not give the main character a voice in this game, as is common in a lot of these games, which I still kind of miss - I get that this is done to make the hero more relatable to you, giving you the option to give him your voice, but having a totally mute main hero has been done countless times and I find it more enjoyable when this isn't the case. That being said: the voice actors from the other people around the world sound kind of bland and I'm under the impression some bad/good guys were all voiced by the same person. They could have spiced this up a bit.

The story feels a bit cliché to me, as an adult, but what more do you need than save princesses and find your family to go on an adventure right?

[i](I hate to say this, but the similarities with Zelda are at some a little too obvious, take this as a good or a bad thing, that's up to you)[/i]


[h1]Pro's, cons, conclusion[/h1]


[table]
[tr]
[th]PRO[/th]
[th]CON[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Non-gamer friendly[/td]
[td]Sometimes too easy for frequent gamers[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Full controller support[/td]
[td]The way the game handles your hardware could be optimised[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Music is very nice[/td]
[td]Character voices are kind of bland[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]


Conclusion: Don't regret being curious enough to buy this game, have been having a lot of fun with it, albeit making the game/puzzles a little bit harder would not hurt. Very good step in game for friends/family who are not that experienced with gaming. Consider it a stepping stone into adventure/puzzle games to later hook them on something more complicated like Zelda, Tomb Raider, Prince of Persia, ...

If you must have a score, I rate this game 67/100, it would have gotten 70/100 if the voice actors could loosen up a little :-)

14965402.review:
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas caused a splash when it dropped on iOS back in 2013. It was plain to see that the game was an almost cut and paste rip, at least visually, from The Legend of Zelda: Windwaker, but it's unfair to call Oceanhorn a clone. To me, 'Clone' is a pejorative term reserved for the scores of cheap knock-offs occupying iOS, Android and Greenlight. Oceanhorn is better than that. It's a love letter to the Zelda series that brings similar, high quality design practices and gameplay values to gamers on iOS and PC. It doesn't quite sail into the same realm as Nintendo's flagship series but it's the closest another developer has ever come.

There's not much worth knowing about Oceanhorn's story, it's much the same as any Zelda game - so, as deep as a puddle and just about as interesting .The fabled sea monster called "Oceanhorn" has come back to your island, leaving your father to go fight it while you sleep. You find yourself alone with nothing but your mothers magical pendant to guide you, and off you pop on a Windwaker-style adventure in your dinky little boat- which, thankfully, doesn't talk this time.

You'll sail to new islands, each inhabited by people with interesting stories to tell, explore vast dungeons, and encounter creatures that are most definitely not ripped off from the Zora or Rito people.

Equipped with your sword and shield, you'll take on dangerous foes and some surprisingly well designed boss monsters. Combat isn't as tight as the Zelda games but it's an admirable impersonation, especially for a game that has made its way over from iOS. Controls can be a bit finicky and loose at times but they are otherwise fine, feeling just as good with the mouse and keyboard as they do with a gamepad.

The developers try their hardest to conjure up the same sense of adventure that can be found in A Link to The Past and Windwaker, and for the majority of the game they succeed. It's unlikely you will forget that you are playing a game very heavily based on a well-known franchise, but it's enjoyable nonetheless.

The game doesn't hold your hand, opting to leave you wander off in your own direction with nothing but the words of other people to guide you. You are free to travel around and explore, neglecting the main story, if you so choose.


Diving in to the meat of the game has you kill easy monsters in deep dungeons, solve simple puzzles, and collect elemental powers (where have we seen that before?). It's fairly standard stuff that even the Zelda franchise has dined out on for far too long. There's nothing particularly outstanding about any of Oceanhorn's action but its richly crafted, sun-kissed worlds are immersive and fun to explore. Ironically, for a game based around traversing large bodies of water, sailing isn't that fun. In fact, it's a bit dull - a complaint that was frequently directed at Windwaker, also. Any frustrations inspired by the mediocre sailing will at least be washed away by Oceanhorn's gorgeous soundtrack.

Audiovisual presentation is an area where Oceanhorn zips past its, rather sparse, competition. A beautiful world-class composer crafted soundtrack and pretty landscapes are destined to keep a smile on your face and a tune in your head.

In truth, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas can be a bit shallow, but it's hard to dislike a game so lovingly crafted - and with such respect for the source material from which it was created. Temper your expectations and you'll find an engrossing adventure that pays homage to one of gaming's greatest, never managing to step out of its shadow.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Disclosure: Review key provided by publisher. Full review available here at:
http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/03/oceanhorn-monster-of-uncharted-seas-review-pc/

14958296.review:
Puzzles involving hitting switches, pushing boxes, and pressure plates? ✔
Smashing ceramics and chopping grass for money? ✔
Bosses with titles? ✔
Copyright infringement? ✔

Imitation really is the best form of flattery. If you're a Zelda fan who's thirsty for adventure, look no further. For a port of a mobile game, Oceanhorn manages to look pretty. The visuals have been polished and everything looks shiny and new, but there are some framerate problems. The art style is pretty much ripped from The Wind Waker, so fans should feel right at home. Speaking of The Wind Waker, you get a boat! This is how you travel from island to island. Unfortunately, your boat doesn't talk and you can't steer it yourself. Traveling between islands is an on-rails affair, but there are enemies to keep you on your toes and driftwood to be smashed for the loot it contains. There's also a leveling system that basically replaces bigger quivers and bomb bags from the Zelda franchise. You gain experience from slaying baddies and attaining in-game achievements, which can force you to backtrack but do add to the longetivity of your adventure. Puzzles are a bit on the easy side and some items are a bit too familiar, but why fix gameplay that isn't broken? If you're a Zelda fan, Oceanhorn is a must-have for your Steam library.

+ Gameplay is immediately familiar
+ Environments are lovely, varied, and don't overstay their welcome
+ Great soundtrack

- Framerate issues
- Controls could be tighter
- Not being able to sail the ocean yourself is a bit of a bummer

14956252.review:
Awesome. I'm having a blast.

edit:
Since my 'review' above is getting downvoted, I asume you want to here more... so:

This game is meant for zelda fans who cant  wait 5 years to play a new chapter.  This is not an easy game type to imitate, therefore we dont have many(any?) games like this.

It's NOT a clone.  It doesnt infrenge on copyrights.  I love zelda and would be one of the first to cry foul if it was a rip off.  I'm happy to report its not.  This game has it's own personality.

In short, if you like zelda then GET IT, if you've never played zelda then go buy a nintendo.

The following is based on 15 hours of game play and I'm maybe 50% through the game.  
---

I will start with the differences from zelda:
1) locked camera: think Diablo.   2.5D-ish, very little ability to look around.
2) blocky world, think minecraft.  Very well designed but can get repetitive and a bit easy to forget.
3) No lock on targeting, you have to turn and face enimies to fight.

Similarities:
1) multiple islands, almost all with dungeons below ground
2) multiple spells, items, weapons, etc. earned as you go.
3) varied enimies and boss and mini boss battles
4) pretty epic story and characters. I didn't expect this part to be as good as it is.

PROS:
great graphics , animations, sound and music. story text is well written.
different areas and dungeons are very well layed out, quite intricate and detailed.
the story and characters make sense and everything progresses with a good pace.
combat works well.
very clean inventory screen.

CONS:
none, I really didn't expect this game to be as good as it is or come as close to a zelda experience as it does.

MINOR GRIPES:
no full screen map, mini map is hard to read.  I mean, roaches showing up as blue dots? why?
no free look / locked cam
enimies are too easy, puzzles have been to simillar and easy, too much block pushing
you can get lost, take this to who? 
sailing is on-rails mini-game, pick your destination island and shoot stuff on the way

Final Thoughts:
Fishing was done really well, actually almost everything the designers put in the game is done really well.  Very high standards of quality.  This game is fun.  I recomend it if you like zelda.

(I'll edit further if things change)

14942506.review:
Being an Android user, this came out of the blue for me. As a huge fan of the Legend of Zelda, and Zelda-likes, this is very much welcomed to my library.

The visual aesthetic is pretty much Wind Waker, with a touch of Minecraft inspired cubic layouts.

Gameplay wise, there is a very simple two button combat system. Your input options change dynamically as you approach objects you can interact with, which can work very well. Managing items is simple and forgiving; you're given more inputs for quick access than I've seen in most Zelda titles.

While the puzzles are mostly tried and true block and button puzzles, its a great trip back to nostalgia lane and leaves me wanting more modern releases from this genre.

Unlike other games of it's genre, there's a levelling system to Oceanhorn. Your character gains experiences through defeating monsters and completing specific goals. Then, through the adventurers guild, you are given access to different weapons and features in the game. This is a great way to tie progress to your regular combat and accomplishments throughout the game.

Cornfox and Bros have done a convincing and enjoyable unique recreation of the travel based Zeldas. I'm a huge fan of this so far, and I can't wait to see what else it has to offer.

14937161.review:
UPDATE:
3/17: Changed what I said about the game's leveling system. Added Video Review.

Wait... This was an IOS game? O_O

[u][url=https://youtu.be/krHe71mFfq4]See the game in action with the review in video form![/url][/u]

Pros:
_Looks alright: The game is colorful and bright, nothing particularly ground-breaking here, but not bad.
_Good music.
_Controls well: I don't know how it played on the iPad, but it plays well here for both Mouse-Keyboard and gamepad.
_The Legend of Oceanhorn, Ocarina of Uncharted Seas: It's clear where the game got its inspiration from. Although the tight-level design and interesting mechanics of Zelda isn't really here (Let's be honest, you shouldn't expect it to be), the game manage to  the Zelda games justice, to a degree, without ripping it off too much. It's like Oceanhorn sat next to Zelda on a test and manage to pull off a B- without the teacher's suspicion.

Cons:
_Where is my windowed mode? Man, TB is gonna freak the fuck out: Ya, for some reason you can't have windowed mode. You can have borderless though, so that's good. But for people who connects their PC to a TV, you'll have to play this game on  a huge resolution.
_The leveling system: This is where the whole "this game used to be on iPad" thing showed its head. You "level up" by completing challenges, but you don't get anything from it, other than just some ingame coins. That is some IOS stuff right there. But no big deal. UPDATE: There's actually more than the leveling system than that, so scratch this off of the list of cons.
_Voice acting is meh.

Overall, you would like this game if:
_You think IOS ports to PC can be done and are looking for some proof.
_You think IOS ports to PC CAN'T be done and are looking to prove yourself wrong.
_You like The Legend of Zelda games.

Is this game worth $15: Yes. It's pretty good. Not in the GOTY sense, but it's very, very decent, borderline excellent for its price.

Seriously, though, I can't believe this game is an IOS port...

14936450.review:
There’s no way of skirting the issue – this game is a Zelda clone, through-and-through. From the bombs and arrows to the comically oversized chests you find them in, Oceanhorn is a mere re-skin mod away from being the Zelda release for PC we all so desperately long for. In fact, this may well be the closest we will ever get.

Is that necessarily a bad thing? I don’t think so. While it shows little in the way of originality, it does a great job of reproducing the magic spark that keeps players coming back. Make no mistake – this is no cheap copy, and will easily keep you entertained for hours. It would have been great to see Cornfox & Bros. take a few more risks to give the game more of a distinct personality, but don’t let that stop you from casting off on this excellent adventure on the open seas.

Read my full review here: http://www.hookedgamers.com/pc/oceanhorn_monster_of_uncharted_seas/review/article-1433.html

14932869.review:
Waking up during a stormy night you find your father has left, leaving a notebook and strange necklace behind. What happened? Where did he go? It's your job to find out.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JjkNpmvSuxU
Oceanhorn is a port of a mobile game from 2013, rather then being a direct port much effort has gone into remastering the game for PC. Was it worth the wait? [b]YES[/b]. Graphically speaking it's just as amazing as the first time you may have played it. Adding 4k+ res, realtime AO, soft shadows, AA, higher draw distance and 60FPS support among other things. While the game played well with keyboard+mouse or controller, everything was completely rebindable.

Staying true to the Zelda formula while keeping a charm of its own, you travel the between islands on your ship gradually piecing together the story. Each island has it's own distinct themes and challenges while some just serve as hub points for restocking and gathering new information about undiscovered locations. Progress will result in level ups which unlocked a range of upgrades including a peashooter for firing off your ship. Later stages traveling becomes quite dangerous so these extra defenses are critical.

Dungeons generally consist of simple puzzles and key finding while backtracking to unlock areas you were unable to access earlier. Select islands contain boss fights and victory often rewarded unique abilities which also helped with opening secret areas. While you do spend much of your time traveling to locations already seen it's not a problem at all, as you will also find many new npcs and sidequests along the way.

Oceanhorn is a little on the easy side but the beauty of the entire package completely out weighs the lack of challenge. The game does ramp up in the later stages and you'll need to learn different attack patterns of enemies to guarantee success. Already mentioned the graphics are very distinct, the closest game to the mark would be Lili: Child of Geos (another decent phone port). With a captivating story, relaxing soundtrack and a whole bunch content to discover. For the asking price it's well worth the investment. Cheers.
